IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Perinatal stroke may lead to the secondary diagnosis of cerebral palsy and life-long movement impairment. By studying processes of early brain recovery and how recovery is related to brain development and movement in the first two years of life, we can develop effective, early treatments for infants with perinatal stroke. Minimizing future disability through early interventions would greatly improve quality of life and reduce burden on children and families.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative This project will focus on Patient-Ventilator Asynchrony (PVA) in children through a prospective observational study in 3 pediatric ICUs, in addition to detailed analysis of existing data and data being gathered as part of an ongoing clinical trial which is testing a novel ventilator strategy. We will characterize the frequency and risk factors for common PVA subtypes in children, identify if PVA is independently associated with poor clinical outcomes and characterize the physiologic pathways which may be involved, and develop automated tools to improve the clinical recognition of PVA in children.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Myonemes are protein-based supramolecular springs that generate high power outputs in response to calcium, to enable rapid contractile motion in some protozoan cells. This project will utilize biophysical techniques to uncover how these springs generate force and develop synthetic myonemes that can be triggered using light. Myonemes have tremendous potential as biosensors, drug-delivery devices and artificial cytoskeletons in synthetic cells, and this research will the groundwork for adapting these nanomachines to novel biomedical function.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative Mutations in the gene encoding Gα-Interacting Protein, C-terminus 3 (GIPC3) are known to cause profound hearing loss in humans. This project explores the role of GIPC3 in mechanoelectrical transduction of mammalian cochlear hair cells. Therefore, the study may identify mechanistic causes of hearing loss in patients carrying specific GIPC3 mutations, potentially contributing to new clinical treatments.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Every year, approximately 100,000 Veterans seek help at VA Audiology clinics for hearing and communication difficulties only to learn that they have normal hearing sensitivity. Unfortunately, there are very few established options to improve hearing and listening for these patients. To address this need, audiologists are increasingly prescribing hearing aids set to provide a small amount of amplification. Patients may benefit from the amplification or from modern hearing aid features such as noise reduction technology and the ability to stream sounds from a desired sound source directly to their ears thus reducing the background noise. This project will help to determine if prescribing hearing aids to patients without hearing loss is, in fact, beneficial and if so, why. It will also help to determine if some patients benefit more from hearing aids than others so that in the future, rehabilitation strategies can be better targeted toward individuals.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Sepsis is a lethal condition commonly complicated by kidney failure (AKI) yet, despite decades of investigation we lack reliable predictors and treatment. In the present study we will utilize mouse models of sepsis associated AKI (sAKI) to establish blood-based biomarkers correlated with critical stages in the pathogenesis of renal tissue injury which will be used to diagnose and stage human AKI blood samples. The immediate outcome of this work will be the development of a liquid biopsy to diagnose and stage human sAKI.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Chemotherapy-related cognitive decline (CRCD) is a common and consequential complication of cancer treatment, yet no standard of care exists to prevent or treat CRCD. This three-arm randomized controlled trial will examine the feasibility, acceptability, and preliminary efficacy of memantine and exercise to mitigate cognitive decline in patients with breast cancer undergoing chemotherapy. This study will contribute several insights important to improving cognitive outcomes in patients with cancer, including: feasibility of multicomponent medication and behavioral intervention trials for CRCD; preliminary efficacy of combined memantine and exercise, as well as of memantine alone, for cognitive decline and underlying mechanisms of CRCD; and characterization of the impact of frailty on treatment-related changes in cognitive function and CRCD biomarkers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Over 30-50% of autologous vein grafts (VG) used to treat coronary artery disease and occlusive peripheral arterial disease fail within 5-10 years of surgery due to intimal hyperplasia (IH). To address this unmet clinical need, we propose to bioengineer VG with the potent atheroprotective molecule A20, using advanced AAV and circular RNA gene therapy (GT) platforms. This first-in-class therapy that can be directly implemented on the operating table will be tested in two relevant animal models of VG failure, in prelude for clinical translation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The goal of this application is to explore the development and feasibility of a brief, family-based adaptive intervention, via SMART design, for youth 10 to 14 years with suicidal and non-suicidal self-injurious behavior (SSIB) to increase community-based mental health (MH) care attendance and reduce SSIB risk post emergency department (ED) admission. The intervention will focus to increase understanding on youth MH literacy, MH communication, and MH engagement. Integrating an adaptive intervention via a SMART design in the ED could address subsequent barriers to youth obtaining appropriate level of community-based MH care and therefore reduce ED readmissions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  The ability to dynamically switch cell states enables cancer cells to adapt to environmental and therapeutic challenges, however, the molecular mechanisms that cancer cells employ to maintain or switch states have not been fully characterized. This proposal aims to dissect the cell-intrinsic and extrinsic mechanisms underlying lung cancer cell plasticity by leveraging a newly developed single-cell lineage tracing technology. A comprehensive understanding of these mechanisms will reveal key gene networks that regulate tumor evolution, and could potentially inform rational therapeutic approaches.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Aberrant biosynthesis of human Sonic hedgehog (Hh) proteins in adult tumors results in a pro- growth survival signal that can spur tumor cell proliferation, invasiveness and chemoresistance. Here we pursue the first small molecules to specifically block Hh protein autoprocessing, a key step in the biosynthesis of these oncogenic effector proteins. We hypothesize that the cell- permeable small molecules discovered here will show anti-cancer activity against human myeloma and colon cancer cells, which we will test experimentally to establish the groundwork for a new class of targeted anti-cancer therapeutics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis (EGPA, formerly known as Churg Strauss syndrome) is a rare, serious disease of blood vessel and internal organ inflammation associated with high levels of immune cells called eosinophils. Patients who have EPGA affecting the intestine tend to do worse, underscoring a need to better understand eosinophils in the intestine. We discovered that signals derived from nutrients regulate small intestine eosinophils during normal conditions, and propose to understand how these signals work, to figure out the impacts of certain aspects of the microbiome, and to study small intestine eosinophils along with these factors in a mouse model of EGPA.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The overarching goal of this K01 Career Development Award is to foster Dr. Byoungjun Kim’s transition to independence as a social/spatial epidemiologist with expertise in examining neighborhood effects on chronic kidney disease (CKD). The proposed study will draw on quasi-experimental study design to investigate associations between co-occurring neighborhood conditions (e.g., social environments, food desert, walkability, and ambient pollutions) and CKD outcomes, leveraging electronic health record data from a national cohort of U.S. veterans. Findings from this work will contribute to the evidence base regarding nuanced causal mechanisms between various neighborhood exposures and CKD outcomes via its clinical causes and will shed light on potential place-based interventions to reduce health disparities in CKD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative The neurotransmitter dopamine (DA) is thought to play a central role in reward-based learning, but the precise nature of this role and how it may be implemented in neural circuits remain the subject of controversy. Taking a reductionist approach, this project leverages novel optical, electrophysiological, and machine learning tools to precisely identify the algorithmic and neural circuit basis of dopamine-driven learning in the striatum of behaving mice. By isolating and dissecting dopamine’s role in learning with unprecedented precision, this project has the potential to transform our understanding of diseases that involve the dysregulation of dopamine, including Parkinson’s disease, addiction, and mood disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Complications from preterm birth are the leading causes of global mortality in children under the age of five, yet currently there are no predictive diagnostics or preventative therapies for preterm pregnancies. Premature inflammation initiates the biological cascade that results in preterm labor and this proposal investigates the contribution of maternal antibodies to this process, identified using a new robust approach. In this proposal, I will chronicle maternal antibodies through the progression of pregnancy for non-invasive diagnostics development and dissect the molecular pathways that may serve as therapeutic entry points to diminish labor- promoting inflammation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Tourette Syndrome phenotypic presentations (comorbidity profiles, tic expression, developmental and cyclical patterns over time) vary widely across individuals. This project computationally examines tic change trajectories across 16 weeks using multi-method time series data to assess the impact of a behavioral intervention both within- and between-subjects. Results will inform the development of precision-medicine techniques to improve intervention outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Membrane tension is thought to be a long-range integrator of cell physiology and a central regulator of many cellular functions including membrane trafficking, cell fate, cell division, and organ homeostasis. We lack a basic understanding of how cells control the range and efficiency of membrane tension propagation. I propose a multipronged approach combining optogenetics, imaging, modelling, and membrane tension measurements to understand how membrane tension functions as a coordinator of cellular behavior.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Nearly 60-85% of Veterans with amputations experience pain at the location of the amputated limb called phantom limb pain (PLP). PLP is a major problem and can have a profound impact on Veteran’s daily function and ability to fully participate in life. Although several rehabilitation interventions are promising, advances in novel rehabilitation interventions are limited. The objective of this project is to refine a mobile app for graded motor imagery in 12 Veterans with amputations and test the mobile app with 36 Veterans with amputations. For this pilot project, we will measure the preliminary feasibility and acceptability of the intervention. Knowledge from this project will provide evidence to guide future larger studies of this graded motor imagery intervention. Developing novel strategies for chronic pain in this population will positively impact quality of life for Veterans with amputations.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Bipolar disorders (BD) are among the leading psychiatric causes of disability worldwide. Similarly, Veterans with BD are at heightened risk for poor outcomes, such as chronic homelessness, disability, and death by suicide. The early identification of prospective manic and depressive episodes, as well as early detection of declines in functioning, are important components of treating BD and alleviating the suffering of Veterans with BD. The goal of the proposed study is to develop and validate early identification predictive algorithms based on smartphone apps/mHealth measures that are passive, objective, and continuously updating in real-time without requiring patient insight or high effort. If the project is successful, it could provide tools that would enable clinicians to collaborate with Veterans with BD and more effectively time clinical outreach efforts to re-engage Veterans in treatment at the times of greatest need, and subsequently prevent functional impairment and loss of life by suicide.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Long-term sequelae of COVID-19 infection have a staggering burden on public health and the global economy, but investigators have little understanding of the determinants and mechanisms that underlie this phenomenon. We lack a clear understanding of the role of COVID-19 vaccination timing, or the role of immune biomarkers such as interleukin-6 (IL-6), in determining an individual’s risk of long-term consequences from COVID-19 infection. I will apply innovative Targeted Machine Learning and Causal Inference methods in order to identify an optimal COVID-19 vaccination schedule to minimize the long-term consequences of COVID-19 infection as well as identify mechanistic biomarkers that mediate the relationship between acute COVID-19 and Long COVID.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE To accurately detect preclinical Alzheimer's disease, it is essential to develop early indicators of cognitive decline that can be obtained in real-world settings, and across multiple timepoints. Traditional clinical assessments of older adults are burdensome and may fail to capture momentary shifts in everyday mood or cognition that could identify potential mechanisms associated with cognitive decline. The proposed approach, a naturalistic paradigm to detect cognitive decline, utilizes assessment of older adults in their daily life, enhances ecological validity, and allows for individualized monitoring of subtle changes in three ways: (1) through examination of cross-sectional and longitudinal relationships between cognitive performance, perceived stress, and psychiatric symptoms in an existing sample from the Indiana Alzheimer's Disease Research Center; (2) through natural language processing algorithms designed to detect and quantify risk factors for depression in midlife and older adults; and (3) through an ecological momentary assessment of the daily cognitive functioning, emotions, and stress in older adults, using validated mobile cognitive tasks.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Each year, an estimated 42 million Americans will receive prescription opioids after surgery, but few will dispose of their leftover opioids. Leftover opioids are often stored insecurely, misused, or shared putting patients, their families, and communities at risk of overdoses, dependence, addiction, and subsequent illicit drug use. This research will lead to an opioid disposal intervention that can be used by pharmacies and hospitals across the country to increase the safe disposal of prescription opioids.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Hypersensitivity to auditory stimuli is one of the hallmarks of Fragile X syndrome (FXS). Peripheral auditory neurons and their enveloping satellite glial cells in spiral ganglia form functional units that receive and transmit sound information, but whether functions of spiral ganglia neurons, satellite glial cells or other non-neuronal cells is disrupted and contribute to auditory hypersensitivity in FXS is not known. We propose to define the transcriptional and structural changes in spiral ganglia, and the defects in neuron excitability, with a potential to open new directions to ameliorate sensory deficits in FXS.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed work will develop a first-of-its-kind, transportable informatics tool, the Population Cancer Assessment and Surveillance Engine (Pop-CASE), that integrates patient-level cancer registry data for a population with granular community- and health system-level data in a standardized data model, while providing a user-friendly query tool to facilitate quick searching by researchers and community outreach professionals. PopCASE will provide a new tool for cancer control researchers, with place-contextualized cancer data at a fine geographic scale. It can also provide the Community Outreach and Engagement (COE) professionals and cancer center leaders working to curb cancer disparities at the local level with an unprecedentedly powerful catchment area data tool.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: Project Narrative This K24 proposal will support Dr. Jennifer Downs to train clinical investigators in the conduct of patient- oriented research focused on schistosomiasis and women's reproductive health in resource-limited settings in Tanzania and Lebanon, and to conduct a new study that investigates the effect of schistosome infections on HPV persistence in women in Tanzania. United States trainees will spend >50% of their time at international research sites in Tanzania or Lebanon, with onsite Weill Cornell faculty, long-standing international collaborators, and outstanding environments for research training. All of the projects focus on patient-oriented research on schistosomiasis and/or women's reproductive health and provide a broad experience for trainees in the conduct of mentored research in clinical epidemiology, translational research, and implementation science.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Despite existing guidelines, a large proportion of patients with colorectal neoplasia (i.e., polyps and colorectal cancer (CRC)) undergo surveillance (i.e., follow-up) colonoscopy either sooner than recommended (constituting overuse) or later than recommended/not at all (constituting underuse). Surveillance overuse leads to increased healthcare costs, wastes limited resources, and leads to delays in care for those who need colonoscopy more urgently. Underuse increases risk for future CRC. Colorectal neoplasia is categorized according to risk for future CRC. Data show overuse of surveillance for low-risk neoplasia surveillance, but underuse for high-risk neoplasia. This non-adherence to guideline-recommended intervals may be due to patient-, provider-, and/or system-level factors. The proposed research will measure and identify factors associated with surveillance non-adherence in order to develop and pilot test an intervention to optimize appropriate use of surveillance, improving colonoscopy resource use and access in the VHA.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE As we age, our tissues become less resilient towards damage or injury, which increases our risk for developing a disease. Factors, such as chronic stress, diet, and genetic predisposition can accelerate this process, thereby causing early disease onset, such as Early-Age Onset Colorectal Cancer (EAO CRC). In this project, we will test the idea that EAO CRC patients have intestinal cells with characteristics of old age and identify possible targets for treatment, with a focus on African-American patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Mortality is rising among Medicare beneficiaries with HF, and evidence suggests this may be partially due to gaps in health care access and affordability. This study aims to evaluate recent Medicare policy changes that could meaningfully address these gaps by: (1) comparing care quality and outcomes between HF patients enrolled in Medicare Advantage vs fee-for-service Medicare; (2) evaluating the impact of the Inflation Reduction Act (2022) on medication access and adherence for HF patients; and (3) using semi-structured interviews of patients and clinicians to identify ongoing and/or new barriers in HF care access, affordability, and medication adherence, as well as novel strategies to address them. This study could have significant public health implications as clinicians and policymakers seek innovative ways to improve outcomes among older patients with HF.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE CRISPR-Cas genome editing enzymes have the potential to treat infectious and pulmonary diseases in the lung but delivering them specifically to diseased cells is a challenge. This proposal will determine how lentivirus-like particles package and deliver Cas9 with its guide RNA to specific cell types and how this mechanism can be harnessed for genome editing of lung epithelia, a tissue implicated in many diseases. The development of a specific delivery method for CRISPR-Cas editing components in lung epithelial cells will be transformative for genetically treating lung diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: Narrative In the US, disparities in maternal and child health (MCH) across socioeconomic status, race/ethnicity, and geography are pervasive with little evidence of improvements despite significant investments. Addressing these disparities requires characterizing the structural drivers of MCH and their association to health to inform the design of multi-level, upstream interventions and policies. The goal of this project is to apply novel and rigorous data science and analytic tools to address significant gaps in our understanding of how structural drivers are geographically patterned and generate racial/ethnic MCH disparities from preconception to birth.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Pregnant women are exposed to an increasing number of environmental contaminants in their daily life, with potential harmful effects for the developing nervous system of the fetus. These exposures during early stages of fetal brain development can cause persistent changes and increase the risk on Alzheimer’s Disease and related dementia (ADRD) later in life. This project aims to provide training to independence via development of an in vitro placental-fetal brain model to investigate early-life exposures impact on later-life susceptibility to brain diseases including ADRD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Every breast cancer survivor is at lifetime risk of developing breast cancer-related lymphedema. The Nurses’ Health Study longitudinal database enables us to explore patterns of association between breast cancer diagnosis and lymphedema symptom development. These findings can inform clinical practice guidelines and health system policies and support local and national survivorship initiatives.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Racial/ethnic minority and uninsured populations experience persistent cervical cancer disparities due to under-screening. HPV self-sampling, a new screening option, could transform and increase access if implemented by federally qualified health centers (FQHCs) who serve these vulnerable populations. Our large pragmatic trial will test strategies for offering HPV kits during clinic encounters and by mail to speed implementation efforts in low resource healthcare settings.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Endocrine-disrupting chemicals have been identified as potential ovarian toxicants and linked to impaired fertility, which is a common issue experienced by ~15% of couples. The proposed research will advance systematic exposome approaches to investigate how complex exposures to thousands of chemicals impact ovarian health and female fertility. This research will also evaluate personal care product habits and their associated racial/ethnic disparities as potential sources to inform future exposure reduction interventions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative The U.S. recently celebrated a million cases of solid organ transplantation, and more than four hundred thousand people are living with a functioning allograft. Despite this life-saving operation, a lack of effective tolerogenic therapeutics is a critical barrier to long-term allograft survival. This project seeks to develop novel strategies to promote allograft tolerance via targeted activation of HLA-E-restricted regulatory CD8 T cells.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE American Indians are disproportionately affected by cardiometabolic diseases, and these disparities may be due, in part, to socioeconomic inequities that burden American Indian communities. An understanding of the biological mechanisms that may be involved in the socioeconomic determinants of cardiometabolic health will be instrumental to abrogating cardiometabolic disease disparities in American Indians; thus, this proposal will provide a comprehensive examination of feasible epigenetic mechanisms that may underlie the effects of socioeconomic adversity on cardiometabolic disease risk in American Indians. Findings from this study will improve our understanding into the importance that socioeconomic determinants have on cardiometabolic health in American Indians with relevance to other susceptible populations, and it will provide compelling evidence that will be instrumental towards developing preventative strategies and precision medicine approaches to addressing socioeconomic inequities and cardiometabolic disease disparities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Ground-level ozone is a major pollutant that increases the risk of morbidity in people with asthma. Our preliminary data demonstrate that ragweed pollen, one of the most common airborne allergens, retains changes from ozone exposure that result in increased pulmonary inflammation in vivo in a model of asthma. The goal of this project is to identify the chemical and structural changes in ragweed induced by ozone exposure and the immunologic mechanisms by which ozone exposed ragweed induces greater pulmonary inflammation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Pediatric pulmonary hypertension (PPH) is a progressive, incurable disease caused by abnormal smooth muscle growth and development of “neointimal lesions” that block blood flow through arteries and veins, with devastating outcomes when venous disease predominates. We have no treatments that target venous lesions because we know very little about what controls their growth and therefore, in these experiments we are 1) defining the transcriptional signature of vein neointima across the lifespan of a lesion to understand the mechanisms driving growth, 2) identifying molecules that control the growth of vein neointima cells, and 3) using new information about distinct smooth muscle cell subsets present during normal human lung development to understand how vascular disease develops in children with PPH, including the growth of vein neointima. We hope that a more complete understanding of the cells and signals driving venous neointimal formation and vascular remodeling in pediatric pulmonary hypertension will lead to a new generation of pediatric disease specific therapies that improve the lives of children with PH.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Respiratory viral infections in neonates and infants are associated with increased acute morbidity and an increased long-term risk of developing asthma. This proposal aims to understand the unique intrinsic and extrinsic mediators of the altered CD4+ T cell response following human metapneumovirus infection in neonatal mice. Further, this proposal will evaluate the long-term effects of neonatal human metapneumovirus infection on formation of tissue resident memory cells and the role of these cells in asthma pathogenesis.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Psychosocial health problems among U.S. adolescents are on the rise and have a disproportionate impact on immigrant youth. While research indicates that peer friendships are crucial for adolescent psychosocial health, the specific ways in which differences in friendship patterns and processes between immigrant and nonimmigrant youth contribute to health outcome disparities remain unclear. This proposed research aims to address this gap by using new friendship network data and employing social network analysis to examine the mechanisms within school and non-school friendships that may exacerbate psychosocial health problems among immigrant youth.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Our research project aims to improve the treatment of coronary artery calcification (CAC) by developing metasurface optical guidewires, which have the potential to revolutionize percutaneous coronary interventions (PCIs). Through precise control of laser dosimetry and the use of laser intravascular lithotripsy (L-IVL), these novel devices could significantly enhance the treatment of calcified stenotic arteries. Successful development and testing of novel metasuface optical guidewires will allow conducting PCI in highly stenotic and calcified arteries to provide therapy and increase vessel compliance.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Autism spectrum disorder (ASD) is a neurodevelopmental disorder that affects 1 in 36 children in the United States. Somatic variants, variants that arise after fertilization, have been implicated in ASD risk, but the types of variants that are enriched in ASD probands as well as the potential contribution of somatic variants in non- coding gene regulatory regions are largely unknown. This proposal will apply innovative approaches to test the hypothesis that somatic variants in both gene coding and gene regulatory regions contribute to ASD risk and can reveal new genes and mechanisms involved in ASD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Adolescents and young adults with sarcomas suffer a significant burden of morbidity and mortality with minimal improvements in outcomes in recent decades. The presence of metastatic disease remains the only strong prognostic factor, and biomarkers are needed to inform new approaches to testing risk-stratified therapy. In the proposed study, I will determine prognostic thresholds for ctDNA burden for fusion-positive and fusion negative sarcomas leveraging structural features seen across all sarcomas and then assess the impact of clinical ctDNA testing for post-treatment surveillance in Ewing sarcoma.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Alzheimer’s disease is a common aging disorder characterized by progressive loss of brain cells and decline in memory and thinking. Identifying the genetic factors that promote risk of Alzheimer’s disease and understanding how these genetic factors contribute to disease risk could lead to better tools for diagnosis, prognosis, and treatment. This study will understand how one form of gene mutation called short tandem repeats contributes to our risk of onset and rate of progression in Alzheimer’s disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This K23 project seeks to address the critical gap in the utilization of pain psychology among socioeconomically disadvantaged patients with chronic low back pain (cLBP), a prevalent health issue contributing to health disparities. The project proposes a three-pronged approach: first, to quantify the effect of socioeconomic status on pain psychology utilization; second, to identify barriers to and facilitators of pain psychology services, which will guide the creation of a tailored intervention, the Empowering Pain Psychology Access and Collaboration (EPPAC); and third, to pilot the EPPAC intervention, assessing its acceptability, feasibility, and preliminary efficacy compared to usual care. The successful execution of this project will generate data and expertise, contributing to the PI's long-term goal of promoting equitable and effective use of evidence-based treatments among marginalized pain populations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Maternal infection during pregnancy is a known risk factor for offspring neurodevelopmental disorders, including autism and schizophrenia. Here, we use a nonhuman primate model of maternal immune activation in pregnancy to study changes in offspring behavior and brain structure, as well as postmortem changes in cellular and molecular organization. The goal of this research is to identify pathways and critical periods for the development of targeted interventions and therapeutics to improve mental health outcomes for individuals at- risk for severe neurodevelopmental disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCIENCE CENTER
PHR: Prostate cancer, the fifth leading cause of cancer death in men globally, eventually fails standard of care entailing hormone therapy and chemotherapy for a large number of patients, which creates an urgency for new treatment plan(s) to delay or prevent the cancer from becoming terminal. We propose to investigate a new approach in which an inactive prodrug, to be synthesized by us, is activated specifically in tumor tissue, thus making it possible to deliver the prodrug at a very large dose to kill all cancer cells and prevent their ability to escape cell death by undergoing mutational changes under the pressure of therapy, while not causing unwanted side effects from indiscriminate toxicity in normal tissues. This study will be conducted in cultured prostate cancer cells and in prostate tumors that develop in mice from the injected cells, and a successful outcome of this preclinical project will lead to clinical trials on patients with advanced prostate cancer (and possibly other cancers) with a goal to test the activity of the novel prodrug, which we will synthesize, in the clinic.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS MED BR GALVESTON
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This research project aims to better understand how cognitive abilities, such as memory and problem-solving skills, change as people age in Mexico. The study will use information reported by close family members or caregivers about these cognitive abilities and compare it with clinical assessments. The goal is to improve how we measure and understand changes in cognitive function, which is crucial for planning healthcare services and dementia care.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Primary immune regulatory disorders (PIRD) are a rapidly expanding subset of inborn errors of immunity characterized by disorganized and aberrant immune responses, and often present with variable manifestations such as autoimmunity and infectious complications. This project will investigate the development of antigen- specific responses and cellular factors contributing to T cell dysregulation in STAT3 gain-of-function syndrome, a known monogenic PIRD. Results from these studies have the potential to uncover new biomarkers, targetable cellular pathways, and further insight into disease pathogenesis and human immunology.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Almost 100% of patients with septic shock—the most severe form of sepsis – have concurrent anemia; anemia in septic shock is often treated with blood transfusions when hemoglobin levels drop below 7.0 g/dL, but little is known about the effectiveness of this hemoglobin threshold-based blood transfusion strategy. The goals of this proposed research are to (1) examine practice pattern variation in threshold-based transfusion strategies in patients with septic shock across the United States, (2) identify patients with septic shock who are most, and least likely to benefit from threshold-based blood transfusion, and (3) pilot the implementation of an evidence- informed decision aid to improve and standardize transfusion practices during septic shock using a Learning Health Systems approach. Completion of this mentored career development proposal will be critical in informing septic shock clinical practice, guideline development, and future clinical trials and providing invaluable training in Learning Health System core competencies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Timely disposal of misfolded proteins is required to maintain a functional proteome and cellular health. Quality control pathways constantly monitor the proteome, promptly degrading proteins that do not fold properly or expose other degradation cues. The goal of this proposal is to elucidate how aberrant proteins are recognized in order to reveal universal mechanistic principles underlying quality control in different cellular organelles.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative The endoplasmic reticulum (ER) is a contiguous membrane-bound compartment, that extends to the periphery of neurons and forms contacts with other organelles to regulate organelle fission, calcium signaling and other important functions. Genes involved in maintenance of ER structure and ER contact sites are commonly found to be mutated in neurodegenerative disorders such as Hereditary Spastic Paraplegia. This proposal will investigate how ER structure and ER contact sites are regulated in neurons, and how mutations in genes linked to human disease lead to defects in ER interactions with other organelles.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Early child development interventions in low-resource global settings usually include a focus on responsive caregiving or early learning and nutrition, and most evaluate the effects on short-term outcomes in early childhood. The proposed work will fill current research gaps by identifying mechanisms through which early interventions impact health and development outcomes, assessing whether these effects persist into adolescence, and estimating the potential impact of multicomponent interventions that target multiple prevalent risk factors in early life simultaneously. This work will contribute to the optimal design of interventions to improve health and development through childhood and adolescence in low-resource global settings.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Among the more than five million people who suffer a moderate or severe traumatic brain injury each year, it is not currently possible to predict who will recover and who will remain functionally dependent on caregivers. Though advanced imaging now enables precise in vivo localization of brain injuries, it is not known whether dependency results from disruption of specific neural structures or networks. Dr. Snider’s proposal combines retrospective big data analysis with prospective independent validation to identify the neuroanatomical location of brain injuries that produce dependency, an approach with outstanding potential to improve prognostic accuracy and inform the design of targeted therapeutics.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Proper development of the left and right sides of our bodies is critical for the correct positioning of our organs. Perturbations in this process result in heterotaxy, which is typically associated with congenital heart malformations and high lethality in the first year of life. This study investigates the evolutionary and developmental mechanisms that establish left-right asymmetry, using veiled chameleons as a research organism, and has the potential to discover novel and conserved processes, and advance the diagnostic outcomes for heterotaxy and congenital heart disease patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Clinical evidence suggests that the cerebellum plays key roles in cognitive and social behaviors, but a circuit- level understanding of how it performs non-motor computations is lacking. The proposed research will apply sophisticated neural recording and control techniques to determine how cerebellar Purkinje neurons contribute to reward learning. This research program will define non-motor computations in the cerebellum, a critical prerequisite to isolating cerebellar disruptions that underlie cognitive impairments in neurological disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: Project Narrative Preterm birth is a major risk for neonatal mortality and long-term child health problems, including motor and mental developmental delays and chronic illness. Knowledge of the stressful contexts in which Black women live and the biolocal pathways through which stress affects preterm birth, will increase our understanding of why some women have poor pregnancy outcomes. These findings will generate new perspectives for future research, inform new lines of inquiry regarding the pathways will contribute to the development of culturally appropriate interventions to reduce racial disparities in preterm birth and ultimately improve birth outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  This proposal aims to tailor design one high-precision optogenetic probing system, based on monolithic integration of close-packed dual-color LEDs and MEA, to dissect inter-region communication within regionalized organoid disease models. Specifically, we will investigate if our probes with scalable pixel counts/pitches could advance organoid disease modeling via tissue-level optogenetic electrophysiology. If successful, our technology will enable high-precision bi-directional optogenetic control of inter-region circuits and electrophysiology across multiple regions and depths of the organoids, which cannot be achieved by existing RNA sequencing, 3D organoid electro-physiology, or cell imaging methods.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative In this proposal, we explore the hypothesis that inhibition of the mammalian Target of Rapamycin (mTOR) promotes a shift in nutrient metabolism away from the utilization of carbohydrates and toward the burning of fats in mitochondrial disorders caused by dysfunction of Complex I of the Electron Transport Chain. We hypothesize that this shift, mediated by two proteins called Sirt3 and C/EBP-β, suppresses symptoms of disease and improves survival. This project will determine the role of nutrient metabolism in the onset and treatment of neurological mitochondrial disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: Project Narrative Understanding the functional and structural roles of microbial communities at the single-cell level is critical for unraveling the interrelationships between members of a microbial community and with host tissue. This project aims to establish a single-cell functional paradigm by measuring microbial adhesion forces within microbial community. Through an innovative combination of expansion microscopy and multiplex PNA FISH imaging, we will explore the functional aspects of microbial communities beyond their spatial arrangement, and globally analyze microbial interactions at the micron level.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Project Narrative Pharmacogenomics has the potential to improve medication safety in the treatment of chronic pain—which impacts an estimated 1 in 5 adults; however, testing is rarely ordered. Pain physicians are an understudied group of expert stakeholders. By examining their knowledge, views, and practices with pharmacogenomics, this study will improve our understanding of a) the barriers and facilitators to testing and b) clinical and ethical considerations to guide the use of pharmacogenomics in chronic pain care.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Alzheimer’s disease is a complex neurodegenerative disorder with overwhelming personal, societal, and economic burdens for which there is currently no means of prevention or disease-modifying treatments. In this proposal, I will use multi-omic analyses in observational and interventional studies of human and mouse models of AD to systematically characterize molecular pathways associated with Alzheimer’s genetic risk and resilience. Completing this proposal can identify causal genetic variants of Alzheimer’s disease that have not been previously resolved using traditional genetic approaches and prioritize genes and pathways for drug development.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS MED BR GALVESTON
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Latinas suffer more perioperative complications that their non-Hispanic peers when undergoing urogynecologic surgery, in part, because of lower surgical preparedness. Prior studies to increase surgical preparedness have been conducted mostly on White women, excluded non-English speakers, and not cost-effective nor practical. The proposed research will use human centered design and dissemination and implementation methods to center stakeholder input to develop a usable and sustainable intervention that considers the cultural and societal needs of Latina patients and their clinical environments, an approach not used thus far in the development and testing of other surgical preparedness interventions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The level of mutations in the mitochondrial genome (mtDNA) increases with human tissue aging, offering a potential metric of aging and a novel target for intervention; however, the scope and functional consequences of these mutations remains unclear due to technical barriers. I will utilize a novel long-read sequencing method I developed and published to discover the tissue specific scope of age-associated mtDNA mutations, along with an induced pluripotent stem cell-based system I am developing, to directly test the relationship between age-induced mtDNA mutations and progenitor cell dysfunction. This work will provide an extraordinary, mentored career development experience and invaluable foundational knowledge for future work to understand the consequences of mtDNA changes in aging and to test data-driven interventions that mitigate these changes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cancer is the second leading mortality in the world, while many different treatments exist including revolutionary immunotherapies, adverse events are frequent and response rates are limited. Basic, translational, and clinical studies defined a key role for the gut microbiota in affecting tumor progression and immunotherapy efficacy, but the underlying mechanism remains at early stage of investigation. The focus of this proposal is to delineate two novel pathways by which microbiota interacts with mammalian hosts to impact tumor growth, progression, or immunotherapy response, thus provoking novel opportunities for intervention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Children with Attention Deficit Hyperactivity Disorder (ADHD) are at substantially increased risk for long- term difficulties into adulthood, including academic underachievement, substance abuse, and criminal behavior. In an effort to improve these outcomes, we propose a Repetitive Transcranial Magnetic Stimulation (rTMS)-based intervention to stimulate brain circuits important in response inhibition and study target engagement in neurophysiologic and behavioral outcomes. Project success will provide rationale for designing a multi-center sham-controlled clinical trial to test clinical ADHD outcome in response to rTMS treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Sepsis is a complex clinical infectious disease that represents one of the leading causes of death across the world. Decades of research have failed to produce new clinically efficacious treatments, mandating the development of novel strategies to prevent and treat infection. The design of such strategies necessitates that we obtain a clear understanding of the mechanisms by which diverse human pathogens injure the endothelium causing lethal disease, which forms the focus of this proposal.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: NARRATIVE The research in this proposal aims to uncover the mechanisms underlying heterogeneity in complex diseases through the identification of: (i) the context (tissues, cell types, gene networks) in which causal genes operate, and (ii) shared and distinct genetic risk profiles among patients. This knowledge will be integrated with additional clinical data in statistical and machine learning models to stratify patients into more homogeneous disease subtypes, contributing to the development of new precision medicine strategies. The study will be initially applied to schizophrenia, inflammatory bowel disease, and coronary artery disease, acting as a guide in the psychiatric, cardiometabolic, and immunological fields.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Narrative Regeneration of bone injuries that will not heal on their own remains a significant clinical challenge, as this affects many veterans and soldiers in US Military and there are few viable treatment options. We propose to engineer scaffold-free cell condensation-based vascularized bone tissue using direct assembly of high-density stem cell- laden core-shell microgel and individual cell-only bioinks via new in situ bioprinting technology with precise spatiotemporally controlled delivery of tissue-specific growth factors. This platform strategy to create geometrically complex functional vascularized bone tissue by means of multi-tissue type cellular condensations may represent a powerful clinical therapeutic advance to treat patients suffering from craniofacial bone tissue damage or loss and improve their lives.

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: Project Narrative This project, titled “Supporting Patients Recovering from COVID” (SPaRC), will build upon the existing multidisciplinary Johns Hopkins Post-Acute COVID-19 Team (JH PACT) out-patient program to expand essential clinical services for, and facilitate patient-centered, equitable care delivery to, people living with long COVID, especially those from under-served communities. SPaRC will build a coalition to strengthen collaboration with, and support for, primary care providers. The SPaRC program will be evaluated using a mixed methods approach, and iteratively refined, within a learning health system, and in collaboration with the SPaRC Stakeholder Advisory Council and the AHRQ Learning Community, to advance Long COVID care.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Supporting Patients Recovering from COVID-19 (SPaRC)

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: NARRATIVE – OVERALL The Mayo Clinic Alzheimer's Disease Research Center (ADRC) will pursue the theme of Multiple Etiology Dementias. The ADRC will intensely focus its efforts on the recruitment on African American/Black, Hispanic/Latino, and rural dwelling communities, and will assess for all ADRC participants' structural and social determinants of health to evaluate the impact of multiple pathologies. Mayo ADRC will share its data, images, and biological specimens widely with the ADRC community and other investigators.

PHR: NARRATIVE We propose that degradation of the extracellular matrix protein Fibronectin-EDA (FN-EDA) could be a novel strategy to mitigate the severity of pulmonary fibrosis. I will identify mechanisms of FN-EDA degradation and test the repurposed drug Lonafarnib for its effects on FN-EDA degradation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  The response rates of NSCLC patients to immunotherapy remain low despite significant advances in the development of immune checkpoint inhibitors (ICIs). Our proposed research addresses the premise that the MUC1-C oncoprotein suppresses immune surveillance, promotes resistance to ICIs and is a novel target for the development of antibody-drug conjugates in advancing the immunotherapy of NSCLCs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: NARRATIVE  The neurobiological basis for the co-morbidity between repeat mild traumatic brain injury (rmTBI), intermittent alcohol exposure (IAE) during adolescence, and dementia remains unclear. This proposal will utilize animal models of rm TBI and IAE during adolescence to examine the role of blood-brain barrier (BBB) disruption and how that may drive the development of dementia-associated proteinopathies in adulthood. The results of this work may provide a new therapeutic treatment to treat humans following TBI.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Sickle cell disease (SCD) affects millions of individuals worldwide and is associated with significant morbidity, mortality, and health care burden. This study investigates the use of a plant-based omega-3-fatty acid (Flaxseed) baked or added to foods to improve inflammation driven pain outcomes in SCD. Flaxseed is an inexpensive, widely available food that has the potential to improve outcomes in SCD and other disease states that are inflammation driven.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Up to one-third of young infants aged ≤90 days old who present to the emergency department (ED) with viral bronchiolitis have potentially avoidable hospitalizations, contributing to preventable exposure to hospital- acquired infections, undue caregiver distress, and high healthcare costs. An accurate clinical prediction model is needed to identify young infants at low risk of developing respiratory progression who can be safely discharged to home. Using clinical history and physical examination factors, identification of the etiologic viruses, and physiologic time series data measured from bedside monitors, the proposed study will create new prediction models to guide clinical decisions and improve clinical outcomes for young infants with bronchiolitis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: STATE UNIVERSITY OF NEW YORK AT BUFFALO
PHR: Human enzymes that are needed to metabolize drugs resemble the structure of the Mycobacterial enzyme (CYP121) that is a current drug target against tuberculosis. Therefore, conventional drug design targeting CYP121 carries a significant risk of unintended inhibition of human drug metabolizing enzymes. The proposed study seeks to take advantage of a unique arrangement of this bacterial enzyme that is necessary for its function and would allow for the development of specific drugs that minimize the risk of drug-related toxicities for patients being treated for this disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Mechanistic target of rapamycin (mTOR) is a highly conserved signaling network upregulated in a number of proliferative lung diseases including pulmonary arterial hypertension (PAH) and lymphangioleiomyomatosis (LAM). This proposal uses three transgenic mouse lines and primary PAH and LAM lung tissues to investigate the role of mTOR hyperactivation on pulmonary vascular remodeling and pulmonary hypertension. The results from this work will help define the role of aberrant mTOR signaling on cellular crosstalk and identify mechanisms of vascular remodeling that can be harnessed to provide potential new therapeutic targets.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Many family caregivers to people with dementia have persistent musculoskeletal pain, which exacerbates their emotional and psychological stress and makes care tasks more difficult to perform. This study aims to adapt an existing evidence-based pain management intervention, Problem Adaptation Therapy for Pain (PATH-Pain), for use by dementia family caregivers who have co-existing persistent pain and high negative emotions. The adapted intervention will be the first evidence-based pain management program customized for dementia family caregivers and will offer a sustainable and scalable approach to person-centered pain management for the growing number of dementia family caregivers who are managing their own physical and mental health comorbidities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
ORG_NAME: PENNSYLVANIA STATE UNIV HERSHEY MED CTR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Rigorous research is needed to identify mechanisms contributing to sexual minority health disparities, particularly from an intersectionality perspective. The intersectionality of geographic location and sexual orientation can profoundly impact prevalence of suicidal thoughts and behaviors, as rural sexual minorities experience disproportionate burden of suicidal thoughts and behaviors, often reside in high-stigma environments, and have limited access to healthcare resources. This project uses an innovative mixed methods approach to clarify acute and dynamic mechanisms underlying suicidal thoughts and behavior disparities among rural sexual minority adults and will inform therapeutic targets for suicide prevention in this uniquely high-risk population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
ORG_NAME: STATE UNIVERSITY OF NEW YORK AT BUFFALO
PHR: Project Narrative There are significant racial disparities in breastfeeding rates, particularly for non-Hispanic black (NHB) women, who are already disproportionally impacted by adverse health outcomes. The proposed research aims to understand the decision-making process, individual level determinants, and environmental barriers to breastfeeding among NHB women. Findings will inform the systematic and community-engaged design of a tailored breastfeeding peer counselor program to improve breastfeeding outcomes (e.g., initiation, duration, intensity, breastfeeding goals) among NHB women.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: VIRGINIA POLYTECHNIC INST AND ST UNIV
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Therapy resistance remains a major problem in effectively treating melanoma despite recent advances in developing chemical inhibitors specifically targeting the most common mutation BRAFV600E in melanoma. This resistance at least in part results from the counteraction of oncogenic phosphatidylinositol 3-kinase catalytic subunit PI3Kβ, a kinase that is highly homologous to, yet functionally divergent from, the other three catalytic subunits PI3Kα/PI3Kδ/PI3Kγ. Based on our recent findings that a nine-residue motif which is found in PI3Kβ, but not in PI3Kα/PI3Kδ/PI3Kγ, we will in this application explore how Selectide-9 comprising this nine-residue motif and a cell- penetrating peptide selectively inactivates PI3Kβ and if Selectide-9 can overcome therapy resistance in melanoma.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Preterm infants with intraventricular hemorrhage are at high risk of developing childhood epilepsy and may provide important insights into epilepsy risk stratification if studied early. This study will capture high-density EEG data from preterm infants with intraventricular hemorrhage during a critical period before epilepsy develops to compare to both early epilepsy and developmental outcomes. The goal of this study is to identify predictive biomarkers directly translatable to future clinical screening and interventions which prevent epilepsy in preterm infants and others at risk.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative Studies focusing on regeneration within the nervous system hold great potential for the development of therapeutic approaches that aim to generate cures for central nervous system injury and degeneration. In this project, I aim to establish the emerging model Danionella cerebrum – one of the world's smallest vertebrates and a member of a clade of vertebrates (teleost fish) that can regenerate after brain injury – as a novel vertebrate model system for nervous system function, and regeneration research. Combining single-cell RNA sequencing, cell-type-specific ablations, and live calcium imaging will allow study of regeneration in the central and peripheral nervous system, and reveal principles concerning the functional and structural basis of regeneration in specific neural circuits.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The overdose crisis is a pressing issue, and there is a need to implement evidence-based interventions for opioid use disorder (OUD) in Federally Qualified Health Centers (FQHCs). To address this need, I propose developing, adapting, and testing the ReTAIN program intervention package to implement measurement- based OUD care using patient-reported outcome measures (PROMs) to monitor treatment progress and improve patient retention in FQHCs. As part of a mentored research training program, this award will enable me to gain expertise in implementation science and become a leading independent researcher with dual expertise in implementation science and addiction medicine. My goal is to bridge the evidence-to-practice gap by studying optimal approaches for integrating evidence-based addiction medicine interventions in FQHCs and other primary care settings.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Peripheral blood eosinophil count, a good molecular biomarker in asthma, has been inconsistent in chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), a leading cause of morbidity and mortality in the United States, leading to mixed results for targeted therapies. Since COPD is a heterogenous and complex disease, it is necessary to investigate the relationship of eosinophils with activated platelets, which perpetuate inflammation and regulate immune cell function. Understanding the complex interplay of platelet-eosinophil conjugates with COPD clinical outcomes and of platelet activation with eosinophil activity furthers the knowledge of inflammatory and immune mechanisms in COPD and provides a foundation for future clinical trials investigating precision therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Episodic memory is central to the human sense of self and wellbeing, and its disruption in Alzheimer’s disease or other forms of dementia profoundly reduces quality of life. This work contributes to an understanding of the fundamental mechanisms, shared across vertebrate species, by which the hippocampus supports episodic memory function. Results will have broad scientific relevance for the development of future technology to improve memory function in health, and alleviate functional declines with age and disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The increasing salinity of groundwater is a key emerging global environmental health risk factor for hundreds of millions of adults, including in the United States. With climate change increasing these risks, there is a vital need to understand the consequences of differential levels of drinking water salinity on risk of dehydration, water insecurity, kidney damage, and hypertension—all significant public health concerns, particularly in hot environments. The findings from the proposed study will inform policy recommendations about maximum salinity levels for health and interventions to prevent exposure to drinking water salinity and its related public health consequences.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: Project Narrative Pathological social aggressive behavior affects 45% of individuals with Alzheimer’s disease, and is associated with poorer quality of life, enhanced burden on caregivers, and poorer outcomes overall. The pathophysiological basis of these symptoms is unknown. By systematically mapping the ability of oxytocin-sensitive neuromodulatory circuits connecting the hippocampus to the lateral septum to control social aggressive behavior and the impact of AD-related pathology on this circuit, we explore the possibility that these devastating neuropsychiatric symptoms can be treated early in disease progression.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Nonsense Mediated mRNA Decay (NMD) degrades both aberrant transcripts and “normal” transcripts with other specific features, impacting around 10% of the transcriptome. This project will investigate the biological roles and molecular functions of UPF3, a disease-linked core NMD factor, in both human cells and zebrafish development. Taken together, this study will help us understand how UPF3-activated NMD and transcriptional regulation is modulated, and elucidate connections between mRNA decay and transcriptional regulation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Alzheimer's disease (AD) is a neurodegenerative disease characterized by a failure in synapses and consequently the progressive deterioration of cognitive functions. The amyloid β peptide (Aβ) and APOE genotype are critical initiators that trigger the progression of Alzheimer’s Disease (AD) I propose an optical imaging approach to investigate the loss of synaptic function associated with Aβ and APOE genotype contribute to the physiological consequences of aging and AD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Trigeminal Neuralgia (TN) is a debilitating orofacial condition associated with severe pain, and undertreatment can lead to a decline in quality of life for older adults. The study aims to investigate the optimal pharmacological treatment approaches for TN among aging Americans by documenting patient-reported experiences of diagnosis and treatment, developing a validated algorithm to identify incident TN cases in Medicare data, and investigating the risk of injurious falls caused by different treatment options using advanced causal inference methods and machine learning techniques. This research is critical for improving clinical outcomes and quality of life for older adults living with TN, while also contributing to the development of precision pain care and comparative effectiveness research in this population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVES: This research introduces a unique multi-trait model that leverages extensive electronic health records to bolster disease prediction and mapping. Addressing the constraints of current genomic studies enhances personalized medicine through optimized treatment strategies and deeper insights into the genetic relationships among complex human diseases. Furthermore, it promotes health improvement and disease prevention, reinforced by rigorous model validation using extensive data sets and expert analyses.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Damage to the spiral ganglion nerve leads to permanent deafness, and a cochlear implant is the most effective treatment for severe-profound deafness. However, cochlear implants are ineffective with neuronal degeneration, and regenerative medicine, such as direct neuronal reprogramming to replenish the damaged spiral ganglion neurons, holds enormous potential to cure deafness and improve cochlear implant outcomes. This grant explores approaches to advance cellular reprogramming of cochlear glial cells into induced spiral ganglion neurons using a new mouse model with selective ablation of spiral ganglion neurons, optimizing gene delivery into cochlear glial cells, and enhancing reprogramming efficiency by combining micro RNAs with neuronal transcription factors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Community-based interventions to interrupt mycobacterium tuberculosis (Mtb) transmission are needed to reduce the considerable global burden of TB, but evidence on how to spatially target these interventions for increased feasibility and efficiency is lacking. I propose to add to the evidence base by (1) developing a tool to estimate the subnational burden of TB by integrating programmatic, mobility, and survey data from Uganda; (2) characterizing transmission within and across distinct but linked communities using genomic data from 3 studies in Uganda and South Africa; and (3) projecting the impact and cost-effectiveness of TB prevention and case finding interventions by fitting a mathematical model of Mtb transmission to data from a large study in South Africa. Combined with a strong mentorship team and institutional support, this award will position me as a leading independent researcher who combines diverse sources of both traditional and emerging epidemiological data with infectious disease modeling tools to answer tough epidemiological questions and inform smarter policy responses.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Experiences in childhood and adolescence (e.g., differential exposure to childhood adversity) contribute to racial inequity in risk for Alzheimer’s Disease and Alzheimer’s Disease Related Dementias (AD/ADRD). Population distributions of these early life experiences, however, are themselves shaped by upstream, structural factors that remain underexplored in the AD/ADRD literature. The proposed research will be the first to examine the implications of federal, state, and local governmental spending priorities – as structurally intervenable exposures that condition early life environments – on overall risk for, and racial inequities in, midlife cognition and later life dementia, providing important information to support government officials in prioritizing investments that facilitate and sustain lifecourse health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Ovarian health and cardiovascular health are intimately connected; however, previous research has not adequately addressed how environmental contaminants that target both the ovary and the heart can intensify a toxicant’s adverse effects by disrupting the reciprocal interactions that occur between organ systems. This proposal will identify the molecular mediators underlying cardiovascular and ovarian toxicity following exposure to the environmental contaminant 2,3,7,8-tetrachlorodibenzo-p-dioxin. Together, these studies will contribute to our understanding of environmentally induced cardiac injury and help identify environmental sources of human infertility.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Endocrine-disrupting chemicals (EDCs) such as phthalates are both obesogenic and neurotoxic, but studies have been conducted separately. No study has linked phthalates' obesogenic effects with their neurobehavioral toxicity in an integrated causal pathway – yet overeating is a behavior associated with poor inhibitory control and high reward processing. The proposed research will investigate the complex relationships among a mixture of phthalate biomarkers, childhood inhibitory control, and reward processing with obesity growth trajectories between 6–17 years to determine if they form a causal pathway to obesity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Use of veno-arterial extracorporeal membrane oxygenation (VA-ECMO) in acute myocardial infarction (AMI) is increasing exponentially yet mortality in this condition remains high. This work will define fundamental ventricular and vascular physiology in VA-ECMO and test novel approaches to mitigate increases in afterload and ventricular injury imparted by VA-ECMO. These results will provide urgently needed mechanistic insight into current and future management strategies to improve outcomes in patients with AMI associated cardiogenic shock.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The majority (>90%) of the human genome consists of non-coding regions that do not directly yield proteins but are transcribed into RNA. Long non-coding RNAs (lncRNAs) represent a large class of these molecules (>170,000) that can have crucial regulatory functions in a variety of biological processes, yet the vast majority of lncRNAs remain completely uncharacterized. This proposal seeks to develop and apply photocatalytic proximity labeling technology and CRISPR-based phenotypic profiling to better understand the mechanisms of lncRNAs, in turn answering fundamental questions surrounding these transcripts in normal and disease biology and es- tablishing novel modalities in precision medicine.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: NARRATIVE Even in the absence of active inflammation, persistent symptoms are common in Crohn's disease (CD), result in worsened quality of life, increase risk for future opioid use, and are among the top drivers of healthcare expenditures in CD. Despite these significant challenges, evidence-based therapies do not exist due to lack of mechanistic understanding of this condition. The overall goals of this project are to identify how sulfur producing microbes may influence the host and whether diet may be a safe and effective treatment for improving persistent symptoms in CD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Babies who are born extremely premature commonly have low blood platelet counts and a high risk of bleeding, usually in the brain or lungs. For this reason, they commonly receive platelet transfusions to decrease the risk of bleeding, although a recent randomized trial suggested that premature babies who received less platelet transfusions had less bleeding and mortality than those transfused with a higher threshold. This has generated uncertainty among clinicians regarding the optimal platelet transfusion thresholds for extremely preterm infants, and this trial is specifically designed to address this uncertainty by evaluating if lower thresholds for platelet transfusions will lead to improved survival without bleeding among extremely preterm infants born at 23 to 26 weeks gestational age.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE People with chronic kidney disease (CKD) in rural areas have challenging experiences, and we need more research and work to improve their care. Many people with CKD need help to ask their doctors, nurses and other clinicians all of their questions about their disease, and treatment and share what matters most to them. In this research project, we will work with people with CKD (stages 4-5) in rural areas, along with their family, friends and clinicians, to customize, use and test a tool called an “agenda-setting intervention” to help them ask their clinicians important questions during their clinic visits.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: Lung cancer screening (LCS) can reduce lung cancer-related mortality by 20%, but only 5-10% of eligible individuals have received an initial LCS, with Black and Hispanic individuals less likely to be screened. The goal of this study is to partner with community stakeholders to jointly develop and pilot test a multi-component community health worker intervention targeting key barriers to improve LCS and tobacco treatment utilization. The proposed activities will lay the groundwork for a subsequent R01 grant, conducting a fully powered randomized clinical trial to establish CHWs as an evidence-based practice that will facilitate access to screening and reduce lung cancer mortality both overall and among underserved populations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Lewy body disorders, a subset of Alzheimer’s disease and related disorders (ADRDs), are progressive, incurable, and the 14th leading cause of death in the United States. Because most persons with Lewy body ADRDs are hospitalized in their last 6 months of life with high rates of intensive, inappropriate care, hospital- based interventions are needed to improve end-of-life care quality for this growing population. The goal of this project is to improve prognostication and end-of-life care quality measurement in Lewy body ADRDs, which will be used to inform future interventions that promote improved care quality, more thoughtful resource allocation, and reduced Medicare spending at end-of-life.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Post-hospital discharge mortality rates among young children aged <5 years in sub-Saharan Africa are as high as 3-18%, far outpacing the 0.1% rate we recently described in US children. Despite this immense disparity, there are currently no externally validated or implemented risk assessment tools to identify young children at risk for post-hospital discharge mortality in sub-Saharan Africa. The proposed research will assess the discriminatory ability of machine learning risk assessment tools for post-hospital discharge mortality, includes the first external validation study of risk assessment tools for post-hospital discharge mortality among young children in sub-Saharan Africa, and will elucidate the role of a novel biomarker of endothelial dysfunction to predict post-hospital discharge mortality among young children.
