IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Peanut allergy affects one in fifty US children, and rates have increased disproportionately in Black and Asian populations. Timely peanut introduction in infants at high risk of peanut allergy involves a series of interdependent steps, from initial screening to peanut introduction, during a critical and short window of opportunity, with barriers along the way. We will explore determinants of timely assessment of peanut allergy and peanut introduction and identify associated barriers and facilitators to inform development and testing of a novel intervention involving virtual medical care to safely facilitate peanut introduction.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Humans with severe or profound hearing loss can regain the ability to hear and understand speech through the use of an auditory neuroprosthesis, a cochlear implant. Attaining adequate speech perception with a cochlear implant, however, does not happen instantaneously and understanding the precise sequences and mechanisms by which the brain, its circuits, and its neurons facilitate this vital adaptation remains incomplete. Here, we focus on cochlear implant use to expand our knowledge on fundamental mechanisms of neuroplasticity, and findings from our proposed research have potential far-reaching impact for cochlear implant users and developing general strategies for neurorehabilitation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Rewarding experiences must be remembered clearly to guide healthy learning, but this memory process can be disrupted in disorders such as dementia and drug addiction. To address our limited understanding of how the brain amplifies the events surrounding reward in memory, this research will leverage large-scale recording technologies to uncover the neural dynamics involved in forming spatial reward memories in two key brain regions, the hippocampus and entorhinal cortex. By investigating what aspects of the rewarding experience are stored and how they are stored, this work will enhance our knowledge of normal memory function and provide insight into neural processes that could deteriorate in mental disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  The goal of this proposal is to reveal how broadly expressed gene-regulating proteins control distinct gene expression programs to shape different blood cell fate decisions by focusing on Runx proteins’ activities in early T cell development and megakaryocyte development. I aim to address my hypotheses that relationship with 3D chromatin structure and the availability of physically interacting co-factors instruct context-specific functions of Runx proteins. In addition, this proposal will test whether the principles underlying dynamic Runx activities apply to other multilineage-expressed regulators’ functions and show how these gene-regulating proteins provide precisely needed regulatory inputs to normal blood cell production but can cause hematologic pathologies when dysregulated.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Access to health information exchange (HIE) is critical to ensuring that emergency care is maximally responsive to the unique needs of older adults with Alzheimer’s disease and related dementias (ADRD); however, prior research suggests that significant racial inequities in HIE may exist, exacerbating existing racial disparities in the care of older adults. The proposed study will 1) characterize racial inequities in emergency care quality, HIE connectivity, and HIE use, and 2) quantify the impact of HIE on ED care quality for adults with ADRD. This research is directly responsive to the National Institute on Aging’s 2020-2025 research goals to facilitate smoother care transitions for older adults, improve the interaction of older adults with the healthcare system, and understand and address drivers of health inequities and disparities related to aging and diseases such as ADRD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cognitive training is a promising intervention for slowing/preventing AD/ADRD in at-risk individuals, including those with MCI, but evidence for robust transfer to untrained domains is mixed, and there is a poor understanding of mechanisms that lead to transfer. Mismatch between cognitive resources and task demands is thought to lead to transfer by increasing the efficiency with which existing resources can be applied to untrained tasks, but there have been few attempts to measure mismatch states that lead to transfer. This proposal aims to develop a conceptual and operational framework for quantifying biopsychological mismatch, measured using experience sampling and ECG measures within and across cognitive training sessions in MCI, with the goal of understanding and improving transfer effects using future personalized, scalable cognitive training programs that can reach those most in need for intervention in MCI.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Sleep disturbances are one of the primary risk factors and pathogenic drivers of Alzheimer's disease and age- related dementias (ADRDs). The goal of this proposal is to use a small molecule identified by a chemical library screen to understand the mechanisms of age-associated sleep disruption as a driver of ADRDs and to exploit them as therapeutic drug targets. This research will establish a critical framework for pre-clinical drug discovery for ADRDs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Higher social capital (resources rooted in social networks) is positively associated with cervical cancer screening among Latinas, but how this association operates by nativity status and how clinic-based social capital interventions can be implemented in safety-net settings to address cervical cancer disparities among this population has not been explored. This project aims to assess the relationship between social capital and health care delays, to inform the design and development of a clinic-based social capital intervention to increase cervical cancer screening and reduce delays in follow-up among Latina patients.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE (RELEVANCE TO VETERANS) VA surgeons perform more than 4000 major lower limb amputations annually. These Veterans are among the 623,000 Americans who live with a major lower limb amputation, the majority of whom were of diabetic or dysvascular etiology (4 out of 5) and the remainder mostly due to trauma. Another several thousand, also of traumatic etiology, stem from the U.S. involvement in enduring military conflicts overseas. These Veterans have all experienced a profound change in their lives. They walk slower and fall more often. Many incur injuries to their residual limb. Few find wearing a prosthesis comfortable. Why? Because the current state-of-the-art prosthetic restoration is no peer of the natural limb. My clinically relevant research aims to improve their mobility, reduce their risk of injury, and enhance their comfort by using innovative approaches to marry new technology with artisanal practice.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: The primary cilium is a tiny, extracellular-facing organelle, with a distinct composition from that of the rest of the cell or plasma membrane, that coordinates diverse extracellular signals (i.e odorants, metabolites, light, neuropeptides, hormones) and converts them into coordinated cellular responses. Though primary cilia have been implicated in a number of pathologies including ciliopathies, diabetes, neural disorders, disrupted immunity, and cancer, the mechanisms by which cilia are built and process signals remain poorly understood. The goal of this proposal is to explore the role of the ciliary traffic protein TULP3 in coordinating both making a cilium and maintaining receptors inside the cilium and how understanding these functions applies in the biological context of immunity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE A growing body of research demonstrates that physical activity may improve behavioral, cognitive, and emotional functioning among individuals with neurodevelopmental disorders. However, it is not known if exercise can improve outcome among individuals exposed to prenatal alcohol, a serious and global public health problem. The present proposal uses both clinical and basic science to understand the relationship between physical activity, neurocognition and mental health and will investigate whether physical activity can improve cognitive and emotional functioning following prenatal alcohol exposure.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: In a national survey of Iraq and Afghanistan combat Veterans receiving VA medical care, anger difficulties were the most commonly reported reintegration concern, particularly among Veterans with PTSD. Problematic anger is associated with numerous negative psychosocial outcomes for Veterans, including discord in family relationships, aggression, road rage, unemployment, and suicide risk. Anger also interferes with progress in PTSD treatment, further highlighting the need for improving anger treatments for Veterans with PTSD. Despite many Veterans reporting a desire for anger management treatments, current available treatments are limited by low rates of engagement and high rates of dropout. An efficacious mobile intervention for anger may help to overcome some of the barriers that have kept Veterans from engaging in, or benefitting from, anger management therapy services and improve functional outcomes and community reintegration for these Veterans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Depression is a prevalent global health issue, and our understanding of its links to neuroinflammation opens new avenues for prevention and treatment. This research aims to use the cytomegalovirus (CMV) as a model to understand how neuroinflammation, which the virus can trigger, might lead to depression by disrupting key brain circuitry. Using cutting-edge genetic and neuroimaging methods, this research seeks to identify individuals at heightened risk, understand the underlying neurobiological mechanisms, and thus lay the foundation for an independent career in population immunopsychiatry focused on the neuroviral etiology of depression across the lifespan.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Bacterial vaginosis is the most common gynecological disease in women of reproductive age and causes pregnancy complications including infection of the amniotic sac and preterm birth. Research on the most common bacterial species associated with bacterial vaginosis, Gardnerella spp., has been hampered due to the inability to make genetic mutations in these bacteria. We have discovered a way to make genetic mutations in Gardnerella spp., and the proposed studies would capitalize on this discovery by developing tools for making gene deletions, insertions, and single base changes as well as making gene constructs for studying gene expression and protein production and localization.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The current project is designed to study radiation-induced coronary heart disease (RICHD), a major concern in cancer survivors receiving radiation therapy. With miniaturized human vessel tissues and novel mouse models, I will map how radiation exposure dysregulates the vascular health over time and correlate molecular changes to specific mutations in TP53 gene. The ultimate goal is to provide insights for the stratification of cancer patients based on their genetic risk for RICHD to improve patient outcomes post-radiation therapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In patients with acute kidney injury (AKI), proteinuria testing within 3 months of hospital discharge is a powerful but underutilized method to identify those at risk for subsequent renal function loss, morbidity, and mortality. We will study provider and patient facilitators and barriers to follow up proteinuria testing and evaluate the relationship between provider or patient AKI awareness with follow up proteinuria testing (Aims 1 and 2). We will also conduct a pilot trial to evaluate the feasibility and acceptability of an intervention to manage proteinuria after AKI hospital discharge (Aim 3).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Nigeria faces the highest global burden of maternal mortality, predominantly driven by hypertensive disorders of pregnancy (HDP) that also pose long-term cardiovascular risks. Leveraging our successful feasibility study on implementation of a postpartum BP monitoring program, we developed the HDP Implementation Bundle and plan to conduct a type 1 hybrid stepped wedge cluster randomized trial to evaluate its preliminary effectiveness in improving postpartum BP and its implementation using the RE-AIM framework. The candidate will gain expertise in dissemination and implementation science complementing her background in cardio- obstetrics and health policy to facilitate her growth as an independent physician-scientist with expertise in global cardio-obstetrics.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Anxiety and depression symptoms occur at high rates in Veteran populations and can significantly impact function, compromising the ability to work and to successfully form and maintain valued relationships. Several other symptoms commonly occur with anxiety and depression, including poor sleep quality and chronic pain. Since all these symptoms frequently occur together, they may have a common underlying biological basis. A single medication that could effectively treat all these symptoms would be ideal. Converging data suggest that pregnenolone is a promising pharmacological agent for treating multiple psychiatric symptoms and functional impairment. We thus propose to conduct a clinical trial of pregnenolone in Veterans with anxiety and depression symptoms. Pregnenolone has minimal side effects, and our prior research demonstrates that pregnenolone is well-tolerated by Veterans. Treatment with pregnenolone could thus be an efficacious new therapeutic for Veterans experiencing depression, anxiety, poor sleep quality and chronic pain conditions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Patients with acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) who are obese have a much higher risk of relapse than those who are not obese. We found that fat tissue induces expression of a protein called RANKL in ALL cells, which might contribute to this poorer outcome. In the present study, we are investigating how this occurs as well as strategies to intervene.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Despite national quality measures and care guidelines, cirrhosis care remains suboptimal and highly variable, leading to poor outcomes. Clinical decision support systems represent an attractive strategy to improve care due to low implementation costs, but these systems remain largely untested in cirrhosis care. This proposal will close this evidence gap by conducting a pragmatic randomized controlled trial of a cirrhosis-specific clinical decision support system, named “CirrhosisRx,” evaluating its implementation outcomes, and identifying factors for successful multicenter dissemination.

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: NARRATIVE The central goal of this proposal is to improve capacity, access, and equity for underserved, vulnerable, and minority populations being served by the UCSF long COVID OPTIMAL clinic program. Using an implementation science approach and leveraging the existing OPTIMAL Long COVID care model and established relationships with community and research we propose to: 1) Scale up Long COVID care in the San Francisco Bay Area to increase access for underserved, vulnerable, and minority populations; 2) Enhance Long COVID care coordination and communication across clinical, research, and community settings; 3) Identify key barriers and facilitators to implementation success and sustainability of the expanded and enhanced Long COVID care model.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Broadening the scale and impact of a comprehensive Long COVID clinic to serve diverse patient groups with multidisciplinary care and research access

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed work aims to determine the relationship of neighborhood-level SDH, prematurity, and long-term health outcomes among Black children, to identify family-prioritized SDH and preferred approaches to interventions, and to determine the feasibility and acceptability of a novel SDH intervention among Black families with preterm infants. It is relevant to public health in that findings will inform a future intervention specifically designed to address SDH to improve the long-term health of Black children born preterm, a NIMHD priority population. Developing effective interventions to address SDH that influence immediate and long-term child health and development is crucial to realizing the NIMHD mission to reduce and ultimately lead to the elimination of health disparities.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Since 2000, at least 250,000 U.S. Service members have experienced a blast-related mild traumatic brain injury. A retrospective analysis of over 100,000 post-9/11 Veterans shows that blast injury more than doubles the risk of a diagnosed auditory problem. Many blast-exposed Veterans experience “functional hearing difficulties” (FHDs): problems in challenging listening environments despite clinically normal hearing as measured by the pure-tone audiogram. VA audiologists have begun using low-gain hearing aids to treat FHDs, but there are no concrete guidelines for this application given standard procedures rely on the pure-tone audiogram. This study proposes a data-driven approach called speech-based audiometry (SBA), which optimizes hearing aid gains from a patient’s responses to speech stimuli in aided conditions. A first study will quantify the behavioral and neurophysiological benefits of low-gain hearing aids programmed conventionally or with SBA among Veterans with FHDs. A second study will explore applications of SBA in current hearing aid users with different loss profiles.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: Project Narrative Black individuals experience two-to-four times higher rates of end-stage kidney disease that their White counterparts. Structural racism, racialized and discriminatory policies and practices promoted through major social systems such as housing and health care, may act as an additional third hit exacerbating the risk of poor kidney health outcomes, above and beyond its impact on co-morbid conditions. This proposal will engage a stakeholder board to help characterize and measure the effects of structural racism on people with APOL1 risks and develop a patient-centered intervention to mitigate the effects of structural racism on adverse kidney health outcomes.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative Vaginal childbirth is a leading risk factor for morbid conditions that affect a quarter of U.S. women, referred to collectively as pelvic floor disorders. Vaginal birth injury to the pelvic floor muscles is the posited link between vaginal delivery and pelvic floor disorders, thus, this proposal will determine how pregnancy-induced remodeling prepares these skeletal muscles for the mechanically demanding task of vaginal childbirth. Multiscale computational and experimental methods will elucidate the hormonal and mechanical drivers of pelvic floor muscle alterations in pregnacy that impact whole muscle active and passive mechanical function.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Significant disparities in cardiovascular diseases persist among racial and ethnic minorities. There is an urgent need for effective and sustainable interventions to improve the cardiovascular health of diverse communities. The objectives of this K24 grant are to allocate protected time for Dr. Elva Arredondo to conduct cardiovascular health equity research and expedite the implementation of evidence based programs in real-world settings, including communities. Additionally, the K24 aims to provide training and mentorship to trainees seeking to conduct community-engaged implementation research to reduce cardiovascular health disparities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Coronary heart disease remains the number one killer in the United States and other developed countries. There is a great need to understand the mechanisms leading to coronary heart disease, particularly in response to environmental risk factors. This study will exploit our recent findings from an NHLBI K08-funded study to understand the role of maladaptive protein aggregation in the vascular wall and coronary heart disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Retaining a vital biomedical research workforce is critical for facilitating the scientific advancements necessary to improve human health. The Training to Enhance Researcher Resilience and Adaptability (TERRA) project will benefit public health through integrating emerging well-being scholarship with educational practices for enhanced self-efficacy, providing novel, freely available training resources to better support biomedical researcher well-being, adaptability, and resilience. By addressing well-being gaps in the current biomedical research environment, TERRA will provide new tools for retaining this critically-important workforce.

PHR: Approximately 1 in every 70 people are transfused each year. This project attempts to understand how transfusion recipients respond to donor blood to help guide the development of ways to prevent this problem.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Accurate, timely surveillance approaches are needed in the U.S. to understand the incidence and prevalence of diabetes among young adults that can distinguish by type, and generate estimates by race/ethnicity, age group, sex and geographic regions. Continuous monitoring of the young adult population will identify disproportionately impacted subpopulations and aide in the development of primary, secondary and tertiary diabetes prevention and management strategies.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: DP20-001 Surveillance of Diabetes in Young Adults between 18-45 Years of Age (DiCAYA) - Component B

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE FOR OCCUPATIONAL SAFETY AND HEALTH
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: Project Narrative There is a high prevalence of post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD) and chronic lower respiratory symptoms among community members affected by the September 11, 2001 terrorist attack on the World Trade Center (WTC) towers (“Survivors”). Despite widely reported cognitive impairments among WTC Responders, there is a lack of information about cognitive status among WTC Survivors and there is a lack of knowledge about the association between WTC exposures, chronic PTSD, severe lung disorders, cognitive status, and cognitive decline over time. To improve diagnosis and treatment and to identify the biological underpinning of the health disorders, in this project we propose to investigate the biological mechanisms linking WTC exposures, comorbid PTSD and severe lung disorders, with cognitive function or decline by assessing the effect of inflammation and neurodegeneration biomarkers in blood as mediators of WTC exposures and risk of cognitive abnormality and as possible modifiable targets for interventions.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Cognitive decline among WTC survivors with chronic mental and physical disorders

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE FOR OCCUPATIONAL SAFETY AND HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Characterizing the totality of WTC exposure—both psychological and chemical—has been challenging, particularly among pregnant women and children, which has limited our ability to identify WTC-related health effects. New advances in high resolution gas chromatography can characterize WTC-related exposure and biological response to exposure in ways that were previously impossible. This study uses novel metabolomic and exposomic methods to characterize WTC exposure and the effects of WTC exposure among those who were exposed in utero or as children, two sensitive windows of development.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Exposomic Approach to Identifying WTC Exposures and Effects in Survivor Youth.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: JAMES J PETERS VA  MEDICAL CENTER
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: Cannabis consumption for recreational and medicinal purposes has increased worldwide over the last decade. Emerging evidence suggests that the kidney expresses cannabinoid receptors and produces endogenous cannabinoids. Activation of these receptors acutely increases urine output with variable effects on sodium and potassium excretion in mice, rats, and rabbits. A body of very few studies in humans suggest that cannabinoids can act as diuretics to promote sodium bicarbonate excretion. Given the emerging evidence suggesting that cannabinoids regulate urine output and ion transport in the kidney, and rapidly increasing widespread usage of cannabis, the proposed investigation promises to elucidate the functional role of cannabinoids in the kidney epithelial cells that regulate total body electrolyte, acid/base and fluid homeostasis, and will allow us to identify new therapeutic agents for the treatment of disorders common among people living with kidney disease such as hypertension, volume overload, metabolic acidosis, and hyponatremia.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cervical cancer is a life-threatening pathology highly associated with human papilloma virus (HPV) infection that disproportionally affects low- and middle- income countries. A major barrier in implementing and sustaining screening programs for cervical cancer in low-resource countries is the lack of an affordable and effective screening test that can provide HPV results at the point-of-care. This proposal will develop and evaluate a novel DNA-based approach that combines isothermal recombinase polymerase amplification with fluorescent quantification in an accurate and low-cost test, which could improve access to cervical cancer screening and significantly decrease mortality due to the disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: NARRATIVE While transcatheter heart valve interventions (THVIs) offer a less invasive option to treat clinically significant heart valve disease in older adults, over one-half of patients are dead, have poor quality of life, and/or are hospitalized 1 year after a THVI. While cardiac rehabilitation is effective at mitigating these poor outcomes, only 25% of patients participate in center-based cardiac rehabilitation in the year after their THVI and numerous barriers to participation exist. We propose a multicenter randomized controlled trial enrolling patients undergoing a THVI to test whether and how a home-based cardiac rehabilitation intervention that addresses key target health behaviors, leverages mobile health technology (e.g. Apple Watch to encourage physical activity and deliver reminders on healthy living), prescribes exercises to build strength and balance, and incorporates habit formation strategies to promote sustained behavior change will improve physical activity, functional capacity, and quality of life and decrease clinical events.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Several studies have explored the possibility to clear tau pathology in animal models of Alzheimer’s disease (AD) using immunotherapy. Unfortunately, the therapeutic potential of antibodies to treat neurodegenerative diseases is limited due to the difficulty of crossing the blood-brain barrier (BBB) and reaching target molecules in the brain. The objective of this study is to investigate the effectiveness of engineered tau antibodies as treatment for tau pathology in transgenic animal models of AD, defining the mechanism of action of immunotherapy, and exploring a cost-effective therapeutic to translate into humans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Project Narrative Inducing selective cell death in tumors lies at the core of ongoing research in pancreatic cancer. This proposal seeks to trigger pancreatic cancer cells for ferroptosis, a form of cell death independent from apoptosis and in culture, pancreatic cancer cells exhibit a native sensitivity to ferroptosis, while they exhibit mechanisms of intrinsic and adaptive resistance in vivo. This proposal will identify the factors that permit potent ferroptotic cell death in vitro, so as to deploy these in pancreatic tumors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: The encoding of auditory and vestibular information begins in the hair cell, a specialized mechanosensitive cell that converts sound pressure waves and head orientation or movement into the release of the neurotransmitter glutamate. This grant aims to understand at a molecular level how hair cells control and regulate the release of neurotransmitter. In particular, this grant application aims at a better understanding of the role of Otoferlin, for which mutations lead to DFNB9 non-syndromic hereditary deafness.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Autophagy deregulation has been implicated in excessive inflammation and tumor cell proliferation. However, the molecular mechanisms underlying these changes have yet to be well-identified. By using a unique mouse model with inducible expression of a cancer-derived autophagy inhibitor, this application aims to elucidate the mechanisms by which intervention with autophagy suppressor exacerbates tumor-promoting inflammatory response and promotes age-related spontaneous cancers, thereby providing the molecular basis for the development of novel therapeutics for autophagy-related pathologies and diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This proposal describes a new PhD training program, Genetic Approaches to Development and Disease (GADD) at Columbia University Irving Medical Center (CUIMC). The underlying philosophy of this program is that genetic approaches, including forward and reverse genetics as well as genomics and epigenomics, represent effective strategies for dissecting the molecular mechanisms underlying development and disease in vivo. GADD students receive advanced training in genetic analyses using model organisms, current genetic and genomic techniques, biostatistics, history of genetics, and the ethics of modern genetics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative: In this proposal, I describe the successful invention of a novel positive-selection screening platform for degraders of transcription factors (TFs). I use it to identify Spautin-1 as a degrader of IKZF1 and propose experiments to (i) elucidate its mechanism of action and (ii) identify derivatives for Spautin-1 with increased potency against IKZF1. These studies will help develop a novel class of therapies against refractory myeloma.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative: Public Health Relevance Statement Diabetes and diabetic nephropathy (DN) are major causes of morbidity in the general population. There is an urgent medical need for identification of novel targets in the development of strategies for rational treatment of DN. Our objective is to characterize the role of Duox2 in DN and identify it as a convenient target for therapeutic intervention as identifying specific sources of oxidants will allow targeted therapy to prevent DN and could translate to treating patients with specific antioxidant therapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: The burden of cervical cancer and Kaposi’s sarcoma in sub-Saharan Africa is daunting; both cancers are common with poor survival because the region lacks effective prevention, early detection and treatment. Efforts to improve this are hindered by a shortage of qualified researchers and efficient research networks. We will create a multi-country collaboration amongst scientists in the U.S. and East Africa to conduct relevant research on prevention and early detection of these cancers while also training both East African and U.S. junior scientists.

PHR: NARRATIVE Tumors help ensure their resistance to immune recognition by limiting dendritic cell and T cell function. This proposal will investigate a new mechanism harnessed by dendritic cells to enhance T cell responses, tumor rejection, and response to immunotherapy. The studies outlined in this proposal may lead to improved strategies to prevent and treat cancer.

PHR: Project Narrative The primary goals of this K12 Mentored Clinical Scientist Development Award Application are to support intensive research mentorship, advanced training, and career development of diverse and talented, doctoral-level, clinically trained individuals committed to a career in patient- oriented addiction research. IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: In East Africa, as is the case in most of sub-Saharan Africa, junior scientists need substantial support following graduate training in order to become productive and independent scientists. In this project, we will create an academic environment for our emerging East African and U.S. junior scientists studying HIV- associated cancers that will help them improve their scientific productivity, scientific leadership, and administrative skills. We will also administer small research grants to identify the next group of junior scientists interested in studying HIV-related cancers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Small cell lung cancer (SCLC) is a recalcitrant subtype of lung cancer for which there are limited treatment options. This study will employ novel mouse and patient-derived models of the disease as well as state-of-the- art technologies to determine the mechanisms by which arginine deprivation impacts the MYC-driven subtype of SCLC. This work is relevant to public health and the NIH mission because it will increase our understanding of the unique metabolic and therapeutic vulnerabilities in SCLC subtypes and ultimately improve the quality of life and survival of lung cancer patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Tumor-associated blood vessels sustain the growth and promote the spread of cancer cells via diverse mechanisms. In this proposal, we have uncovered a new role for DNA methyltransferase 1 (DNMT1), the major enzyme responsible for re-establishing patterns of methylation during cell division, for the survival, specification, and immunosuppressive features of tumor-associated endothelial cells. We aim to explore the role of vascular DNMT1 in sprouting neovessels that sustain cancer cell growth, how DNMT1 is regulated by growth factors in the tumor endothelium, and how DNMT shapes immune/vascular micro environments in metastasis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Despite the availability of effective prevention methods, Sub-Saharan Africa still accounts for nearly 90% of the global cervical cancer burden. This research will evaluate a new integrated community-based prevention and early detection program for cervical cancer implemented by the Ministries of Health in Kenya and Uganda. The findings will provide a new paradigm in cervical cancer prevention in Africa – a public health approach to reach the greatest number of girls and women at the lowest cost.

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The ability to treat disease and injury of the brain depends upon developing a fundamental understanding of the complex neural circuits that comprise the central nervous system. The use of neurotrophic viruses as transneuronal tracers provides a unique and powerful tool that reveals the functional organization of these complex circuits. The CNNV is a national resource that provides training in the use of this approach and distributes reagents to a world-wide cadre of investigators.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The Cancer Epigenetics Training Program at Van Andel Research Institute (VARI) will prepare postdoctoral fellows to become independent research leaders in the field of cancer epigenetics. The program will accomplish this by offering cutting-edge, interdisciplinary research training in structural and functional aspects of epigenetics, complemented by state-of-the-art institutional resources, unique professional development activities, and integration with established translational research programs and partnerships led by VARI investigators. Trainees will emerge from the program with comprehensive training in cancer epigenetics and a professional foundation from which to launch their independent research careers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Although the disparity of lung cancer survival in low-income people is well documented, the determinants of lung cancer care in this vulnerable population remain undetermined. In the population-based cohorts of lung cancer patients insured with Medicaid, we will assess the impacts of neighborhood contexts, Medicaid policies, and hospitals on cancer-directed treatment, tobacco cessation treatment, and cancer outcomes, as well as their contributions to racial disparities in lung cancer treatment and survival. The results will enhance our understanding of the mechanisms for socioeconomic and racial disparities in lung cancer care and survival, and will also help identify modifiable targets for future multilevel lung cancer disparity interventions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: In sub-Saharan Africa, the cancer known as Kaposi’s sarcoma (KS) remains a significant problem among HIV-infected patients. Diagnosis often does not occur until patients develop advanced disease and survival is poor. We will apply a technique known as Rapid Case Ascertainment (RCA) to inform efforts aimed at controlling KS; improve our understanding of why KS still occurs despite antiretroviral therapy; and evaluate novel strategies for KS diagnosis and linkage of patients newly diagnosed with KS to cancer care.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Sepsis is a common syndrome of dysregulated immune responses to infection that occurs in all ages and populations. Without a clear understanding of the complex biology that causes these responses we cannot provide effect treatments to minimize the risk of death or long-term complications. This proposal has the potential to uncover biology to lead to therapeutic improvements for the treatment of sepsis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Acute kidney injury (AKI) afflicts 1.2 million hospitalized patients annually in the US, and 20-50% of survivors of AKI progress to chronic kidney disease (CKD) as a result of failed renal repair. There are no available therapies to enhance renal repair/regeneration, underscoring an immense unmet clinical need. In this application, we seek to determine molecular mechanisms that underlie how oxidative stress impedes renal repair/regeneration and establish a proof of principle that activating anti-oxidative stress pathways can enhance renal repair and prevent the AKI-to-CKD transition.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research aims to uncover information that is essential to develop a new schistosomiasis control strategy. The work also aims to determine which molecules are fundamentally required for the evolution of animal cellular adhesion and chemotaxis—important phenotypes for a range of diseases from immune disorders to cancer metastasis. Because this project is uniquely applicable both to a neglected tropical disease and to some of the most common diseases in the U.S., it is relevant to human health and the NIH’s mission to reduce illness.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Here we investigate a blood test to identify stroke patients who are eligible for tPA therapy. We use whole blood whole transcriptomic to analyze blood RNA patterns to identify signatures of stroke, and then test the impact of sex and race on this test accuracy. Finally we investigate a novel rapid sequencing approach which has the potential to enable timely point of care transcriptome analysis for stroke diagnosis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Innate threat behavior offers a new avenue for the study of trauma-related psychiatric disorders, and involves locus coeruleus norepinephrine neurons. The goal of this project is to identify threat computations specific to norepinephrine cell-types across molecular, cellular, and circuit scales using newly developed norepinephrine biosensors, head-mounted microendoscope calcium imaging, and transcriptomics. This work will demonstrate the relationship between norepinephrine cell-types and network activity in defensive behaviors, thus laying a foundation for future studies to improve threat-related symptoms in psychiatric disorders.

PHR: Our studies focus on UCHL5, a deubiquitinase enzyme and a member of Ino80 chromatin remodeling complex. We propose to study in depth mechanism of role of UCHL5 and subsequent epigenomic reprogramming in promoting melanoma metastasis as well as test the effect of its inhibitor on growth of metastatic melanoma. Our work is expected to provide critical biological insights into the role of epigenome in metastasis that could have broad implications for melanoma and other malignancies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative: Alzheimer’s disease—an incredibly debilitating dementia currently affecting more than 6 million people in the United States—is associated with changes in the gut microbiome that may contribute to disease progression by shaping neuroinflammatory responses to pathology. While microbiome-disease associations are described, the contribution of specific Alzheimer’s disease-linked bacteria is unknown. The present study aims to pinpoint the specific effects of individual Alzheimer’s disease-associated microbes on neuroimmune and disease outcomes and evaluate the cellular pathways and bacterial molecules involved in transmitting these signals from gut-to- brain, thus allowing for the identification of novel treatment targets.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: The goal of this study is to design and develop a fully characterized novel tissue engineered disease model of aged tissue environment integrated with a mouse model as a system to study the role of aging in disease initiation and progression. With a fully integrative approach implementing human tissue analysis, state-of-art tissue engineering approaches and by incorporating the engineered tissues in a hybrid mouse model for physiological relevance, we propose a highly interdisciplinary project to reconstruct and validate aged human tissue at the molecular, cellular and physiological levels. The tissue engineered 3D models as well as the hybrid mouse models developed here will be of great importance in isolating the effects of aged human (i) ECM, (ii) stromal cells, and (iii) disease cells on disease progression.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Familial partial lipodystrophy 2 (FPLD2) is a rare disease that causes adipose tissue loss, dysfunction, and redistribution; FPLD2 is caused by mutations in LMNA, which encodes proteins important for nuclear function and gene expression. Mechanistic studies are required to understand how and why loss of LMNA function leads to FPLD2, and to reveal therapeutic targets for lipodystrophy patients. This project uses inducible adipocyte-specific Lmna knockout and other mouse models to identify mechanisms of adipocyte loss, which I hypothesize occurs because reduced lipogenic gene expression leads to an inability of adipocytes to maintain their lipid stores.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative: We propose a new study to determine the role of cyclohexanone, an organic solvent contaminant of medical plastics, in mediating adverse cardiovascular outcomes in neonatal cardiac surgery. We will determine cyclohexanone and its breakdown products effect on test MP and validation U Michigan and CATCH studies morbidity, mortality, and neurodevelopmental outcomes, determine mechanism of toxicity by examining in vitro neural cell and brain slice culture, effects on the blood brain barrier and in vivo on learning and memory and whether exposure can be reduced by CPB circuit manipulation. Reduction of organic solvent exposure from medical plastics offers an opportunity for an immediate and actionable means to improve neonatal cardiac surgical outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: Project Narrative - Overall The Myeloproliferative Neoplasm Research Consortium (MPN-RC) is an inter-active group of laboratory and clinical scientists from 13 institutions who work in a coordinated fashion to develop and evaluate therapeutic strategies that will improve the survival of patients with myelofibrosis (MF). We hypothesize that combinations of drugs which act by directly targeting malignant hematopoietic stem cells and/or by correcting their tumor promoting micro-environments can be used to deplete the numbers of cancer stem cells. The overall goal of the MPN-RC is to employ the complementary skills and efforts of its scientifically diverse membership to generate the scientific foundation for novel therapeutic strategies which will be evaluated in rigorous, well- constructed independent investigator-initiated clinical trials to prolong the survival of MF patients.

PHR: NARRATIVE There is a need for new treatments for myelofibrosis (MF) patients based on laboratory insight into disease pathogenesis. We will use studies of preclinical models of MF and primary patient samples to understand how different mutations and biological pathways contribute to MF development and to test novel treatment approaches. Most importantly, the studies in this project are aimed to validate novel therapies that can then be rapidly tested in clinical trials in this research consortium.

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Zebrafish models are invaluable tools to our understanding of human health and disease and have taught us much of what we know about biology. Immense efforts have gone into the generation of transgenic, reporter, and mutant lines; however, maintaining live fish indefinitely has become a huge cost burden that also puts animals at risk. This project aims to develop a flexible zebrafish cryopreservation protocol that is compatible with multiple developmental stages, including embryos and larvae, and to train external labs with an easy to implement protocol through extensive dissemination efforts.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: RELEVANCE: The change in stroke occurrence and recurrence over time is the ultimate test of how well science has translated new discoveries into benefits for the population. Our study has examined racial disparities in stroke over the last 25 years, showing that blacks have higher risk for stroke than whites. In our population, the occurrence of stroke is decreasing in whites but NOT African-Amerians, and we will continue to describe trends in stroke occurrence, recurrence, cause, treatment, and outcome in a biracial metropolitan population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Myelofibrosis (MF) is a disease characterized by the accumulation of abnormal megakaryocytes that contribute to progressive bone marrow fibrosis and impaired hematopoiesis. The goal of this project is to understand the events that contribute to disease progression by focusing on megakaryocytes and the factors that they secrete and respond to, such as TGF- and IL-13. We aim to deliver novel therapies that target abnormal megakaryocytes to patients through this consortium.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Adoptive T cell therapy to treat human malignancies has been revolutionized by the use of chimeric antigen receptor (CAR) T cells in the past decade. However, the clinical success of this approach has been difficult to replicate for diseases other than acute lymphoblastic leukemia. We have pioneered the use of CD30.CAR-Ts to treat patients with relapsed/refractory Hodgkin Lymphoma demonstrating their antitumor effects. However, barriers still need to be overcome to further increase the response rate and long-term durability of complete responses of thse patients. Our proposal exploits major synergies between adoptive transfer of effector T cells, redirected and competitive T cell trafficking, and immune responses. If successful, our approach would alter the clinical practice of CAR-T cell based immunotherapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: This interdisciplinary program will train a diverse group of exceptional graduate students to become future leaders in 21st Century genetics research. Students will receive rigorous predoctoral research training from world-leading scientists in quantitative, computational, and experimental approaches to answer fundamental questions in molecular, statistical, and evolutionary genetics. The program will train 90 new Ph.D. scientists in 5 years to make major breakthroughs in understanding how genetic information affects biological systems in health and disease – essential knowledge to better diagnose, prevent, and treat a wide range of genetically-encoded conditions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Physical frailty is common in adults with heart failure and increases the risk for poor health outcomes. Clinicians need tools to identify adults with physical frailty as part of routine care to support early intervention to treat frailty and reduce this risk. This application seeks to develop a novel measure of physical frailty using data collected as part of routine clinical care and recorded in the electronic health record.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH NARRATIVE The burden of cardiovascular disease is the highest in minority and socioeconomically disadvantaged communities. Lifestyle and behavioral interventions that have demonstrated effectiveness in improving blood pressure and medication adherence may not be available and accessible to individuals living in socioeconomically disadvantaged communities. Storytelling, peer health coaching, and web-based interventions are promising evidence-based approaches for promoting behavioral change. Combining these approaches may enhance the efficacy of an intervention and may offer a sustainable approach for promoting lifestyle change.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Social anxiety is a common and chronic problem but, for unknown reasons, many patients do not respond to existing treatments. Despite advances in neuroscience and computational psychiatry, there remains no reliable predictor of treatment response that can be used to select an optimal treatment for a given patient. The goals of the proposed research are to examine whether neuroimaging can offer an evidence-based precision or personalized medicine approach to predict treatment in patients with social anxiety, and to apply advanced computational and multimodal imaging approaches to improve our understanding of the neurobiology of social anxiety disorder, and brain changes (plasticity) associated with treatment response.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: Project Narrative Myelofibrosis (MF) is a chronic myeloproliferative neoplasm (MNP), which is primarily the consequence of intrinsic abnormalities occurring within hematopoietic stem and progenitor cells (HSPCs) associated with at least five events: 1) acquisition of MPN driver mutations leading to increased JAK/STAT signaling; 2) increased activation of NF-κB; 3) progressive downregulation of the tumor suppressor p53; 4) upregulation of components of the anti-apoptotic pathways and 5) upregulation of HIF1. These intrinsic MF HSPC abnormalities also lead to additional extrinsic events resulting in a chronic pro-inflammatory state and a dysregulated hematopoietic tumor microenvironment which favors the predominance of malignant HSPCs with increasing burdens of mutational and cytogenetic events. To test this hypothesis, combinations of drugs that upregulate p53 will be evaluated for their potential to disrupt the p53/NF-κB/HIF1 axis, deplete myelofibrosis HSPCs as well as disarm their supportive TME prior to their subsequent evaluation in clinical trials.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Mitochondrial dysfunction and cellular energy deficits have emerged as hallmarks of aging-associated disorders. In this project, we aim to measure the effect of nicotinamide riboside (NR) on brain energy metabolism in patients with mild cognitive impairment and Alzheimer’s disease. Specifically, we will use novel MR spectroscopy techniques to investigate and validate NR target engagement in vivo in the brain, as well as explore the cognitive and functional effects of NR supplementation in this patient population.

PHR: Project Narrative Research training in hearing and balance requires a wide range of experimental and theoretical knowledge. This training program brings together experts from molecular genetics to population health to produce the next generation of scientists addressing these all-important senses. The gradual decrement of hearing and balance in our increasingly aged population makes this effort especially meaningful.

IC_NAME: FOOD AND DRUG ADMINISTRATION
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project will contribute to public health through developing recommendations for prioritized alternatives to antibiotics to manage diseases in major livestock species in order to reduce the use of antibiotics in food- producing animals. Bacteria that are resistant to antibiotics are a growing threat to public health and to food security and safety. Reducing antibiotic use in food-producing animals decreases the selection pressure for the emergence and spread of antimicrobial resistant bacteria in the environment and in areas where humans and animals interact, and supports antibiotic efficacy being preserved into the future.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Integration of a multi-pronged standardized methodology to identify key diseases and prioritized antimicrobial alternatives in production animals

ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Narrative – Overall MNORC Obesity is a critical health problem that contributes to a wide range of health problems and healthcare costs. Obesity has also defied easy treatment. The Michigan Nutrition Obesity Research Center will provide researchers the opportunity to utilize advanced technologies and computational tools to understand how causes of obesity vary among individuals and across the population. Through these efforts, health professionals will be able to translate these lessons to the design and implementation of novel dietary, exercise and medication interventions to control obesity and obesity- related diseases in both adults and children.

PHR: NARRATIVE – PROJECT 4 The overall goal of this project is to directly translate therapies originating from therapeutic targets identified from scientific Projects 1-3 into novel treatment strategies targeting the myeloproliferative neoplasm (MPN) hematopoietic stem cell (HSC) and the supportive microenvironmental abnormalities in patients with myelofibrosis (MF). Such therapies will be evaluated in investigator-initiated, early developmental phase, clinical trials with agents derived from the scientific Projects (1-3) and designed to deplete the MPN HSC through direct anti- clonal activity and modification of the impaired microenvironment, thereby favorably altering the natural history of disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative  Coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) has infected millions, impacted billions of lives, and precipitated socioeconomic destabilization. There is a pressing need to understand SARS-CoV-2 replicates in the host gastrointestinal tract, interacts with the mucosal immune system, and drives diarrheal disease. We expect our results to drive innovative therapeutics to treat COVID-19 related enteric diseases with or without inflammatory bowel diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF CONNECTICUT SCH OF MED/DNT
PHR: Project Narrative Ovarian cancer causes more deaths than any other gynecologic cancer, largely due to late stage at diagnosis and frequent treatment failures. In this proposal we expand on our initial findings that ovarian cancers are sensitive to ferroptosis, a novel iron-dependent form of cell death, by examining new enzymes and pathways that modify ferroptosis, finding where in the cell iron triggers the ferroptotic death signal, and examining how certain cells that surround the ovarian cancer affect the extent to which ovarian cancer can be killed by drugs that induce ferroptosis. These experiments may ultimately pave the way for more effective use of ferroptosis- inducing drugs in ovarian cancer therapy.

PHR: CORE A Narrative Core Lead: Ronald Hoffman, MD The Administrative Core of this Program Project is designed to provide scientific leadership, effective communication and an administrative support structure, and to ensure the collaborative translational research network that supports and synergizes the laboratory and clinical studies led by MPN-RC investigators is maintained. The essential services provided by the Core include, but are not limited to: administrative support for all of the investigators in each project and core; fiscal management and oversight for all components of the Program Project; and organization and communication of all Program Project meetings and activities. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Alzheimer’s disease is one of the major health and economic challenges of our time. There is an urgent need to understand the structurally polymorphic nature of amyloids with different structures accumulating in different neurodegenerative diseases and their subtypes. We have assembled a world class team of pathologists, biochemists, biophysicists and structural biologists to purify, structurally characterize and replicate homogeneous samples of the polymorphic brain amyloids and distribute them to researchers along with reagents and protocols to identify, quantify and authenticate them in vitro and in vivo.

PHR: Core B Project Narrative The Core B Tissue Bank is an essential resource of the Myeloproliferative Neoplasms-Research Consortium (MPN-RC) which receives, processes and stores tissues collected from MPN patients consented under IRB approved Protocol 106 (Project 4), as well as patients on Project 4 clinical trials. Core B provides a central repository for these tissues that are associated with clinical and mutational annotation (Core C), which enables appropriate selection of specimens for each project. Specimens are distributed to MPN-RC investigators and the larger scientific community for translational research and clinical trial specimens are utilized for biomarker and pharmacodynamic analysis of novel therapies (Core D).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Efforts to promote recovery of function after human spinal cord injury (SCI) will likely require interventions targeting the corticospinal motor system, the most important pathway for voluntary motor control in humans. This work will expand our knowledge of the primate transcriptional state after SCI, identify potentially optimal time points for therapeutic intervention, and allow enrichment of neural stem cell grafts with cell types that constitute the best means of forming new functional relays across sites of severe SCI.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Mutation is the driver of evolution, the root of heritable diseases, and the initiator of tumors. Despite its direct relevance to human health and evolution, we understand little about why mutation does not happen at the same rate at all sites across the genome. We will apply novel computational methods to genomic and epigenomic data from various sources to investigate the molecular mechanisms behind mutation rate variation across the genome, as well as its functional, evolutionary, and practical consequences.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: Core D - Project Narrative Myeloproliferative Neoplasms, which include myelofibrosis, are clonal hematopoietic stem cell disorders with limited therapeutic options currently; there is thus a need to develop innovate therapeutic approaches requiring efforts using rational, targeted therapies in order to maximize therapeutic efficacy. The MPN-RC seeks to develop novel therapeutic strategies and understand the disease biology of myelofibrosis. Core D will carry out dynamic analyses of mechanism-based biomarkers, including genomic studies, which pertain to each of the biologic and clinical studies proposed by the MPN-RC, allowing these studies to assess the mechanistic impact of specific therapeutic interventions.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Parkinson’s disease (PD) is the fastest growing disorder of the nervous system and affects about 110,000 Veterans. Genetic studies have provided vast quantities of data that will be used to better diagnose and treat PD, but most of them have been done in people of European ancestry. The problem is that some of the results cannot be generalized to people of other ancestries who might not be able to benefit as much from the advances in treatment this information will provide. This project will address that disparity by examining the genetics of PD in African American and Latino Veterans in the Million Veteran Program (MVP) and the Veterans Parkinson’s Disease Genetics Initiative (Vet-PD). We suspect that some genes have a larger influence on the risk of developing PD in these two groups than in people of European origin. Finding these genes will provide researchers with even more opportunities to learn about the causes of PD and ultimately allow clinicians to make better decisions about treatment based on a person’s genetic profile.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Acute Interstitial Nephritis (AIN) is an important cause of kidney dysfunction, and can lead to chronic kidney disease in many patients. We know that AIN occurs as an immune response in the kidney to certain drugs or infections, but do not have a clear understanding of the cell sources of the inflammation or the tubular and vascular responses. This proposal is designed to define these immune events in human kidney biopsy samples left over after clinical diagnosis has been completed, and to determine how they relate to the development of chronic kidney disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Natural products are the best source of drugs and drug leads and terpenoids, the largest family of natural products, have a wide range of clinically important activities including antibiotic, anticancer, antimalarial, and immunosuppressant properties. The proposed studies will lead to the discovery of new natural products with important biological activities, facilitate future discovery efforts by the development of systems dedicated to facile identification of terpenoids in bacteria, and result in the characterization of natural product biosynthetic enzymes. A greater understanding of terpenoid biosynthesis will also provide insights into how nature constructs medicinally relevant compounds and how these enzymes may be used as tools for future discoveries in biochemistry, bioengineering, and drug development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE STATEMENT There remains an important need for the development of effective and safe methods for accurate diagnosis of breast cancer and its subsequent management. Optoacoustic tomography (OAT) has great potential to circumvent the limitations of existing breast imaging modalities but, currently, there is no validated OAT method that is sufficiently accurate for widespread clinical imaging. The proposed research will establish computational tools for performing virtual imaging trials that can inform and accelerate the development of clinically viable and effective 3D breast OAT technologies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR COMPLEMENTARY & INTEGRATIVE HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Chronic neck pain ranks in the top five causes for years lived with disability. To inform the feasibility and design of a future definitive trial, the goal of this application is to perform a pilot study of chiropractic care and Tai Chi mind-body exercise for adults with chronic non-specific neck pain.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because it seeks to reduce opioid-related health inequities experienced by American Indians and Alaska Natives. It would do this by characterizing opioid use disorder systems of care and barriers and facilitators to care. This project is relevant to NIH’s mission because it would generate knowledge to reduce opioid-related morbidity and mortality (e.g., overdose deaths) by developing optimal opioid use disorder treatment implementation strategies in the context of Tribal Nations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE In the first cycle of this grant, we found that a protein belonging to a novel and currently untapped class of drug targets is present at high levels in cells lining the joints of rheumatoid arthritis patients, where it promotes the aggressive behavior of these cells in joint inflammation and destruction. The objective of this renewal application is to better understand the role and regulation of this protein in rheumatoid arthritis. The long-term goal is to design novel therapeutics against this protein to help control rheumatoid arthritis in patients non-responsive to current therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Narrative The primary goal of the CIFASD Consortium Diagnostic-Telemedicine Resource is to ensure consistent and accurate diagnoses of children and adults with fetal alcohol spectrum disorders (FASD) at study sites throughout the world. Because there is a critical shortage of health care practitioners who have the expertise to make this diagnosis, the Diagnostic-Telemedicine Resource will train new practitioners using telemedicine, aided by novel eHealth tools to perform these examinations. Finally, we will test these methods in delivering diagnostic services for FASD to remote areas of Alaska.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Hormonal systems regulate key physiologic processes in virtually all organ systems, and are especially important for growth and development, reproduction, and carbohydrate homeostasis; these are areas addressed by Pediatric Endocrinology. Well-trained Pediatric Endocrine investigators in basic, translational, and clinical research are needed to advance this complex and rapidly developing field, to better understand normal physiology and associated disorders. This proposal seeks continued funding for one of the oldest and most successful Pediatric Endocrine Fellowship Training Programs, with the aim of continuing to produce the next generation of academic leaders and mentors in this field.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE & PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVENCE This proposal aims to elucidate how peripheral sensory systems alter nicotine aversion neurocircuitry and ultimately regulate nicotine intake using mouse models and various genetic approaches. The existence of this ‘bottom-up’ regulation of nicotine intake by the nodose ganglia could prove extremely useful for the development of novel addiction therapies for two reasons: first, direct electrical stimulation of this ganglia has already been validated as a treatment for other neurological disorders, and second, nodose activity can be altered by non- invasive means either via systemic drug administration that targets the organ systems that it innervates or lifestyle changes such as diet and exercise.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: Controversies about the contributions of epithelial to mesenchymal transition (EMT) mechanism in tumor metastasis and chemoresistance have been discussed for decades. Given the transient, reversible and dynamic natures of the EMT process, we propose to employ multiple lineage-tracing models to study the roles of EMT in metastasis and chemoresistance. Resolving the controversies in the field will not only improve our mechanistic understanding of tumor metastasis but also provide novel targets/opportunities in combatting the deadly disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Pediatric oncology lags behind adult cancers with respect to the availability of targeted therapies. Expanding and accelerating treatment options for pediatric cancers to improve outcomes and to satisfy the requirements of the Research to Accelerate Cures and Equity (RACE) for Children Act is a central goal for NCI's Pediatric In Vivo Testing Program (Ped-In Vivo-TP). We will establish the Pediatric In Vivo Testing Coordinating Center (PIVOT CC) to manage a comprehensive and cohesive testing program to advance precision medicine in pediatric oncology through effective public-private partnerships among pharmaceutical companies, regulatory agencies, funders, and research organizations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: Project Narrative Metastasis is the main cause of fatality from breast cancer which is further aggravated by diabetes and understanding the molecular basis of this process and targeting key players that promote it is likely to lead to better therapeutic options. To achieve this goal, we developed a potent inhibitor of ARK5 and CDK4 (proteins that drive breast tumor growth) (ON123300), which was very effective in inhibiting tumor cell growth in diabetic models. Here, we propose to examine the mechanism of action and utility of ON123300 as a therapeutic agent for high-risk breast cancers using a diabetic mouse model and in mouse models of high-risk breast cancer generated from patient tumor tissues (PDX models).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Few people realize that environmental pollution and some behaviors like physical activity and tobacco smoking can affect their health by “turning on” or “turning off” certain genes through a process called “epigenetic modification.” This study will develop and test strategies for communicating about epigenetics that are understandable to people from different social and demographic groups, and that do not promote stigma, discrimination, or other harmful beliefs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Human intestinal organoids (HIOs) represent an excellent in vitro model of the human intestine and a promising source for intestinal tissue repair therapies. However, the HIO in vitro differentiation process is limited by low yield of organoids, while the therapeutic translatability is hampered by a lack of clinically-relevant delivery materials. This project will result in a well-defined engineered synthetic matrix to guide the HIO in vitro differentiation process and in vivo delivery, increasing the clinical relevance of the HIO transformative therapeutic potential.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Obesity is a major public health concern as it increases the risk for a number of common diseases such as type 2 diabetes, heart disease, stroke and certain forms of cancer. Obesity results from the interaction of the environment with a genetic predisposition and large-scale efforts have recently pointed at regions in the human genome in which genetic variations predispose humans to obesity. Our studies are aimed at determining how these genetic variations are involved in obesity and how this knowledge could be harvested for new obesity treatments.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative: Peroxisomes are ubiquitous, membrane-bound organelles that cells use to compartmentalize specialized metabolic reactions. Loss of peroxisome function causes Peroxisome Biogenesis Disorders, characterized by hearing and vision loss, neurodegeneration, and liver, kidney, and bone disease. This research seeks to understand the molecular mechanisms underlying the formation of maintenance of peroxisomes and the consequence to the cell when these mechanisms go awry.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: OVERALL: PROJECT NARRATIVE The Alvin J. Siteman Cancer Center (SCC) at Washington University and Barnes-Jewish Hospital is a NCI designated Comprehensive Cancer Center whose mission is to prevent cancer in the community and transform cancer patient care through scientific discovery. SCC accomplishes this mission through strong research programs, shared resource support, education and training, pilot funding programs, and community outreach. The translational research and scientific discovery facilitated by our seven multidisciplinary research programs and 10 shared resources (11th requested in this application) is driven by the needs of patients in our 82-county catchment area throughout Missouri and southern lllinois.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: There is urgent need to reach justice-involved women for life-saving, evidence-based PrEP and medications for opioid use disorder, using innovative healthcare delivery models that surmount existing social and structural barriers to engagement. We will randomize justice-involved, PrEP- eligible women with opioid use disorder across two sites (Connecticut and Alabama) to receive a PrEP decision aid + eHealth delivery of integrated PrEP/medications for opioid use disorder vs. the decision aid-only. We will evaluate clinical and implementation outcomes important for scalability and sustainability across diverse contexts.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The brain changes that accompany normal aging and Alzheimer’s disease do not occur at the same time or to the same degree in every part of the brain; instead they show a characteristic pattern in which some regions are affected to a much greater degree than are others. It is not known the extent to which these spatial patterns reflect differences in the local vulnerability between areas, nor the extent that they might reveal a mechanism by which pathology spreads. By measuring - across the entire cortex and cerebellum of aged individuals - the extent of pathological change, the patterns of brain inter connectivity, and local protein expression and metabolism we will test hypotheses about vulnerability and spread of Alzheimer’s pathology, opening the door to protective intervention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Type 1 diabetes (T1D) is one of the most common and serious diseases of childhood, afflicting one in 300 people in North America by 18 years of age and burdening them with a lifelong medical problem. T1D is a complex genetic disease, and to date, most of the mutations that cause or influence it remain unknown. Using new and powerful genetic methodology, we will find scores of mutations that either augment or suppress T1D in mice, yielding new insight into the causes of T1D in human patients and opening the way to specific therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Delivering antiretroviral pre-exposure prophylaxis (PrEP) to people who inject drugs (PWID) through syringe services programs (SSPs), a trusted and well-utilized institution, is acceptable and feasible, yet interventions are needed to support and scale-up the implementation of these services. This randomized controlled trial will assess the effectiveness and cost-effectiveness of an organization-level intervention designed to help SSPs optimize the delivery of PrEP services for PWID.

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Addressing the complex challenges facing the nation’s health care system requires diverse perspectives and disciplines. This post-doctoral training program is designed for both clinicians seeking to become clinician-researchers by acquiring health services research skills, as well as PhD-trained economists seeking to apply their methodological expertise to the field of health services research. We aim to train future leaders in health services research who will address our health care delivery system’s most pressing problems and make health care organization and delivery higher quality, safer, more efficient, and equitable.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This research addresses a central challenge in current global health research, the burden of stunting among infants in low- and middle-income countries facing a high burden of enteric infection. With this award, I will build an independent, interdisciplinary research program that bridges community-based enteric disease research and advanced computational modeling methods for systems epidemiology. This research will inform interventions to reduce the burden of infectious diseases on infants and children living in low- and middle-income countries.
