IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: VIRGINIA POLYTECHNIC INST AND ST UNIV
PHR: Narrative Cache Valley virus (CVV) is an important, zoonotic, arthropod-borne virus in North America that can potentially emerge and become a major pathogen of humans, wildlife and livestock. CVV emergence can result in potentially devastating consequences on our economy, food availability, human and animal health. To circumvent this threat, we will develop a lipid inorganic nanoparticle formulated, replicon-RNA vaccine that demonstrates exceptional immunogenicity and outstanding safety, and completely protects against all aspects of CVV disease, including viral-induced abortions and congenital birth defects.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE A range of neuropsychiatric disorders, including obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD) and addiction, are theorized to involve maladaptive habit formation, contributing to compulsions and disruptive repetitive behavior. Current approaches to treating these disorders are limited because we lack a solid foundation for understanding the basic neurobiological processes that go awry to produce symptoms. This project focuses on answering fundamental questions about the neural circuit mechanisms underlying habit formation and motor skill acquisition with the ultimate goal of deciphering how dysfunction in these circuits contributes to OCD, addiction, and other neuropsychiatric disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The current proposal reexamines protein turnover as a mechanism to maintain proteostasis with age. We use novel mouse models, isotopic labeling, treatments that slow aging and advanced mass spectroscopy to understand the conflicting data related to protein turnover and aging and to understand mechanisms to maintain proteostasis. The successful completion of this study will overcome a significant hurdle in the understanding of proteostasis to appropriately target proteostatic mechanisms to slow aging.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF MASSACHUSETTS MED SCH WORCESTER
PHR: NARRATIVE The research proposed here will determine how the human genome is folded inside the cell nucleus, and how this organization changes as cells go through important transitions during early differentiation and during aging. The work will produce important reference maps for the organization of the human genome during these critical phases of life, as well as new tools to study and visualize the structure and dynamics of the genome. The results can provide mechanistic insights into how genomes are regulated and will lead to a deeper understanding of how altered chromosome conformation can contribute to a variety of human diseases including premature aging.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: There is an etiologic synergy between Aβ deposition and tau misfolding in the pathogenesis of both early- and late-onset Alzheimer’s disease. In this project, we will investigate whether specific phosphorylation sites on tau protein are crucial in driving this synergy. We will also explore whether specific types of amyloid deposits are required for maturation of soluble tau into intracellular inclusions. Data generated in this proposal will broaden our mechanistic knowledge of the neuropathologic cascade in Alzheimer’s disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: The Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome (ARDS) is a global public health concerns that is currently managed by life support measures in intensive care unit across the USA. Although survival has improved with judicial fluid management and protective ventilation strategies, there are no specific pharmacologic treatments that are based on the molecular pathogenesis. The main objective of this research is to define the molecular mechanisms that regulate the role of macrophages in ALI/ARDS development and show that pharmacologic interdiction can be developed as a novel approach to prevention and treatment of ARDS that will improve human health outcomes from critical illness.

PHR: Narrative Individuals with overweight/obesity can improve their health with weight loss, but maintaining long-term changes in eating behavior and physical activity is difficult. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative An interdisciplinary team approach is necessary to fully address current HIV/AIDS research challenges that generate massive amounts of complex, high-dimensional data. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Environmental health is an important component of public health programs, with developmental processes such as reproduction, particularly vulnerable. Through its impact on reproductive health, the environment generates novel genetic variation that can lead to reproductive incompatibilities, which can ultimately cause infertility between individuals that have been differentially exposed. This proposal will study how the environment impacts oogenesis to produce genetic incompatibilities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Young Black men who have sex with men (YBMSM) have a high incidence of HIV in the South and interventions to enhance engagement in prevention services are urgently needed. Barriers to PrEP uptake among YBMSM occur at each level of modified social ecological model (MSEM) and include access, cost, transportation, low perceived HIV risk, stigma, and medical mistrust. Utilizing components of Acceptance and Commitment Therapy, we will design an intervention to improve PrEP uptake, persistence, and adherence through addressing these barriers.

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
PHR: Narrative The BioGRID database provides an extensive collection of protein and genetic interaction data for the major model organism species and humans, with user-oriented tools to explore this information. The BioGRID facilitates better understanding of human disease by enabling inference of gene and protein function through network context and the computational comparison of these gene and protein networks in human health and disease to analogous networks mapped in model organisms. The vast amounts of data in the BioGRID are freely provided to many other databases and biomedical researchers, thus enabling both fundamental and translational research.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Cryo-electron microscopy (cryo-EM) has already had a revolutionary impact on cell and molecular biology and become a major source of structural information. Still, the minimum number of parti- cles needed for a three-dimensional reconstruction of a structure, and the minimum size of the particles amenable to reconstruction, remains far above fundamental limits. Over the past four years, we have developed a laser-based phase-plate (LPP) that can contribute to reaching the standard quantum (shot-noise) limit of imaging in cryo-EM.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative An understanding of how neural circuitry produces behavior would provide important insights into the basis of brain disorders; however, the tools are lacking. The nematode Caenorhabditis elegans gives us the opportunity to study how an entire nervous system functions together to extract ecologically-relevant information about chemical stimuli, and to couch these analyses in the known structural connectivity between neurons. This project will establish a theoretical framework for understanding fine- grained, yet holistic neural processing in many neural systems using graph theory and information theory, and will enable us to understand how neural circuits work in health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE U.S. children fall short of physical activity recommendations, and innovative, practical strategies are needed to close the gap equitably. Policy recommendations promote school- and home-based interventions as well as programs that improve children's physical literacy – that is, their ability, confidence, and motivation to be physically active for life; yet no prior study has empirically tested a multilevel, PL-focused intervention for children. To fill this gap, this study will leverage a unique university/national non-profit partnership to design and test an innovative program that reaches children both at school and at home to improve their physical literacy and physical activity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Intracerebral hemorrhage (ICH) occurs when there is spontaneous bleeding into the brain, and it causes a high rate of death and serious disability, including progressive cognitive decline. Increasing evidence suggests that inflammation after ICH contributes to brain injury and clinical outcomes. Using specialized blood testing, this proposal seeks to understand which components of post-ICH inflammation affect patient outcomes, including functional outcome and the development of progressive cognitive decline. IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Pancreatic cancer is an increasingly common disease with dismal outcomes, so better therapeutics are desperately needed. Our studies demonstrate that inhibition of the sterol regulatory element-binding protein pathway that controls lipid metabolism is a promising therapeutic target. In this proposal, we will identify potent chemical inhibitors of this pathway, enabling pre-clinical studies in pancreas cancer and motivating development of therapeutics for treating pancreas cancer patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NURSING RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The Congenital Heart Disease Physical Activity Lifestyle intervention (CHD-PAL), which was designed to target elements of the Theory of Planned Behavior (TPB), has demonstrated feasibility/preliminary efficacy for increasing moderate-to-vigorous physical activity (MVPA) among adolescents and young adults (AYAs) with CHD who are less physically active; however, a larger trial is needed to determine efficacy for CHD-PAL. The current study aims to determine if CHD-PAL increases MVPA as compared to a more rigorous attention control comparator, examine durability of intervention effects, explore changes to the TPB hypothesized mechanisms, and explore the impact of CHD-PAL on biomarkers of cardiovascular health. The current study is the necessary next step in the refinement of CHD-PAL before dissemination to multiple sites for assessment of health implications and eventually the cost effectiveness of the intervention for AYAs with CHD, an understudied population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative In this project, we develop new molecular simulation methods that combine Markov State Model (MSM) and expanded-ensemble approaches. These tools can leverage the distributed computing power of Folding@home to make fundamental advances in computational drug discovery and molecular design that will lead to widespread benefits for human health. We apply these tools to understand and design new inhibitors of key cancer targets, including the PTEN tumor suppressor.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Influenza causes millions of respiratory infections every year, but there are substantial differences in the susceptibility of each person to severe flu infection. Sex differences are a major contributor to this variation. This proposal will elucidate the genetic mechanisms underlying sex differences in influenza infection, define sex- specific biomarkers for flu severity, and provide a new computational resource for the research community.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE/RELEVANCE This project will develop novel methods to capture the increasing specialization of physicians in the US based on their observed practice patterns, describe patterns in subspecialization over time and geography, and assess the impact of subspecialization on health outcomes for older adults. The results from this work will provide novel evidence to guide health policy for the aging population, including improved methods to accurately measure specialty supply, evidence to guide health insurers and policymakers for applications such as determining adequacy of specialist coverage in insurance design (e.g., Medicare Advantage), data for identifying populations with shortages in subspecialist access, and evidence for guiding development of telemedicine infrastructure. This understanding will be crucial for policies regarding the growth and distribution of subspecialty expertise and technologies to implement the National Institute on Aging’s mission of improving the health and well-being of older Americans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE. Chromosomal-breaking agents (i.e. clastogens), including ionizing radiation, remain a cornerstone of cancer therapy; nevertheless, their efficacy could be improved by inhibiting the repair of chromosomal breaks in cancer cells. Indeed, inhibitors of the DNA-dependent protein kinase catalytic subunit (DNAPKcs) are being developed for this approach; but to identify the ideal contexts for using such inhibitors, it is critical to understand the role of DNAPKcs in chromosomal break repair. Thus, our proposed studies to elucidate the mechanisms of DNAPKcs function during chromosomal break repair will support the mission of the NIH to improve cancer treatments and patient outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Over the past ~15 years there has been tremendous progress in the treatment of lung cancer with EGFR mutations with targeted therapies. However, even the newest agents are not curative and there is variability in the depth and durability of responses. The goal of this research is to provide insight into the genetic mechanisms that modulate the growth and sensitivity to therapy of EGFR mutant lung tumors to eventually identify better potential therapeutic strategies for this disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: This study plans to validate an existing “risk calculator” (RC), a mathematical tool that can help predict mood recurrences and whether the recurrence is depression or mania. The existing RC only predicts risk between 1 and 5 years, but not imminent risk (1-4 weeks before recurrence). To do this, we are going to evaluate whether data obtained from a smartphone application that continuously measures sleep-activity rhythms, mobility, and digital social interactions will enhance the RC to predict the immediate risk of a recurrence and thus, enable clinicians to intervene promptly before the recurrence occurs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Overexposure to UV radiation causes skin damage, inflammation, defective immunity, and development of skin cancer, which is the most common cancer in the US and the world. The β-blocker carvedilol prevents UV-induced skin cancer by attenuating DNA damage and skin inflammation and reversing immunosuppression, and our recent data indicate that the non-β-blocking enantiomer R-carvedilol shows the same effects without disturbing the cardiovascular system. Studies are proposed in this application to determine the molecular target, safety and delivery of R-carvedilol, which will not only provide valuable information about repurposing a β-blocker as a topical prophylactic medication for cancer, but also lead us to identify new targets for cancer chemoprevention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative: Pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma (PDAC) is projected to become the second deadliest cancer by 2030. We recently showed that TH2 cells produce type 2 cytokines (IL4 and IL13) that provide trophic support to PDAC tumorigenesis. In this proposal, we aim to understand the mycobiome mediated cancer cell-TH2 axis and explore the therapeutic potential of inhibiting this axis for PDAC treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative  Lymphoid malignancies are primarily tumors of B cell origin and will be responsible for approximately 150,000 new cases of cancer and 40,000 deaths in the USA in 2020. While responses in advanced B cell tumors treated with chimeric antibody receptor (CAR)-expressing T cells have been remarkable for some people, many patients do not respond to this treatment. This proposed research will explore how manipulating signaling through the type I interferon receptor chain subunit 1 (IFNAR1), a key molecule for T cell activation, function and proliferation can be harnessed to improve CAR T cell therapy for patients with B cell tumors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Type 1 diabetes mellitus (T1DM) is associated with significant patient burden, and environmental factors are thought to trigger disease onset. Modifying these exposures may offer safe and cost-effective approaches to prevent or delay T1DM; however, the timing and combination of exposures that contribute to T1DM etiology are poorly understood. This study aims to identify temporal sequences of exposures that contribute to T1DM with the long-term goal of improving the clinical translatability of exposure modification in T1DM prevention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In biomedical and public health studies, careful planning is critical to ensure robust scientiﬁc results as well as efﬁ- cient use of resources. Part of that process involves estimating the sample size needed to obtain statistical results at the needed level of precision. This project develops new methods for estimation of sample size and statistical power in the widely-used “bread-and-butter” generalized linear models class of statistical analysis methods.

PHR: NARRATIVE We propose to develop intranasal, parainfluenza 5 (PIV5) viral-vector delivered vaccines against human Lyme disease for the US market. IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Public Health Relevance: Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) is one of the leading causes of mortality, but we have not yet discovered treatments that significantly reverse the lung damage of COPD. In this study, we will continue a successful project that has already identified ACVR1B and TGFB2 as likely COPD-causing genes, and we will use new methods to directly observe alternative splicing in lung tissues and cell types in order to identify new COPD-causing genes and disease mechanisms. The genes and disease mechanisms identified by this project will advance efforts to identify new treatments for COPD that could improve the lives of millions of people affected by this disease worldwide.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Mutation is the source of all evolutionary novelty and diversity shaping both the structure and sequence of genomes. The genomes of individual somatic cells also accumulate mutations throughout the lifetime of organisms impacting cellular functions and contributing to diseases. The goal of the proposed research is to understand at both the cellular and organismal level how cell-type, genotype, selective pressures, and evolutionary histories influence the structure and sequence of the genome.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Lung cancer is the second most common malignancy in the US with Human immunodeficiency virus (HIV)-infected individuals and AIDS patients at increased relative risk by 250% and younger diagnosis. HIV-infected cells secrete extracellular vesicles, such as exosomes, into the blood and other body fluids which we found to stimulate lung cancer growth in HIV-infected persons. This research will help us understand why and how HIV-associated exosomes promote cancer and find a new method to control lung cancer development and progression in the population of persons living with HIV.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Emory prepares physician scientists to tackle health promotion, disease treatment and the pursuit of research- intensive careers. We offer research training in the biomedical sciences, biomedical engineering (Emory/GA Tech joint program), public health and social sciences (such as anthropology and sociology) to diversify the physician scientist training force and enhance early appreciation of the power of multidisciplinary approaches. Clinical training across multiple sites that include Grady Memorial (level I trauma/safety net hospital), Emory University Hospital Midtown (urban community hospital), the Atlanta VA Medical Center (serving Veterans across northeast GA), Wesley Woods (geriatric hospital), and Children’s Healthcare of Atlanta cultivates appreciation for the specific needs of diverse patient populations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative Two out of three people treated with select types of chemotherapy experience a side effect known as peripheral neuropathy that causes pain, discomfort and numbness in the extremities and contributes to poor quality of life. We do not know who is at greatest risk for this side effect or how patients and providers weigh the risks of neuropathy against the potentially life-saving benefits of cancer treatment. The proposed study will help identify patients at high risk for chemotherapy induced neuropathy and assess how patients and clinicians might use information about neuropathy risk to make better informed decisions about cancer care.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Legionella pneumophila (Lp) is the agent of a severe form of pneumonia known as Legionnaires' disease and an intracellular parasite of amoebae when in its natural aquatic habitats and an intracellular parasite of macrophages and epithelia when it is introduced in the lungs. We have gained evidence that Lp expresses two functional forms of type IV pili (T4P), surface appendages that often mediate attachment to human cells and other important surfaces. T4P are part of a fuller understanding of pathogenesis and potential targets for disease diagnosis or prevention, and therefore, the proposed studies are aimed at determining how different forms of Lp T4P promote infection and in different ways.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Transcranial magnetic stimulation (TMS) is an effective treatment for depression, but clinical outcome is suboptimal, partially because we are missing biologically-grounded brain markers which show that TMS is modifying activity at the intended target in the brain. The goal of this proposal is to characterize the key markers of the brain’s response to repeated doses of TMS with high resolution using invasive brain recordings in humans, and relate these brain markers to noninvasive recordings. These markers will improve our understanding of TMS and can be used to optimize and enhance clinical efficacy for depression and other psychiatric disorders. Repetitive transcranial magnetic stimulation (rTMS) is an effective treatment for depression, but clinical outcome is suboptimal because we don’t understand how rTMS affects the brain and we do not have brain measurements that indicate when stimulation reaches the target location in the brain (target engagement) and when stimulation changes the target (plasticity). The goal of this proposal is to characterize the key signatures of the brain’s response to rTMS with high resolution using invasive brain recordings (Aim 1), investigate how these recordings relate to noninvasive brain measures (Aim 2), and study how noninvasive brain measures relate to clinical outcome after TMS treatment for depression. Linking noninvasive brain measures to both invasive measurements and clinical outcome can greatly improve our understanding of the brain mechanisms underlying TMS-induced clinical outcome and provide a path for optimizing TMS around these measures to improve clinical efficacy. Transcranial magnetic stimulation (TMS) is an effective treatment for depression, but clinical outcome is suboptimal with up to half of patients not responding. A critical missing factor that may improve TMS treatment are markers that TMS is modifying activity at the intended target in the brain. The goal of this proposal is to characterize the key signatures of the brain’s response to TMS with high resolution using invasive brain recordings, and relate these measures to noninvasive recordings and clinical outcomes of TMS treatment for depression, which will provide a path for optimizing TMS around these measures to improve clinical efficacy. This research will help our understanding of how transcranial magnetic stimulation (TMS) affects the brain. We will develop new methods of measuring TMS-induced changes in brain activity with high spatial and temporal accuracy that is only possible with intracranial recording and relate them to noninvasive recording measures that are more commonly used and to treatment outcome in depressed patients receiving therapeutic TMS. The research will provide key markers of TMS stimulation that can be used to facilitate the development of better interventions and treatments for depression and potentially other psychiatric diseases. Transcranial magnetic stimulation (TMS) is an effective treatment for depression, but clinical outcome is suboptimal, partially because we are missing brain markers that TMS is modifying activity at the intended target in the brain. The goal of this proposal is to characterize the key markers of the brain’s response to TMS with high resolution using invasive brain recordings, and relate these markers to noninvasive recordings and clinical outcomes of TMS treatment for depression. These brain markers can be used to optimize TMS around these measures to improve clinical efficacy for depression and potentially other psychiatric diseases. with up to half of patients not responding. A critical missing factor that may improve TMS treatment are markers that TMS is modifying activity at the intended target in the brain. The goal of this proposal is to characterize the key signatures of the brain’s response to TMS with high resolution using invasive brain recordings, and relate these measures to noninvasive recordings and clinical outcomes of TMS treatment for depression, which will provide a path for optimizing TMS around these measures to improve clinical efficacy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Liver cancer affects Southeast Asian Americans disproportionately with higher death rates relative to other Asian Americans and relative to non-Asian Americans. This proposed research is one of the first comprehensive assessments of the social determinants of health of patients with this cancer with a special emphasis on understanding transportation/distance barriers as well as joblessness, trouble finding childcare, limited education, and other social determinants of health. These findings – in conjunction with an in depth career development plan for the principal investigator – will inform the testing of innovative and feasible solutions to eliminate these prevailing disparities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE For many ion channels activated by binding of multiple ligands at distinct domains, the sequence of binding events that drive gating of the central ion conducting pore are difficult to observe as they are obscured by averaging over asynchronous events in ensemble measures, challenge structural identification due to their transient nature, and often precede opening of the channel pore and thus do not elicit ionic currents. This project will employ an innovative combination of single-molecule and fluorescence imaging techniques that can resolve individual binding events and parse out the energy landscape governing the dynamic behavior and coordination of multiple binding sites for both agonists and drugs. The proposed work will fill a critical gap in our understanding of the sequence of energetic events during activation of cyclic nucleotide gated channels essential for visual and olfactory sensation, and resolve a long standing debate on the basis for drug modulation of GABAA receptors by benzodiazepines, one of the most widely prescribed class of psychotropic drugs today.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF OKLAHOMA HLTH SCIENCES CTR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Normal cognitive function requires an adequate blood supply to support neuronal activity via neurovascular coupling, and recent evidence demonstrates that age-related cognitive decline is directly linked to reduced neuro- vascular coupling (NVC) responses. Based on the abundant literature in the field, our published preclinical results and preliminary data in humans, these series of studies are designed to assess a clinically relevant intervention to improve endothelial function and NVC responses in community dwelling older adults to prevent and, potentially to treat, age-related cognitive decline. We demonstrated that age-related decline in cellular nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide (NAD) levels is a critical mechanism that promotes impairment of cerebromicrovascular endothelial function and NVC responses, and we propose to target this mechanism via safe-to-use, as demonstrated in recent clinical trials, NAD supplement nicotinamide riboside in a double blinded, placebo controlled, parallel group study.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: NARRATIVE This project will test the effect of a home delivered foods and kitchen skills (FoRKS) intervention among adult safety-net primary care patients who report food insecurity and have hypertension. Sixteen and 24-week blood pressure will be compared between participants randomized to FoRKS vs enhanced usual care. Additional outcomes include learning engagement, kitchen confidence and skills, and nutrition and food security.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative The field of cancer metabolism has had significant clinical impact: imaging modalities, biomarkers, and new therapeutic targets have resulted from studying tumor metabolism in cell culture. However, many findings from cell culture studies have been difficult to replicate in vivo, suggesting additional factors that influence tumor metabolism. In this project I use clinically-matched, patient-derived xenografts to identify the factors that influence tumor metabolism in vivo.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cardiovascular diseases leading to heart failure, heart attack, and sudden death due to catastrophic arrhythmias (irregular heartbeat) remain the leading cause of death among American adults. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCI CTR HOUSTON
PHR: Intestinal failure is a devastating disease with an incidence of 24.5 cases per 100,000 live births that if left untreated results in dehydration, malnutrition, and ultimately, death. As a pediatric surgeon, I often witness the significant loss of bowel resulting in intestinal failure, and the complications that arise from inadequate treatments such as parenteral nutrition, bowel lengthening procedures, teduglutide, or intestinal transplant. Tissue-engineered intestine is a potential therapeutic solution for these nutritionally crippled children; and understanding the developmental processes required to generate a fully functional intestine is relevant to the NIH's mission and a high priority to improve the lives of affected children.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Developmental lead exposure is still a significant public health problem resulting in long-term adverse cognitive and behavioral outcomes, yet the mechanisms through which lead causes these adverse outcomes are still not completely known. At the basic science level, understanding the molecular mechanisms that may be involved in the adverse effects of lead on the brain and behavior is important and will be addressed in proposed work by studying, for the first time, the effects of developmental lead exposure on a novel epitranscriptomic mechanism involving direct modification of RNA and its influence on gene expression levels and behavioral responses following developmental Pb exposure. The proposed studies will add a new dimension to the understanding of gene-environment interactions following developmental Pb exposure and set the stage for further studies that may ultimately impact treatment of Pb-induced cognitive/ behavioral dysfunction.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This interdisciplinary research will provide a better understanding of the relationship between social determinants and biological mechanisms during the transitional period of late adolescence to young adulthood. Our findings could have strong implications for social justice measures as well as public health interventions to curb cardiometabolic disease. By studying interpersonal discrimination and the results of environmental racism as stressors, we begin to deconstruct the psychosocial and physical costs of allostatic load for Latinx youth so that future interventions will be approached not only from an individual, but also at a systemic level.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Abnormal vision during a childhood ‘critical period’ can cause amblyopia, also known as lazy eye, a disorder comprising several deficits in spatial vision including impaired binocular depth perception. The proposed research is relevant to public health because knowledge of the neuronal basis and developmental timeline of binocular depth perception will improve our understanding of targets for therapeutic intervention. The proposed research is relevant to the mission of the NEI/NIH to increase understanding of how the development of the visual system and visual experience results in binocular depth perception.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Shifts between pathological and healthy brain states are fundamental features of many psychiatric disorders. Here we propose to investigate a novel mechanism mediating the transitions between network and behavioral states, which may provide insight into the episodic nature of psychiatric illnesses. We hypothesize that stress disrupts network function and behavioral states by impairing local neurosteroid signaling in the BLA and that increasing the capacity for endogenous neurosteroidogenesis can restore healthy network and behavioral states.

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed short-term training for veterinary students blends expertise and resources across Tufts Cummings School of Veterinary Medicine and the Division of Comparative Medicine at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology to provide a rich, vibrant environment for trainees to engage in a diverse array of activities that include laboratory-based research, animal models of disease and comparative/translational medicine among others. This new collaborative will leverage the diverse scientific landscape within Massachusetts and provide unique opportunities for students to experience research within the context of academic centers, industry/biotechnology entities and contract research organizations. Importantly, veterinary students will explore alternative career choices in the context of a structured, engaging and supportive program led by veterinary scientists committed to generating trainee enthusiasm and interest in future research pursuits.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Cytoplasmic mislocalization of TDP-43, an essential protein with critical roles in RNA processing and stability, is seen in over 95% of amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) cases and up to half of frontotemporal dementia (FTD) cases, and widely implicated in the pathogenesis of neurodegeneration. Mechanistic understanding of the basis of TDP-43 mislocalization in disease, and therapeutic strategies to oppose TDP-43 nuclear clearance, are urgently needed. Here, we will define the mechanism and key regulatory features of TDP-43 nuclear export, which our preliminary studies show is both energy- and RNA-dependent, and investigate the ability of RNA-based TDP-43 nuclear retention to attenuate neurodegeneration in patient derived neurons and Drosophila models of TDP-43 proteinopathy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Leukemia patients carrying the rearrangement of the NUP98 gene exhibit particularly poor clinical outcomes, demanding a better understanding of how such diseases develop. This project aims to investigate the previously less-studied oncogenic function mediated by the unstructured protein region harbored within the leukemia-associated onco-proteins, which contributes to aggressive tumor phenotypes. The outcomes of the project may help develop new therapeutic strategies in future; therefore, the proposed research is directly relevant to public health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative: The proposed research is relevant to public health because it focuses on the rational development of a therapeutic strategy targeting clinically occult breast cancer cells that persist despite current treatments. Once such a strategy has been developed, there is the potential for significant improvement in anti- cancer therapy to prevent tumor recurrence and disease progression. Thus, the proposed research is relevant to the mission of NCI through the development of improved treatments that would decrease morbidity and mortality in patients with breast cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Chromosomal variation plays an important role in several biological processes and is associated with multiple traits, yet the forces driving and maintaining this variation are not fully understood. This proposal tackles challenges regarding the evolution of two major features of the genomic landscape: chromosome inversions and sex chromosomes. By developing computational tools necessary for genomic analysis and by testing core hypotheses of the evolution of large genomic features, this work will make important strides in our understanding of how and why the structure of the genome changes through evolutionary time.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: PALO ALTO VETERANS INSTIT FOR RESEARCH
PHR: We propose to investigate novel mechanisms of action of the SIRT7 enzyme in regulating chromatin – the structure in which the human genome is packaged – and how these mechanisms are linked to mammalian aging and cancer biology. Defects in chromatin regulation can contribute to numerous aging-associated pathologies, including cancer, metabolic and neurodegenerative disease. This proposal will provide new insights into how chromatin mechanisms regulate important cellular functions, and has the potential to identify new targets for therapeutic intervention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The overall goal of the Medical Scientist (MD/PhD) Training Program (MSTP) at the University of Wisconsin- Madison (UW-Madison) is to train physician-scientists in the broad range of research areas critical to advancing frontiers of medical knowledge and therapeutics. Integrated MD/PhD programs, by immersing trainees in research during what are arguably their most impressionable and creative years, are a key component of our country’s portfolio to provide such training and dovetail into the combined missions of UW-Madison and its School of Medicine and Public Health (SMPH). UW-Madison consistently ranks as one of the top 20 research universities in the world and is especially well-known for graduate education and contributions to society. Research and education related to biomedicine are carried out in a large number of departments, centers, and programs inside and outside of the SMPH that are integrated, collaborative, and span the many disciplines that will improve the health of our nation and world.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Brain-related aging and health, including Alzheimer's disease and related dementia (ADRD) have a profound impact on individual physical and mental functioning, and also on families and society. Therefore, investigation of neurocognitive aging and ADRD is crucial to our society and the individuals within it; however, we have too few trained underrepresented scientists to address the challenges of neurocognitive aging and ADRD faced by our increasingly diverse aging population. Our project will develop an exhaustive research training experience in neurocognitive aging ranging from basic neurobiology of neurodegenerative conditions, modifiable risk factors and health disparities related to neurocognitive aging, which will subsequently establish a talented, committed, and sustained pipeline of underrepresented students reflective of community demographics, who have unique perspectives, capable of addressing critical neurocognitive aging challenges in our changing world.

PHR: Project Narrative: LRRK2 is a multi-enzyme and multidomain protein that is associated with several diseases, including Parkinson’s disease, inflammatory bowel disease, tuberculosis leprosy, and Alzheimer’s disease. This study addresses several issues of central importance to understanding the structure and activity of LRRK2 by using biophysical and biochemical methods, which will show a molecular understanding of LRRK2 and how it might cause the disease mentioned above.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative TNF inhibitors (TNFi) are biological anti-inflammatory drugs that are used worldwide as first or second-line treatment for chronic autoimmune diseases. Paradoxically, however, 15-30% of patients treated with TNFi develop anti-nuclear antibodies within 6 months of starting treatment and 0.2-1% develop clinical lupus. This project will use both mouse models and a cohort of human patients starting on TNFi to determine the mechanism for the induction of autoimmunity in the setting of suppression of B lymphocyte responses. These studies should enhance our knowledge of regulation of immune responses and may help to improve selection of patients for safe use of TNFi treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK STATE PSYCHIATRIC INSTITUTE DBA RESEARCH FOUNDATION FOR MENTAL HYGIENE, INC
PHR: NARRATIVE Schizophrenia represents a major public-health problem worldwide. In this proposal, we aim to combine genetic, developmental, fMRI, neurocognitive, and self-report data across several large-scale datasets to provide an integrated framework for the convergent pathophysiological mechanisms linking the complex genotypes to neural and behavioral phenotypes associated with the illness. In doing so, we hope to contribute to the development of novel brain-based biomarkers for diagnosis and treatment selection, and to help reduce the harmful stigma associated with schizophrenia, which could have important public-health repercussions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Characterizing the molecular and evolutionary basis of host-pathogen interactions may improve our understanding of the dynamics of human infectious diseases, help identifying therapeutical targets, and inform public health policies to combat future epidemics. Using ancient DNA obtained from archeological specimens, we can directly assess the signature of these interactions in the past and identify pathogen and human genetic variation lost with time. This research proposal centers on developing new resources (datasets and methods) for characterizing host-pathogen interactions and pathogen-driven human evolution using time-series data based on ancient DNA.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NURSING RESEARCH
PHR: Psychosocial interventions for chronic musculoskeletal pain have proliferated and show efficacy when compared to largely inert control conditions, but the effects appear to be no more than modest. To increase the potency of these treatments, we must identify specific and shared mediators, as well as reveal factors that predict whether a given treatment is most effective for a certain person. We will address this issue by comparing the mechanisms of three leading interventions for chronic pain: Cognitive Behavioral Therapy, Acceptance and Commitment Therapy, and Emotional Awareness and Expression Therapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cone beam CT (CBCT) is becoming an indispensable imaging modality for minimally invasive image-guided interventions. High quality CBCT imaging plays a pivotal role in guaranteeing the success of diagnostic and treatment procedures. In this project, a new CBCT imaging platform that integrates both a photon counting detector and a flat panel detector to provide much improved soft-tissue contrast detectability and quantitative spectral CT image guidance will be developed to enable more accurate diagnoses and image guidance for treatment planning and treatment delivery.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Glycosylation is an abundant and complex co-translational modification of proteins that impacts protein folding, maturation, stability, subcellular localization, and enzymatic activity. While critical roles of N-linked glycosylation are beginning to emerge in the brain, its involvement in Alzheimer's disease (AD) remains largely unknown. We provided preliminary data in support of N-linked glycan alterations as a driver of AD disease pathology, the goal of this proposal is to define the cellular and extracellular events underlying altered N-link glycan metabolism in AD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Human Papillomaviruses infect keratinocytes in the skin and mucosa and induce epithelial tumors. In order to cause disease virus has to deliver its genome to the nucleus of the basal cells of this stratified epithelia. Herein, we propose to fill gaps in our understanding of late events of viral trafficking and establishment of infection, which in turn allows identification of novel targets for prevention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative: Chronic liver injury leads to scarring which impairs liver function and leads to liver failure; however there are no therapeutic options to limit or reverse scaring formation. A subset of liver cells produce scar tissue, and this process causes cellular stress which cells must overcome to survive and promote fibrosis. The goal of our project is to understand how liver cells accommodate stress to produce excess scar tissue, and inhibit these processes to limit or reverse liver fibrosis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Normal cellular proliferation requires an orderly progression through the cell cycle, but cancer cells proliferate inappropriately and without end causing morbidity and mortality. Since tumor cells proliferate inappropriately, precise inhibition of the cell cycle may lead to the death of tumor cells while normal cells may be spared. Herein we investigate CDK1 as a therapeutic target for cancer with broad utility in tumors and metastasis.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) is an important cause of death in adults with high mortality rate (80%) if rupture occurs. This study will provide compelling evidence and new findings that will lead to novel strategies for developing effective therapeutics to treat AAA.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research will fill a gap in the science by examining respiratory sinus arrhythmia (RSA), a marker of emotion regulation, as a predictor of adolescent substance use and sexual risk. Such markers are needed for reliably identifying vulnerable early adolescents for targeted prevention interventions to address Healthy People 2020 objectives related to adolescent health, including pregnancy prevention (FP-8.1), sexually transmitted diseases (HIV-2, STD-2), alcohol use (SA-14.4), and marijuana use (SA-13.2).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES

PHR: Project Narrative  Cystathionine β synthase (CBS) regulation is critical to maintaining low levels of intracellular homocysteine. In this study I will examine how mutations in a linker of human CBS alter the enzyme’s catalytic activity, AdoMet induced activation, and redox mediated inhibition. I will also elucidate how these changes translate into a cellular context. These studies will provide insight into the mechanism by which the transsulfuration pathway is controlled.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The research team proposes to identify patterns of brain activity that increase risk for depression and psychosocial protective factors that can reduce this risk, which could be targeted in interventions for adolescents exposed to adversity to prevent the development of depression. Importantly, the research team will also measure allostatic load, an index of wear-and-tear on the body resulting from stress that predicts a range of physical and mental health problems, to identify protective factors that reduce risk for depression without raising allostatic load. This project is relevant to NIMH’s mission because it characterizes developmental processes that give rise to mental illness and identifies protective factors to serve as novel intervention targets.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE STRA6 is the receptor for retinol bound to its specific carrier in the bloodstream retinol binding protein, and it mediates cellular uptake of this essential nutrient. Understanding at the molecular level the relationship between the structure and the function of mammalian STRA6 is of high relevance to human health, as it may point at novel targets for therapeutic approaches in treatment of developmentally-related pathologies and diseases of the visual system. Indeed, mutations in the STRA6 gene have been associated with severe developmental malformations that are hallmarks of the Matthew-Wood syndrome, which among other phenotypes includes ocular defects ranging from mild microphthalmia to anophthalmia.

PHR: Project Narrative It is difficult to predict recovery after severe traumatic brain injury (TBI). The results of this study will help clinicians know if their patients have chance of recovery after severe injury when discussing recovery and prognosis with family members.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Knowledge of the function of every human gene is necessary for determining the roles and relationships of genes and regulatory elements in various normal and disease-associated biological pathways and networks. In this project, we will leverage the state-of-the-art cellular engineering and single-cell capabilities of The Jackson Laboratory to comprehensively catalog the phenotypes of 250 null mutations in human induced pluripotent stem cells differentiated into extra-embryonic and neuroectodermal lineages. By focusing on these early embryonic lineages, we will gain important insight into multiple biological processes, including neurodevelopmental disorders and those impacting later life.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Mutations in the RNA splicing gene U2AF1 are commonly observed in Myelodysplastic syndromes (MDS). In this proposal, we will define the roles of U2AF1 mutations and co-occurring epigenetic mutations in the pathogenesis of MDS, and determine the molecular mechanisms of myelodysplasia induced by U2AF1 mutants. Results from these studies may lead to identification of new therapeutic approach for treatment of MDS.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The Engaging and Mentoring through Biomedical Research And Career Exploration (EMBRACE) project will increase the diversity of the biomedical research workforce through designing and implementing career development opportunities and research experiences for students and strategic professional development for faculty to better guide students on biomedical research careers. Students will participate in integrated research and career support activities organized longitudinally through the biology degree program, including a novel research experience sequence and career development resources, mentoring, and support. The desired outcome is to support a diverse group of undergraduate students and stimulate their interest, boost their self-efficacy, and provide strategies to pursue careers in biomedical research.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR COMPLEMENTARY & INTEGRATIVE HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Our 5-year clinical trial in 25,871 adults found promising effects of vitamin D for reducing cancer death and of marine omega-3 fatty acids for reducing myocardial infarction and total coronary heart disease. Genetic and biochemical studies will help determine which individuals are most likely to benefit from supplementation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This proposal seeks to develop a new class of b-strand/sheet mimics capable of disrupting the aggregation of amyloid proteins. These compounds will be used to selectively target the fibrilization and transmission of toxic tau filaments from cell to cell. The research plan incorporates chemical synthesis, structural characterization, and biological evaluation of novel peptide and protein mimics to probe neurodegenerative protein assemblies.

PHR: Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is a complex age-dependent disorder that requires multiple approaches to understand at a molecular level in order to develop novel diagnostics and disease modifying treatments. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Sexual minority women experience exceptionally high rates of mental health problems. This study aims to describe developmental trajectories of sexual minority women’s mental health across adolescence and young adulthood; identify risk and protective factors; and explore biological, psychological, and social/interpersonal mechanisms through which minority stress negatively affects mental health in this vulnerable population. Findings will inform the development of interventions to prevent and treat mental illness among sexual minority women. 1

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Heritable changes that can last for multiple generations without changing DNA sequence have been reported in many organisms, including humans. By focusing on the regulatory architectures that promote or prevent gene silencing in the nematode C. elegans, we will gain broadly applicable insights regardless of the particular molecules that mediate similar regulatory interactions in other systems. These insights will improve the diagnosis and treatment of hereditary diseases, especially those with an epigenetic origin in previous generations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative: Pathologic Tau protein spreading in neurons and other brain cells significantly contribute to the disease progression and severity of Alzheimer's disease and other tauopathies. However, underlying mechanisms are poorly known and therapeutic strategies are lacking. This project aims to determine if lymphocyte-activation gene 3 (Lag3) is a receptor of pathologic tau fibrils and can be targeted to inhibit pathologic tau spreading for the treatment of tauopathies. Pre-clinical results from this project will provide a proof of concept of LAG3-targeted therapies using monoclonal antibodies for Alzheimer's disease and likely other tauopathies.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Our aim is to explore unitary principles of nervous system development. PHR: Project Narrative This project will develop a novel genetically engineered mouse strain in which a newly discovered super- enhancer that regulates the genes encoding the IL-33 and IL-18 receptors can be conditionally ablated in selected individual cell types. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Although poly(ethylene glycol) (PEG) hydrogels are widely regarded as biologically inert materials, mounting evidence suggests that a significant percentage of the population is primed for an immune response against this polymer. IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Metabolic waste accumulation due to meningeal disruption has been linked to the onset of neurodegeneration, increased incidence of stroke, altered vascular permeability, cognitive decline, and lower recovery from brain injury. Expanding our understanding of the integral cell populations comprising the meninges and the pathways regulating their development and function will help elucidate genetic mechanisms affecting meningeal and CNS stability during disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Voltage-gated Kv7/KCNQ potassium channels require membrane lipid cofactor PIP2 to open and calmodulin to traffic to the neuronal axons where they potently suppress repetitive and burst firing of action potentials. This proposal will identify the PIP2 binding sites that change by different gating states, subunit composition, and calmodulin binding of Kv7 channels, thereby controlling their axonal enrichment and function to reduce neuronal excitability. In contrast to a well-established role of PIP2 in gating modulation, this project will provide novel concepts that the PIP2 binding landscape is dynamic and modulates both function and trafficking of axonal Kv7 channels to impact neuronal excitability and the mechanisms of pathogenic variants in Kv7 subunits that cause epilepsy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Reperfusion injury is a common pathology that can occur after restoration of blood flow to ischemic heart muscle. This proposal seeks to develop and investigate non-invasive cardiovascular magnetic resonance imaging and positron emission tomography approaches to detect reperfusion injury in vivo and assess their prognostic value for adverse remodeling of the heart.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Approximately 40 million people worldwide are living with HIV/AIDS, and a protective vaccine or functional cure has been elusive despite four decades of extensive research. The proposed Duke Consortium for Innovative HIV/AIDS Vaccine and Cure Research (CIAVCR) program will provide new insights into the effects of vaccine-induced polyfunctional protective immune responses on eliminating HIV latent reservoirs. The ultimate goal of these studies is to develop an effective combined immunotherapeutic regimen for HIV-1 prevention and cure using the non-human primate (NHP) model that provides a direct path into the clinic for use in humans.

PHR: Project Narrative To fully understand how we hear, and develop effective treatments for hearing deficits, requires knowledge of multiple disciplines, such as biology, medicine and engineering. This program trains junior scientists to be experts in one discipline and familiar with several, so that they are able to focus the tools and techniques of multiple disciplines on the problems to be solved.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Primary progressive aphasia (PPA) is a degenerative condition of language loss that affects many patients with frontotemporal dementia (FTD) and Alzheimer's disease (AD) and for which there are no effective treatments. The inability to access names of objects, or anomia, is one of the most common, burdensome deficits associated with PPA, and while promising early evidence suggests that a noninvasive neuromodulation technique called transcranial direct current stimulation (tDCS) may be helpful in treating anomia, progress toward bringing this treatment into widespread clinical use is hampered by the absence of large, convincing, multi-site clinical trials. The current project addresses this gap by conducting the world's first well-powered Phase 2 clinical trial of tDCS therapy in PPA, in order to more definitively determine whether tDCS paired with behavioral naming treatment results in lasting improvement in naming ability and also to identify the characteristics of persons with PPA for whom treatment with tDCS is most likely to be effective. Project Narrative

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative  The proposed mobile solution to be developed under this SBIR project will be the first clinical tool that utilizes a mobile device to capture detailed foot 3D shape dynamics for in-office customization and rapid prototyping of foot orthotics. The unique data acquisition and optimization framework has many advantages over existing practice in the podiatric industry. We foresee the proposed solution will have a reasonably large market share in the rapidly growing multi-billion dollar foot ulceration care industry due to the growing aging population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Despite high prevalence rates of mental illness in youth, most U.S. youth with mental health need do not receive mental healthcare, with the disparity in need and service use highest among racial/ethnic minority and socially disadvantaged families. Psychoeducation, which provides information about mental health problems and treatment options, has emerged as a promising tool for engaging families in mental healthcare. To achieve health equity, a Psychoeducation Toolkit that contains evidence-based, culturally responsive elements will be co-developed with community stakeholders to engage underserved families in mental healthcare.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Memory CD8 T cells can provide immunity against infections and tumors, and improving their generation is a major goal of vaccination and immunotherapy. This project aims to understand how a highly functional subset of circulating memory CD8 T cells contributes to sterilizing immunity. Our goal is to understand the strengths and weaknesses of this population and to use this knowledge to enhance memory T cell persistence and function.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Microbial production of fucosylated human milk oligosaccharides Human milk oligosaccharides are potent bioactive compounds that modulate neonatal health and are of interest for development as potential drug treatments for adult diseases. The potential of these molecules, their limited access from natural sources, and difficulty in large-scale isolation of individual HMOs for studies and applications have motivated the development of novel production strategies. In this proposed project, we will establish a strategy for efficient and cost-effective production of fucosylated lacto-N-tetraoses (LNTs) such as LNFP II, LNFP I, and LNDFH I from lactose and L-fucose in live engineered Escherichia coli cells.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis (ALS) patients usually have symptoms starting in one part of the body with weakness spreading rapidly over time to other regions. We believe that this disease spread may be mediated by astroglia through the hemichannel-mediated release of factors into the extracellular environment that results in motor neuron death. This project will investigate the pathways by which hemichannels on ALS astrocytes cause this toxicity and will investigate a pharmacologic therapeutic strategy for blocking hemichannels by utilizing novel ALS human iPS cells and rodent models.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The Transdisciplinary Conference for Future Leaders in Precision Public Health aims to develop and sustain a conference that provides a space for early career investigators who work in the field of cancer precision public health to come together to support capacity building for the field. This conference will annually convene 150 precision public health investigators and practitioners, from around the world to increase knowledge, to advance key research priorities for the field, and to establish an ongoing collaborative network to advance precision public health research in cancer. The long-term goal of this conference is to build capacity for and the impact of precision public health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MIAMI SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: NARRATIVE  Esophageal adenocarcinoma is a significant health problem in the U.S. due to its increasing incidence, poor survival rate, and limited treatment options. The proposed research will provide new insights into esophageal carcinogenesis and lay the groundwork for novel cancer chemopreventive treatments.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Chromosomes are packed into a cell’s nucleus in an orderly fashion, and early studies suggest that disorganized chromosomes can lead to health problems, for example neurological disease. This study will investigate what happens when the genes that orchestrate orderly chromosome packing are mutated. The results will improve the diagnosis of patients with mutations in these genes, lay the groundwork for targeted therapy of this class of neurogenetic disorder, and will generate fundamental knowledge about the spatial organization of the genome and the purpose it serves for reading the right genes in the right amount at the right time.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Frontotemporal dementia (FTD) is a leading cause of dementia and one of the most common causes of early- onset dementia. Diverse molecular pathologies cause FTD (collectively known as frontotemporal lobar degeneration [FTLD] pathology), which has complicated the development of positron emission tomography (PET) tracers for these diseases. This project will evaluate and validate new PET tracers, which could improve FTD/FTLD diagnosis and differential diagnosis and facilitate drug development for these diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative: We carried out the largest prospective study of laser ablation and traditional open resection (OR) epilepsy surgery techniques using neuropsychological testing and neuroimaging completed at pre- and 1-year post- surgical time points (N=425+), and will now assess moderate term (5-10 year) outcome for all subjects with regards to seizure freedom, and cognitive and functional recovery (i.e., changes in ability to work, live independently). Preliminary data lead us to predict far better longitudinal cognitive and functional recovery for laser ablation patients, and has led us to question the validity of existing models of the brain regions involved in verbal memory and language. We will use advanced neuroimaging techniques to guide surgical practice (i.e., extent and location of ablation/resection) and outcome prediction at the level of the individual patient, while improving our knowledge of the neural circuits underlying cognition.

PHR: Project Narrative Ocular and visual health are critical to independence and maintenance of quality of life. This grant seeks to train the next generation of vision scientists conducting both basic and clinically translational work to develop treatments for sight-threatening conditions. The interdisciplinary faculty from the vision science graduate program housed within the College of Optometry at The Ohio State University provide a diverse portfolio of research expertise to develop future leaders in vision research.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative - A Global Syphilis Vaccine Targeting Outer Membrane Proteins of Treponema pallidum The scientific premise of this CRC proposal derives from three decades studying the composition and ultrastructure of the outer membrane of Treponema pallidum subsp. pallidum, the syphilis spirochete. The central hypothesis of the proposal is that T. pallidum’s repertoire of outer membrane proteins are the best targets for syphilis vaccine development and that vaccines based on this premise can be produced at the scale needed for a phase 1 clinical trial.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE We aim to create a special mouse strain that will help us understand the functions of immune cells called ILC3s, which are important for defending the body against microbes and in maintaining tissue health. By using a cutting- edge gene-editing technique called CRISPR, we will develop a mouse strain that produces a genome engineering protein, called Cre, only in mature ILC3s, allowing us to study unique ILC3 functions without interference from other similar immune cells. This breakthrough will open doors to explore the effects of ILC3s in various health and illness settings, such as infections, inflammatory bowel diseases, cancer, and autoimmunity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative  This project seeks to test the effectiveness and feasibility of delivering a brief digital intervention, designed to rehabilitate self-worth through classical conditioning exercises, as an adjunct to intravenous ketamine treatments delivered by embedded providers in real-world ketamine clinics. Ketamine, a fast-acting antidepressant, may rapidly prime the brain for helpful forms of learning, and we seek to deliver such learning efficiently, through portable, low-cost, digital techniques. This work could ultimately lead to the ability to treat depression more efficiently and effectively.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL LIBRARY OF MEDICINE
ORG_NAME: PENNSYLVANIA STATE UNIV HERSHEY MED CTR
PHR: Project Narrative Meta-analysis provides an invaluable tool to synthesize safety data from multiple clinical trials, offering a chance to comprehensively assess the risk of various adverse events including infrequent or even rare events. However, safety data pose unique statistical challenges, as adverse events vary in type and severity, are incompletely reported, and are influenced by a variety of clinical risk factors. To address a critical gap in analytical methods in this area, we propose to develop novel statistical strategies for combining safety data along with publicly available software implementations, providing useful tools to the scientific community to enable evidence-based evaluation of drug safety.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: This proposal requests funds to characterize the social and transmission networks of migrant workers in Greece to mitigate ongoing and future coronavirus epidemics among vulnerable populations in diverse contexts. We aim to better understand COVID-19 prevention, testing, treatment, vaccination, seroprevalence and immunogenicity in order to address facilitators and barriers to COVID-19 transmission mitigation. Critical to public health is improving COVID-19 prevention among these populations and their larger social networks.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Sleep disturbances in early adolescence are a major source of transdiagnostic mental health risk, including those associated with long-term morbidity and mortality including depression, substance use and suicide. The Pediatric Precision Sleep Network will identify clinically relevant sleep signatures that predispose youth to future mental health risks and develop predictive models that will inform screening and risk stratification based on these clinical signatures in primary care settings.

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
PHR: NARRATIVE The Cryo-EM Facility at the University of Colorado Anschutz School of Medicine is an essential institutional and regional cryo-EM resource. Since it was established in 2016, the facility has supported cutting-edge NIH- funded research from groups across the Medical School and beyond. The centerpiece of the facility is a 200kV Thermo Fisher Talos Arctica transmission electron microscope. The current direct electron detector on the Arctica is 6 years old, starting to become unreliable, and no longer able to generate the best quality data in an efficient and user-friendly manner. Upgrading the imaging system in the Arctica represents the most economical and efficient way to bring the instrument back to the cutting-edge of cryo-EM technology. The imaging upgrade will allow the CU Anschutz Cryo-EM Facility to generate higher quality cryo-EM data in a considerably more efficient way, resulting in major cost benefits, easier data collection, and access to large- scale 3D imaging approaches like cryo-electron tomography. The imaging upgrade will ensure that the facility continues to provide state-of-the-art cryo-EM services for years to come.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Early detection of cancer is challenging due to poor adherence to screening schedules and poor sensitivity of existing methods. Using novel techniques for non-invasive detection of cancer, we will sequence epigenetic signatures found in the cell-free DNA found in the plasma fraction of blood. Using a combination of cell-free DNA from patients with a cancer diagnosis and pre-diagnostic plasma from the PLCO Screening Trial, we will determine the overall benefit of our new technology.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because understanding the dynamics and mechanism of how regulatory T cells use dopamine to control their function is informative for understanding a variety of immune-related disorders and even neurodegeneration. Understanding how immune cell-derived dopamine changes with age and how these changes influence signaling at neuron-immune synapses is not well understood and this proposal seeks to address this fundamental gap. Thus, this proposal is relevant to part of the NIH’s mission that pertains to fostering fundamental creative discoveries and innovative research strategies as a basis for protecting and improving health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative: Decreased coronary microvascular function is a recognized contributor to the development of chronic heart failure; mitochondrial DNA damage is thought to be a key component that uncouples cardiac demand from blood flow and Restoration of mitochondrial integrity is sufficient to restore physiological heart function. However, The effect of systemic anti-cancer therapy on human coronary microvascular function has not been evaluated and we hypothesize that anti-cancer therapy mitochondrial DNA damage promotes mitochondrial dysfunction (including elevated free radical production and release of mitochondrial DNA fragments) which augments therapy-induced microvascular dysfunction.  The overall goal of this application is to determine the role of telomerase, specifically in the mitochondria, in maintaining coronary vasodilation during external insult by chemotherapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research addresses whether living near the coast during red tide events (caused by the algae K. brevis, which frequently grows out of control in the Gulf of Mexico and produces natural toxins) triggers emergency hospital visits among children. As the first ever epidemiologic study of residential brevetoxin exposures among children, this work will quantify short-term associations with emergency encounters overall and by discharge diagnoses. Such knowledge will be useful for characterizing the health effects of brevetoxin exposures among children, who are expected to be a sensitive population, and for improving public health guidance aimed at reducing the negative human health impacts of red tides.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE A fraction of the variation in lifespan is attributable to genetic differences among individuals, yet genomewide studies in humans have largely failed to identify specific genetic variants affecting longevity. Experimentally- flexible model systems offer a complementary avenue to study aging, but while work in fruit flies has been successful in addressing many questions about the control of lifespan, studies seeking to identify lifespan genes in flies have been underpowered. Here, we will deploy a novel strategy to compare cohorts of extremely old animals to control flies, enabling powerful detection and localization of the genetic factors that determine lifespan, and those that impact the response to a lifespan-extending intervention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative This project will develop a new simpler tool for conditional modification of proteins and RNA in mice called SpliceTag. Our work will allow researchers to extract proteins, organelles, and RNA from a single cell type in the context of complex tissues and organs that comprise multitudes of different cells. We expect that SpliceTag will not only forward our research in blinding disease, but its simplicity and utility will find a broad application.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project narrative Mounting evidence from recent research, encompassing a variety of cancer types, points to links between biology of the disease and the patient's ancestral genetic background. It is the goal of this project to facilitate large-scale data-driven investigation in this important area via methods to learn a patient's genetic ancestry from tumor-derived molecular data, without the need to genotype the patient's cancer-free DNA or to know the patient's ethnic self-identification. Anticipated successful completion of the project will make hundreds of thousands of DNA and RNA profiles of tumors, from genomic data repositories, and millions of tumor specimens in biobanks, most with no matching normal genotype and no racial/ethnic annotation, available for ancestry- oriented cancer research.
