IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE - OVERALL The overarching scientific theme of the Wisconsin Alzheimer’s Disease Research center (ADRC) is preclinical, multimodal biomarkers of Alzheimer’s disease (AD) and their role in predicting transition from presymptomatic to clincial stages of the disease. There is convincing evidence that AD pathology starts several decades before the onset of symptoms, and discovery of biomarkers that represent asymptomatic stages of the disease will lead to early diagnosis and effective treatments and prevention strategies for the disease. Identifying asymptomatic at risk individuals during preclinical stages of AD will allow initiation of therapies that will either slow or, preferably stop the progression of the disease. Breakthrough research conducted at the Wisconsin ADRC has made seminal contributions to the field of AD research and has the potential to eventually find a cure for AD. This will have a great impact on patients and their families and will reduce the enormous societal costs and burden associated with this devastating disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Enteric infections by helminths that trigger type-2 immune mediated intestinal inflammation remain a significant global health problem. In this study we generate new tools to investigate epithelial cell-intrinsic host responses to helminth-induced mucosal type-2 immunity. These findings may provide rational approaches to modulate mucosal type-2 inflammation to enteric parasitic infections in humans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative T-cell-based immunotherapies are providing new opportunities for personalized treatment of different types of cancer, but computational methods supporting these efforts are still missing key structural information. Our research aims at bridging this gap through the development of a new computational environment (HLA-Arena 2.0), which integrates new structural bioinformatics methods with existing ITCR resources. This will enable (i) structure-guided discovery of tumor-associated antigens, (ii) identiﬁcation of safer therapeutic T-cells for cancer immunotherapy, and (iii) the implementation of the ﬁrst database for T-cell off-target toxicity risk assessment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative The microbiome induces intestinal permeability and inflammation in metabolic syndrome. Identifying gut bacterial metabolites that damage intestinal integrity will illuminate how the microbiome affects host health. This will further allow development of therapeutics to alleviate microbiome-mediated disruption of intestinal homeostasis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL LIBRARY OF MEDICINE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project seeks to address the urgent need for improved methods in trial sequential analysis to enhance the reliability and timeliness of living evidence derived from systematic reviews and meta-analyses. By developing innovative approaches that accurately establish decision boundaries in early-stage cumulative meta-analyses, this project aims to overcome the limitations of existing methods for trial sequential analysis. The proposed methods will effectively handle between-study heterogeneity and reduce the risk of prematurely terminating living systematic reviews, ensuring robust utilization of trial sequential analysis in assessing living evidence and guiding decisions on the necessity of new randomized controlled trials.

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Traumatic injuries, fibrotic diseases, scarring, chronic inflammation, and aging impact multiple organ systems affect millions of people worldwide at great economic cost. We propose to develop multiple genetic technologies to genetically manipulate Acomys (Spiny mice), the only known mammalian species that with significant, systemic, regenerative non-fibrotic wound healing capacity as adults. These technologies will enable us to unlock the mechanisms driving mammalian regenerative healing programs to guide urgently needed new therapies for human regenerative medicine.

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
PHR: NARRATIVE The Albany Medical College (AMC) Imaging Core Facility requests funds for the purchase of an Olympus FVMPE-RS multiphoton microscope for intravital microscopy and large tissue samples and 3D model imaging. This instrument is configured to cover the main requirements of all major and minor users, while allowing for future upgrades and additions through institutional or individual investments. Through the acquisition of the Olympus FVMPE-RS multiphoton microscope, we will leverage the state-of-the-art animal facility at AMC to provide the needed access to multiphoton and intravital microscopy to NIH-supported investigators within AMC and at other research institutions in the Albany Capital District, fostering cross-institutional collaborations among NIH- supported investigators at these institutions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: Project Narrative Extracellular vesicles (EVs) are released from all cells and contain bioactive cargo that robustly alters signaling in the receiving cell. The ability to engineer EVs holds promise for the next generation of therapeutics, yet the methods to do so are underdeveloped. This proposal will utilize the endothelial cell’s ability to load extracellular material into EVs, to efficiently customize EV cargo for the treatment of disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE New classes of antibacterials are required to combat the spread of antimicrobial resistance (AMR). AMR is an underlying factor in ~5 million deaths worldwide each year and deaths due to resistant microbes are predicted to overtake cancer by 2050. Novel classes of antibacterials have the potential to combat AMR because existing resistance to these new agents is not predicted to be widespread.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: LOUISIANA STATE UNIV A&M COL BATON ROUGE
PHR: The central goal of this proposal is to develop a protein platform comprising two bacterial toxins targeting lung cancer cells that overexpress the glycan Sialyl Lewis X (SLeX), which correlates with cancer metastasis. One bacterial toxin binds SLeX and delivers the other bacterial toxin, a “killing” component, into cancer cells. The outcome of this study will provide a potential novel therapeutic approach against cancers overexpressing SLeX prone to metastasis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE For patients with inherited retinal degeneration who have lost most of their photoreceptor cells and no longer have useful vision, therapeutic autologous photoreceptor cell replacement is one of the most promising approaches currently being developed. While robust retinal differentiation protocols that enable production of clinical grade 3D retinal organoids exist, validated methods for reproducibly isolating transplantable photoreceptor cells are required. In this application, we propose experiments designed to support complete characterization of the retinal cell product following staged organoid dissociation and fabrication of a continuous flow organoid dissociation and microfluidic photoreceptor cell enrichment device to facilitate production of a highly pure clinical grade therapeutic.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Project Narrative This project will enhance basic genomic data from the 2014 wave of the Child Development Supplement to the Panel Study of Income Dynamics in a number of important ways. It will create new genomic measures, make them available to the research community free of charge, and promote their use through comprehensive documentation and outreach efforts. This project will allow researchers to use these new genomic measures to answer crucial scientific questions about how genetic propensity and social environment intervene to shape health, behavior, and well-being.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative  This project seeks to test the effectiveness and feasibility of delivering a brief digital intervention, designed to rehabilitate self-worth through classical conditioning exercises, as an adjunct to intravenous ketamine treatments delivered by embedded providers in real-world ketamine clinics. Ketamine, a fast-acting antidepressant, may rapidly prime the brain for helpful forms of learning, and we seek to deliver such learning efficiently, through portable, low-cost, digital techniques. This work could ultimately lead to the ability to treat depression more efficiently and effectively.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: Project Narrative The poor understanding of the impact of NPs-protein corona interactions on the biodistribution of NPs results in the inefficient delivery of NPs to target solid tumors. The objective of this proposal is to develop an artificial intelligence (AI)-assisted model to improve tumor delivery efficiency by considering the impact of NPs-protein corona interactions. This project is relevant to public health because the resulting models and the methods gained from the proposed research will help address the design of smart nanomedicine and improve cancer therapy with optimized nanomedicine.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Efforts to address the high burden of mental health conditions have been hindered by the lack of data to match patients to treatments, resulting in delayed or insufficient care and a growing public health burden. The proposed research study will establish baseline factors and track behavior and clinical markers among individuals as they enter and progress through mental health treatment. Ultimately, this study seeks to develop scalable treatment decision tools that can be readily adopted and hasten recovery for the millions of Americans suffering from mental health conditions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Engagement in daily activities is thought to be important for the maintenance of cognitive function and resilience to age-related pathology, however, despite the potential importance of engaging in activities, older adults actually report decreased participation in activities in daily life. This project will provide critical and detailed information regarding the behavioral and neurobiological mechanisms of daily life activity participation in older adults and its relationship to Alzheimer’s disease pathology. Such information has clear relevance for public health, by improving understanding of how and why aging might lead to changes in activity participation, and in developing appropriate interventions to address such changes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Pancreatic cystic lesions (PCLs) are incidentally identified on abdominal imaging studies in more than a million patients annually in the U.S. and they represent an opportunity for early detection of pancreatic adenocarcinoma. Most patients with PCLs have “indeterminate” cysts in which both the type and histologic grade are clinically and radiographically uncertain, and current diagnostic tests are inadequate and require large cyst fluid volumes that are often unavailable. We propose to evaluate our novel micro-volumetric two-tier classifier that can improve diagnostic accuracy of current cyst fluid tests, as well as to use novel tools including mPower, a radiology report search engine, to improve capture of patients with “missed” PCLs and, thereby, expand racial and ethnic diversity in our electronic Panc Cyst Registry.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: NARRATIVE Synapses–the connections between neurons–are the building blocks of the brain, enabling its ability to execute so many complex thoughts and behaviors. Measuring synapses in the primate brain has been especially challenging, because of the brain’s enormous size, and relative inaccessibility. This project will develop technology to meet this critical need, providing foundational tools for uncovering the circuitry of the primate brain.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Among patients being evaluated for heart transplantation or left ventricular assist devices, inadequate duration of caregiving is the most common perceived contraindication to candidacy, and caregiving duration requirements are highly variable across U.S. advanced heart failure centers. This grant proposal uses the PRISM implementation science framework and implementation mapping to conduct critical pre-implementation work that will (1) assess best practices and organizational processes needed to decrease caregiving requirements using a positive deviance approach and (2) adapt interventions that will allow centers to shorten caregiving requirements while simultaneously limiting clinical staff burden and maintaining optimal clinical outcomes. Results of this proposal will inform a future R01 type 1 hybrid effectiveness-implementation trial aimed at: (1) testing non-inferiority of shorter duration caregiving at centers that currently require 3+ months and (2) creating an evidence base defining associations between caregiving and outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Clear race-based disparities exist with regard to incidence of esophageal cancer in the US; however, the biological underpinnings that support these racial disparities remain unknown. We will utilize single cell RNA Sequencing to assess, for the first time, the influence of race upon cellular and molecular heterogeneity in normal esophageal epithelium as well as epithelium from patients diagnosed with esophageal cancer. These results have profound implications for our understanding of the established disparities in esophageal cancer and help to inform novel approaches that will improve care for all patients with esophageal cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Despite considerable investments in treatment development for psychological conditions, response rates for most interventions are quite modest (30-40%). Given the limitations of our current psychological intervention system, the overarching goal of the proposed study is to provide initial evidence that targeting a limited number of high-order, personality-based dimensions represents a more potent, parsimonious, and personalized approach to mental healthcare.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
ORG_NAME: STATE UNIVERSITY OF NEW YORK AT ALBANY
PHR: Project Narrative  The proposed study will investigate the effects of Uniform Accident and Sickness Policy Provision Law (UPPL) on alcohol consumption and alcohol consumption related outcomes. The results from this study will provide policy makers with new, important information about the effectiveness of UPPLs and contribute to the recent policy discussion on whether these laws should be repealed.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The neuroimaging community faces numerous challenges in data collection, preprocessing, estimation of brain connectivity, and analyses of relationships between brain connectivity and behavior. An ever-expanding community of researchers are employing optical methods based on functional near infrared spectroscopy and diffuse optical tomography in order to infer pathophysiological state of tissue, such as inflammation and metabolism for detection/characterization of disease or cerebral hemodynamics for understanding human brain health, development, and aging. We propose to broadly disseminate and extend intuitive, validated, powerful cloud-based resources for optical brain mapping that facilitate efficient, accurate, and standardized processing that will harmonize the emerging set of optical measurement strategies within the growing ecosystem of network level analyses used throughout the greater brain mapping community.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Many of the drugs we use are derived from microbial compounds known as nonribosomal peptides, which are produced by modular assembly-line proteins. While these assembly-lines can evolve in nature and enable microbes to make new drug-like chemicals, we haven’t been able to effectively replicate this process in the lab. In this proposal, we will establish a plug-and-play platform to evolve and engineer modules within assembly- lines, allowing us to program the production of new molecules in living bacteria that could be used as probiotic therapies or producers of new drugs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Sexual minority (SM; e.g., gay, lesbian, bisexual, pansexual, queer, non-heterosexual) individuals are one of the highest-risk groups for developing eating disorders; however, no specific eating disorder treatments for SM individuals exist. Addressing distinct SM identity-related stress processes that maintain eating disorder symptoms in SM individuals could help address this disparity; however, these SM stress processes are not targeted in existing eating disorder treatments. The current study will address this critical gap by refining and testing an innovative virtual treatment that integrates evidence-based care for eating disorders with SM- affirmative care, designed to target mechanisms that underlie increased risk for eating disorders in SM individuals.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Recruiting diverse study samples into clinical trials is imperative to finding solutions to lessen health disparities. This project will evaluate participants’ preferences for specific trial attributes under investigators’ control, which could be leveraged to increase clinical trial participation rates in underrepresented groups. This project will produce generalizable information to help researchers prioritize clinical trial features that are maximally appealing to diverse study participants.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Behavioral interventions at home and school, as well as the communication between home and school, are critical in shaping the mental health outcomes of children with or at-risk for Attention Deficit/Hyperactivity Disorder (ADHD), a prevalent and impairing mental health condition, but caregivers and teachers need implementation supports to use behavioral interventions with fidelity. Using a community participatory approach, we will develop implementation strategies for caregivers to support their use of behavioral interventions as early intervention for children with or at-risk for ADHD, and pilot test them alongside existing teacher-facing Coordinated caregiver-facing and teacher-facing implementation strategies, disseminated through schools, have the potential to promote healthy outcomes for children with ADHD on a large scale.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We propose secondary data analysis of thousands of conjunctival photographs that have been collected and graded for trachoma as part of several previous NIH-funded studies. We will explore the best methods for using conjunctival photography in trachoma monitoring, especially with regards to defining the gold standard photo-grade, aggregating grades from multiple graders, and using more granular trachoma grading systems.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Myocarditis, a serious inflammatory reaction in the heart causing cardiac death, can occur as a result of immune checkpoint inhibitor therapy. Immune checkpoint inhibitors (ICIs) are a novel class of cancer therapeutics that release the brakes on T-cell cytotoxicity against tumor cells, but may also lead to fulminant myocarditis. This project aims to define a pathway by which macrophages mediate T-cell trafficking to the heart, thus paving the way to prevention and cure of this serious side effect of ICIs and helping ensure cardiovascular safety for cancer patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR COMPLEMENTARY & INTEGRATIVE HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative: With the improvement in cure rates of childhood cancer over the past 50 years to over 80% likelihood of survival, we now have an urgent public health problem that most children survive but endure debilitating symptoms and suffering during treatment. Many children are receiving complementary health interventions such as creative arts without strong evidence of the benefits. This research paves the way for rigorous study of a mind-body intervention with creative arts to improve the whole person health of children with cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE There is an unmet need to identify effective therapies for treating diseases associated with intestinal parasite Giardia lamblia. This organism causes considerable morbidity and mortality, especially among children. A unique set of chemically validated crude fungal extracts will be used to find novel chemical compounds/scaffold that can inhibit the growth of G. lamblia while providing an effective window of safety. Our overall goal is to discover new therapeutic lead compounds and apply them to the needs of people suffering from Giardia infections.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: OVERALL - NARRATIVE Development of more effective approaches to prevention, diagnosis, care, and therapy of Alzheimer’s disease and related dementias (ADRD) is critically needed in the face of an aging and increasingly diverse population. Advances in the field require targeted, more inclusive team-based research that addresses the needs of understudied populations, as well as complexities related to the heterogeneity of ADRD. The Shiley-Marcos Alzheimer’s Disease Research Center coordinates activities to foster this science, engage the research and broader communities, and educate an emerging and more diverse cadre of brilliant, creative investigators.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This proposal will establish scalable methods for linking neurons' molecular identities to synaptic inputs and outputs across the mammalian central nervous system. The molecular and connectivity information will be registered to a common atlas, allowing scale-up to the full brain. Once these methods have been developed, they have the potential to accelerate functional studies of neural circuits in a variety of species and brain areas, and disease states.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project narrative. Individuals with autism spectrum disorder (ASD) are more likely to have gastrointestinal dysfunction and inflammation and worsened gut symptoms co-occur with worsened behavioral and learning problems. The gut microbe Limosilactobacillus reuteri is observed in animal models and preliminary human trials to mitigate ASD and gut inflammation. This proposal aims to investigate the mechanism by which L. reuteri remediates these diseases and suggest a gut or microbial therapeutic for ASD and gut inflammation.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: The research proposed in this grant will have a significant impact because when successfully completed it will fill key gaps in our understanding of the basic mechanism of insulin secretion in healthy men and insulin deficiency and type 2 diabetes in a large segment of the aging and androgen-deficient male population of the Veterans Healthcare system. This information will provide the foundation for development of approaches to modulate the androgen receptor (AR) to prevent diabetes without prostate or cardiovascular side effects. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative This innovative multidisciplinary doctoral program trains researchers in Speech and Hearing sciences by combining broad exposure to relevant basic science and engineering disciplines, with rigorous expertise in at least one research area, and intense exposure to clinical practice. The program’s graduates are taking on leaderships roles in academia and industry where they work at the forefront of scientific discovery and develop novel assistive devices and therapies for those affected by disorders of hearing, voice, speech, language and balance. Some are combining research careers with clinical practice in otology, neurology, audiology or speech- language pathology.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: HARRY S. TRUMAN MEMORIAL VA HOSPITAL
PHR: Project Narrative: Relevance to Veterans Health Corneal fibrosis (scarring) is a leading cause of blindness in veterans, military personnel, and civilians. Globally, 23 million people have corneal opacity/fibrosis in one eye and 4.9 million people are blind in both eyes. At present, 2 million veterans have impaired vision, >167,000 veterans are legally blind, and >7000 veterans develop blindness each year. Currently, corneal transplantation is standard of care to restore vision and no-specific drug therapies exist to cure corneal fibrosis without side effects in humans. The project leads development to novel mechanism-based non-surgical treatments to control active wound healing and established corneal scar in vivo, advance translation of the first non-surgical therapy for preexisting corneal fibrosis towards human clinical trials and identify mechanisms, targets, and strategies to prevent/treat corneal blindness from open-field blast injury. Successful completion of project fulfills the mission of the Veterans Health Administration to achieve excellence in research and offer best health care to veterans.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: We are developing a visual prosthesis that can restore vision to the blind. The lateral geniculate nucleus (LGN) of the thalamus is an attractive site for implantation because it is spatially more expansive than the retina and thus enables higher acuity and a larger number of stimulation sites. At the same time, the neural signaling patterns used by LGN neurons are much less abstract than those of the visual cortex, thereby allowing for more straightforward encoding schemes with the prosthesis. While it has been challenging to develop a high- count, multi-channel device that can safely be implanted into a deep brain structure, our colleagues have recently developed such a device, and here we are studying how to effectively stimulate LGN neurons including how to optimize transmission to downstream cortical neurons. A functional LGN prosthesis is particularly attractive as it would be suitable for just about all blind patients, including returning battlefield soldiers and others who have suffered traumatic eye loss.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative  The goal of this program is to enable remote C-H functionalizations by catalytic, radical mechanisms that are not possible by other methods. This strategy will facilitate rapid conversion of simple feedstock chemicals (alcohols, amines) to medicinally relevant, nitrogen-rich molecules (α-amino acids, β-amino alcohols, aza- heterocycles). Towards this end, the key enabling tactic of regioselective 1,5-hydrogen atom transfer (HAT) will be (1) rendered asymmetric and (2) intercepted by novel mechanisms – to yield unique reactivity and selectivity and streamline access to complex, biologically relevant molecules.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Relevance to Public Health This randomized controlled trial will test whether a recently developed community-based intergenerational mentoring program known as Generation Exchange (GenX) can enhance antiviral resistance in a COVID- vulnerable population of older African-American women and men in a low-SES urban community. Additional studies will identify the biological processes that promote resistance to respiratory virus infections and viral disease in older African-American women and men.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: NARRATIVE Alcohol misuse exacerbates cognitive aging and increases the risk of Alzheimer’s disease and related dementia. Aging and chronic alcohol consumption both influence noradrenergic circuit functions. We combine brain imaging and longitudinal clinical assessment to investigate the noradrenergic mechanisms that underlie the effects of alcohol misuse on cognitive aging and the development of Alzheimer’s disease and related dementia.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative The learning and un-learning of a fear response through conditioning and extinction learning is a process that is of interest not only for basic neuroscience research, but also for clinical intervention and diagnostic procedures in a variety of psychiatric disorders. In the present proposal, building on strong preliminary data that suggest a pivotal role of visual and attention systems, along with limbic structures, in aversive learning, we seek to use simultaneous EEG-fMRI, combined with computational modeling and advanced analytical techniques including machine learning, to characterize—in time and space—the dynamics and communication within and among the brain’s visual, attention and limbic networks during the acquisition and extinction of conditioned fear in healthy populations. Furthermore, testing of the proposed computational model on a community sample stratified by their cardiac reactivity to threat will advance our understanding of the model’s capability to differentiate individual differences in threat response, and lay the foundation for identifying new biomarkers and treatment targets for disorders of fear, anxiety, and post-traumatic stress.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Type 1 diabetes (T1D) is a chronic autoimmune disease characterized by the T cell-mediated destruction of insulin-producing pancreatic b cells. CD8 T cells, with the help of CD4 T cells, are required for this destruction, however, the cellular mechanisms mediating this process remain incompletely understood. Therefore, the goal of this fellowship is to characterize a possible mechanism that may provide new therapeutic targets for the prevention and treatment of T1D.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative There is a longstanding gap of knowledge in the developmental role of the renal interstitium. Our proposed studies aim to understand how renal interstitial cell pattern is established and the function of this pattern. The proposed research will greatly enhance our capability to generate functional and mature nephron tubules for potential cell replacement therapy

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative A poor understanding of the vascular etiology of Alzheimer’s disease and related dementias has hindered progress toward treatments and preventive strategies in older adults. Cardiac autonomic dysfunction, indexed by lower heart rate variability (HRV) or higher QT interval variability (QTV), may be associated with worse cognitive performance and incident dementia, yet most studies of HRV and QTV are limited by their short-term duration or imprecise computation that does not accurately capture autonomic function in real-world settings. The goal of this K01 Mentored Career Development Award is to obtain training in computing novel measures of extra long-term (14-day duration) ambulatory HRV and QTV that better represent autonomic function using an innovative signal processing method, and initiate a mentored research project to determine their association with cognitive performance and dementia risk in a large cohort of older US adults.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: The purpose of this proposal is to provide training in professional skills to a diverse group of PhD students in cellular, biochemical and molecular biology research that will enhance their ability to develop into independent scientists with careers in biomedical research-related fields. In addition to rigorous training in cellular and molecular-based scientific disciplines, the students will be involved in experiential learning in scientific communication, networking and mentoring, and career development. The goal is to prepare these trainees to become leaders in the scientific workforce in a supportive, safe, inclusive and academically rigorous environment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: VIRGINIA POLYTECHNIC INST AND ST UNIV
PHR: Project Narrative Three-dimensional (3D) bioprinting has shown tremendous potential in constructing customized tissue models and implantable tissues. However, existing 3D bioprinters are incapable of printing biomimetic tissues with the resolution, complexity, and functions as native tissues. The proposed research will develop an acoustics-based 3D bioprinting technology, which overcomes these obstacles and enables biocompatible, fast, and scalable printing of functional biomimetic tissues with high resolution and complex features such as controlled anisotropic properties, high cell densities, and biomimetic cellular architectures.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Drug resistance is a major impediment to the successful treatment of infectious disease and cancer. Although genetic mechanisms of drug resistance have been widely studied, non-genetic mechanisms may explain the extraordinary speed and frequency with which many medications can be rendered ineffective. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Aging women are at an increased risk for cardiovascular disease, which is the number-one killer of women in the US and women who enter menopause prematurely have a 50% increased risk of cardiovascular disease compared with women who enter menopause at a typical age. The proposed research aims to determine mechanisms that contribute to autonomic and blood pressure dysregulation in younger and older premature- and early-menopausal women, providing fundamental knowledge of the causes of hypertension and cardiovascular diseases in these women. Results from this study will inform future studies on prevention and treatment strategies to improve cardiovascular health in aging women.

PHR: The overall goal of this predoctoral program is to offer exceptional interdisciplinary training in Molecular and Cellular Biology and Genetics with a concentration in cell signaling, epigenetics and genome maintenance. This program will provide a broad understanding of disease mechanisms and is aimed at developing in the trainees an in-depth understanding of the clinical challenges associated with their research interest area. Beyond scientific and state-of-the- art technical knowledge and translational research competencies, our goal is to develop in these trainees critical thinking and rigor, managerial, teaching and training skills, communication proficiency and a capacity for professional networking.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Retroviruses are major causes of disease in animals and humans that replicate by reverse transcribing viral RNA into DNA. The initial immune response to retroviral infection is critical to the ability to clear infection, because once the viral DNA integrates into the host chromosomes, persistent infections arise, leading to diseases such as cancer and immunodeficiencies. Here we will examine the timing and location of virus replication and host response, using unique cell culture and mouse models developed by our lab.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative We propose to study the impacts of socioeconomic, behavioral, and psychosocial impacts of COVID-19 pandemic and mitigation on adolescent girls in rural Kenya. We will examine these factors in relation to biological measures of stress, and how this relates to vaginal microbiome composition, Bacterial vaginosis, sexually transmitted infections, and HIV. This proposal advances global health and adolescent health, as the knowledge gained will support future policy and guidelines on school closures and the types of support adolescent girls need in the wake of similar future catastrophe.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The eye lens is a transparent organ responsible for fine focusing of light onto the retina. Two common age- related lens pathologies are: 1) cataracts, defined as any opacity in the lens, a leading cause of blindness worldwide and 2) presbyopia, a reduction in the lens' ability to change shape during focusing, which is linked to age-dependent increases in lens stiffness. This project will use a multiscale integrative approach to determine the fundamental mechanisms by which molecular regulation of actin filament networks controls nanoscale membrane structures and microscale cellular shapes and deformability, to establish macroscale biomechanical properties and transparency in genetic (mouse) and physiological (primate) models for the human lens.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Mental health depends critically on the capacity to simulate structural relationships in the environment. Surprisingly however, little is known about the underlying brain mechanisms of mental simulation. Our work aims to deepen our understanding of the computational principles and neural mechanisms of mental simulation. This knowledge would benefit the future development of rational diagnostics and therapeutics for mental health problems related to inference, prediction, and planning.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The modification of proteins with the addition of a lipid group, S-acylation, is a tightly regulated, dynamic process with profound effects on many biological processes. The study of S-acylation using traditional experimental approaches, however, has proven technically challenging. This research program will build upon and further innovate chemical biology technologies to study the enzymes that install and remove this protein modification to ultimately define their role(s) in pathophysiologically-relevant contexts.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative: Alzheimer’s disease (AD) and related dementia syndromes (ADRD) represent an enormous challenge for patients, families, caregivers, and health care systems. Due to availability, cost, contraindications, and a number of other factors, currently available clinical diagnostic tools leave many people presenting with mild memory loss (and their families) with substantial uncertainty regarding their risk and likely rate of progression moving forward. In this project, we assess whether novel blood-based biomarkers of ADRD can be used to improve diagnosis and predict prospective rates of cognitive decline and thereby serve as powerful clinical and research tools.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Up to 20% of women Veterans (WV) using VHA primary care experience past-year intimate partner violence (IPV), which contributes to numerous physical and mental health conditions, including suicidality. Despite national recommendations to screen WVs for IPV, there is low adoption of IPV screening programs in primary care. In response, VHA is spreading IPV screening programs in Women’s Health Model 1 and Model 2 primary care clinics, where the majority of WV VHA primary care patients receive care. The systematic and effective implementation of IPV screening programs within primary care clinics is expected to enhance care for WVs as well as improve access to, and timeliness of, IPV-related care. Given the high prevalence of IPV among WVs and its significant negative health effects, successful implementation of IPV screening programs is expected to reduce morbidity among WV VHA patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Although most children with cancer are cured long-term, 10-15% of children will ultimately develop advanced, incurable illness, rendering cancer the leading cause of non-accidental death in children. The proposed research will help develop family-centered measures of high quality end-of-life care and test novel methods of evaluating quality.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE The development and function of the hematopoietic system require precisely regulated gene expression programs orchestrated by noncoding regulatory DNA sequences such as transcriptional enhancers. This project aims to fill a critical gap by developing new approaches to dissect the molecular composition of tissue- specific enhancers in native chromatin during erythroid differentiation and hematopoiesis. Given that noncoding regulatory elements are frequently targeted by disease-associated genetic variations, these studies may provide new strategies for developing mechanism-based therapeutics for genetic or acquired blood disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Pancreatic β cells secrete insulin into the vasculature at specific locations called secretion hot spots, where various cytoskeletal and mechanosensitive proteins localize and modulate secretion levels. Since the mechanisms of this regulation are to a large extend elusive, I propose to determine details of organization of the cytoskeletal networks at hot spots and test if their molecular interplay regulates insulin secretion toward the vasculature. Understanding these molecular mechanisms may have high impact by providing potential targets for restoring normal glucose-stimulated insulin secretion in type 2 diabetes.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: MICHAEL E DEBAKEY VA MEDICAL CENTER
PHR: Chronic kidney disease (CKD) is a major public health problem, afflicting an estimated 37 millions of US adults and among Veterans, the prevalence of CKD is nearly 50% higher than that of the US general population. CKD is associated with maladaptive cardiac remodeling resulting from impairments in insulin/insulin like growth factor-1 receptor (IGF1R) signaling. We have identified a novel mechanism: signal regulatory protein alpha (SIRPα) that interferes with myocardial insulin/IGF-1 receptor functions resulting in CKD-induced cardiomyopathy. This discovery will stimulate novel targets for therapies to prevent CKD-associated heart failure.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Alzheimer’s Disease is a currently incurable brain disease. Brain entropy is an important trait of brain function and may provide critical information for unveiling neuromechanisms of complex disorders like AD. Using large existing data, this project will examine brain entropy change in AD and to assess brain entropy as a potential biomarker for AD. Given our aging population and the increasing prevalence of AD, performing this project is likely to have significant public health impact.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: My laboratory is studying the signaling pathways that may be responsible for the development of primary open angle glaucoma (POAG). POAG is an age-related, chronic optic neuropathy that results in irreversible blindness. A major cause of POAG is the increase in the expression of TGFβ2. The goal of this grant is to study how the coordinated activities of the Calcineurin/NFATc1 and αvβ3 integrin pathways can drive the expression of TGFβ2 by creating a positive feedback loop.

PHR: Narrative The International Agency for the Prevention of Blindness’s Vision Atlas reports that as of 2021 there are 43 million people living with blindness and 295 million people who have moderate to severe vision impairment. In the US there are 12 million people with visual impairment, including one million people who are blind. The Training Program in the Molecular Bases of Eye Diseases has as its goal to train scientists who will use a wide range of disciplines to elucidate the causes of visual impairment and blinding diseases with the aim of developing methods for earlier diagnosis, more effective treatments, means for prevention and eventually to develop cures.

PHR: Narrative Individuals can be predisposed to specific cancers, such as blood cancers, by inherited variation. In this grant, we will study the pressures that arise from these inherited risk variants that promote blood cancer emergence.

PHR: Project narrative In our screens to identify an adjuvant that can promote dose sparing and prolong duration of protection with an attenuated malaria vaccine, a novel glycolipid, 7DW8-5 that binds CD1d, and stimulates iNKT cells, was the only agent over several TLR ligands tested, to demonstrate significant enhancement in a mouse malaria model. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative: We propose to conduct a first-in-human clinical trial of BDNF gene therapy in Alzheimer’s disease. BDNF (“Brain Derived Neurotrophic Factor”) builds new synapses in the brain, prevents cell death and stimulates neuronal function. It offers the potential to slow or even reverse cognitive decline in Alzheimer’s disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Depression in older adults is characterized by poor motivation, cognitive deficits, and mobility impairment. Dopamine is a key neurochemical basis underlying all of these processes, but its precise contributions to the deficits seen in late-life depression are poorly understood. This study will comprehensively characterize dopaminergic dysfunction in Late-Life Depression and determine the degree to which it responds to pharmacologic modulation with levodopa.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Antibodies specific for pathogenic threats can provide immediate protection from infectious disease but longevity of an antibody responses after vaccination or infection can be highly variable. The proposed research is relevant to public health because it will illuminate factors that influence antibody durability of immune responses. This is expected to have a substantial impact as it will inform vaccine design for the current as well as future infectious threats.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Cutaneous T-cell lymphomas (CTCL) are a common form of skin cancer with highly variable clinical behavior and without robust tests that can be used for unequivocal diagnosis or predict who will have aggressive disease or response to therapy. Sézary Syndrome is an aggressive form of CTCL with poor outcomes, and our laboratory recently developed a strategy to identify histone post-translational marks that will offer a robust strategy for provide better diagnostic tools and predict response to histone deacetylase inhibitors. The studies in this proposal will lead to development of simple blood-based assays that will improve early detection and predict response to therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed project is relevant to public health because it represents novel and clinically-relevant potential therapeutic strategy i.e., targeting TACC3, to inhibit tumor growth and metastasis in breast cancer patients with centrosome amplification, representing a highly aggressive patient subgroup with worse survival and a high risk of developing distant metastasis. Once TACC3 is established as a potent target pre-clinically using our novel inhibitor in state-of-the-art experimental models, there is potential for significant advance in the treatment of highly aggressive breast and potentially other tumors with centrosome amplification. Thus, the proposed project is relevant to the part of the NIH’s mission that pertains to reducing illness and disability.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Although the immune system has emerged as an effective therapeutic target to control tumor growth and metastasis of peripheral cancers, little is known about the immune response to breast cancer brain metastasis and why it ultimately fails to control CNS metastasis in breast cancer patients. We have utilized single-cell RNA-sequencing to find that microglia, the main immune cell populations of the CNS, display a dramatic and heterogeneous pro-inflammatory response to brain metastasis and are critical to suppress metastatic outgrowth in the CNS. In this study, we will determine the mechanisms underlying microglia-mediated metastasis suppression, by testing whether they are critical to recruit peripheral anti-tumor immunity and/or present antigen for local stimulation of T cell responses.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The goal of this project is to further development of a bioconjugate vaccine against Streptococcus agalactiae, commonly referred to as Group B Streptococcus (GBS). The key objectives of the Phase II project are to optimize vaccine production and purification processes, perform dose-escalation studies in mice to evaluate immunogenicity and functional antibody responses, and assess vaccine efficacy using an established neonatal pup survival model.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE We propose a randomized controlled trial to test a 4-session virtual health insurance navigation intervention that will increase knowledge about health insurance, reduce financial burden, and improve surveillance for recurrence among 300 young adult cancer survivors ages 26 to 39. We will combine self-reported survey data with electronic health records and claims data to examine the trial outcomes and efficacy. We will also conduct an economic evaluation using cost-effectiveness and budget impact analyses, to establish the sustainability of the intervention at improving outcomes of young adult survivors through increasing their health insurance knowledge and decreasing their financial burden.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Bladder cancer is one of the top ten most common cancers in the U.S., with 75% diagnosed with non-muscle invasive disease (NMIBC) and up to 70% of which experience recurrence, making it one of the most expensive cancers to treat per patient. Body composition, which is the amount of fat and muscle tissue, affects the inflammatory and immune environments, and thus can possibly influence treatment response and disease prognosis in NMIBC patients. In a prospective study of 1,472 NMIBC patients, we will conduct a comprehensive study of body composition, inflammation, and immunity to evaluate their impact on treatment and prognosis outcomes over eight years of follow-up.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Project Narrative Patients with T2D are at increased risk for greater morbidity and mortality due to bacterial pneumonia; therefore it is critical to understand how immune responses are altered due to obesity and T2D. We have identified that innate immune cells such as alveolar macrophages and neutrophils have inherent functional and recruitment defects during obesity. This project aims to understand these defects and how they contribute to increased disease during pneumonia caused by Pseudomonas aeruginosa, which will provide insight that may lead to advances in treatments for patients with T2D diagnosed with respiratory infections.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Epilepsy is a debilitating chronic disease that affects over 3 million people in the United States, many of whom have ongoing seizures despite optimized treatments. I propose to determine the mechanism and consequences of a dysfunctional neuronal circuit that I have identified in a genetic mouse model of epilepsy, using cutting-edge techniques for the manipulation and recording of defined neurons within the brain. This mentored career development award will fill gaps in my scientific and technical knowledge and skill set, preparing me for a career devoted to development of novel, mechanistic, circuit-based therapies in preclinical experimental models of epilepsy that can be translated to patient care.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Narrative/Public Health Relevance Statement  The splicing of genes is essential for normal cell function but can lead to many human diseases when performed incorrectly. The SRPKs are essential enzymes that play vital roles not only in splicing but also at the beginning of life where necessary changes in DNA are required upon fertilization of the egg. We will study the mechanisms that allow SRPKs to drive these essential biological functions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  There is a major national shortage of qualified clinician scientists able to conduct rigorous gastrointestinal clinical research that is projected to increase in the next decade. Clinician scientists are needed to address pivotal questions regarding the etiology, treatment, public health impact, and optimal models for delivery of care for gastrointestinal diseases such as functional bowel disorders, inflammatory bowel diseases, intestinal cancers, chronic liver disease, and pancreatitis. This training program addresses this shortage through the efforts of a distinguished, experienced, and committed program faculty.

PROJECT_TITLE: Clinical Epidemiology Training in Gastroenterology

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE As the U.S. population of adults over age 65 increases and grows more diverse, highly sensitive, objective and automated measurement of functional abilities is needed to identify older adults at risk for cognitive decline and to advance our understanding of mild functional difficulties and disability. This proposal evaluates the utility of the Virtual Kitchen Challenge, a novel, portable, non-immersive, virtual reality task developed for the assessment of everyday function and characterization of functional difficulties in older adults with a range of cognitive abilities, including people with mild cognitive impairment and dementia.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Disorders of hemochorial placentation are a significant health issue and lead to pregnancy complications for mother and fetus. Invasive trophoblast cells are responsible for many necessary adaptations that occur at the uterine-placental interface. Identification of genes that regulate the invasive trophoblast cell lineage can provide insights into the development of diagnostics and therapeutic interventions for pregnancy-related disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative: The proposed research is relevant to public health because racially/ethnically diverse young women diagnosed with breast cancer at age ≤ 50 years, particularly Black and Hispanic/Latina women, suffer disproportionately from breast cancer health disparities and are under-represented in cancer genetics research. The objective of this career development award is to conduct a mixed methods study to gain contextual understanding of the experiences of young breast cancer survivors with regards to hereditary breast and ovarian cancer (HBOC) syndrome genetic testing, modify an existing web-based decision aid to meet the needs of young women diagnosed with breast cancer (survivors), add content related to sharing genetic test results to family members, and to conduct a pilot randomized controlled trial to determine the effect of the adapted decision- aid on reducing decisional conflict, increasing HBOC genetic testing, and promoting family risk communication among racially/ethnically diverse women. Upon successful completion of the proposed project, we expect our contribution to be an elucidation of factors that impact completion of HBOC multigene panel testing among diverse young breast cancer patients in South Florida and efficacy of a behavioral intervention for increasing multigene panel testing, cancer risk- reduction, and family risk communication.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NURSING RESEARCH
PHR: Project Narrative Our project will estimate the impact of unprecedented pandemic era eviction-prevention policies on all cause- mortality, age-specific mortality, cause specific mortality, and racial and gender inequalities in these outcomes. We leverage: 1) a unique linkage between eviction filing data and mortality data to examine the impact of eviction on death rates during the pandemic 2) policy mapping data that comprehensively describes state and local eviction moratoria, data from the Treasury Department on the roll-out of emergency rental assistance, and a difference-and-difference framework to examine the impact of eviction prevention policies on county- level measures of mortality 3) qualitative data to examine lived experiences with these policies and pathways that connect them to mortality.

This is of particular relevance to Veterans of the U.S. Military in whom the prevalence of allergic rhinitis is approximately 30% and allergic asthma is approximately 3%. Thus, allergic diseases are an important cause of morbidity among Veterans. Our preliminary data reveals that prostaglandin (PG) I2 lymphocytes. PGI2 inhibi glycolysis and pathway analysis strongly suggests that this occurs by PGI2 signali ng critically regulates the metabolic program of CD4 Th2 restraining glutamine and glutamate metabolism. This is supported by our in vivo data that reveals that PGI2 signaling inhibits pro-inflammatory metabolic pathways and that this is the mechanism by which it restrains allergic inflammation in the lung. Our studies have important therapeutic implications as PGI2 and PGI2 analogs are approved by the Food and Drug Administration (FDA) for treatment of pulmonary hypertension, and therefore their use could be extended for the treatment of allergic airway diseases such as asthma. ted

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: This application proposes examining the efficacy and mechanism of family therapy compared to usual care for children between the ages of 6 and 12 who are diagnosed with Avoidant restrictive food intake disorder. Preliminary data suggests that family therapy is superior to usual care and that improvement in parental self-efficacy related to feeding their children is the mechanism of treatment. In addition, this study will attempt to identify specific patient groups who respond to family therapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Sepsis is a syndrome of critical illness defined as life-threatening organ dysfunction due to a dysregulated host response to infection and is a leading cause of global mortality. In sub-Saharan Africa, tuberculosis (TB) is a common driver of sepsis in people living with HIV and is associated with high mortality rates. Yet TB sepsis is difficult to identify clinically and microbiologically, so many patients with TB sepsis go untreated, or have delays in treatment. Therefore, we propose a randomized 2x2 factorial clinical trial to compare 28 day survival from sepsis between study participants who receive 1) empiric immediate initiation of anti-TB therapy plus standard care or diagnosis dependent anti-TB therapy plus standard care and 2) sepsis-specific dose anti-TB therapy plus standard care or conventional dose anti-TB therapy plus standard care. This clinical trial will deliver important knowledge about the optimal content, dosing, and timing of the antimicrobial regimen for adult sepsis in sub-Saharan Africa.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative There are currently no disease-modifying treatments that can halt or slow the progressive cognitive decline of Alzheimer’s disease (AD). We are developing a new, oral medication, ALZ-801, that inhibits soluble toxic amyloid oligomers, the upstream drivers of neurodegeneration. We intend to conduct a Phase 3 clinical trial in AD patients who carry two copies of the high-risk, apolipoprotein E4 gene, to test if the drug can improve cognition, reduce brain atrophy, and have positive effects on CSF and plasma biomarkers of neurodegeneration in AD. If successful, we will seek FDA approval so that APOE4/4 AD patients can benefit from this therapy.

PHR: Principal Investigator/Program Director (Last, First, Middle): Foronjy, Robert Francis HIV infection accelerates the development of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), which is a leading cause of morbidity and mortality in people living with HIV. This proposal will advance public health by determining how cigarette smoke and HIV virus promote airflow obstruction and airway remodeling in HIV by repressing HuR to alter the airway epithelial transcriptome. IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative: Overweight/obesity and sleep problems, including insomnia disorder, increase women’s risk of breast cancer and poor treatment outcomes. Behavioral weight loss and sleep interventions are effective for many patients; however, they have never been combined and examined in a large clinical trial to see if they result in better weight loss. We plan to combine cognitive behavioral treatment for insomnia with behavioral weight loss, delivered using video technology, to determine if treating insomnia prior to weight loss in breast cancer survivors is associated with better weight loss, sleep, dietary and physical activity changes compared to no sleep intervention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Lay Description of Work: Future advancements in our ability to fight infection, inflammatory diseases like arthritis, and cancer depends on advanced training of scientists in the relatively new field of “innate immunity.” Our Training Program, Signaling Pathways in Innate Immunity (SPII), provides predoctoral and postdoctoral trainees with the the analytical skills required to “connect the dots” and unravel complex molecular interactions that underlie our earliest immune responses to microbes and other noxious substances. Towards this goal, talented SPII trainees receive exceptional multidisciplinary academic support, research guidance, and mentoring from our dedicated faculty, as evidenced by the scientific successes of SPII trainees in its first ten years.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Nontuberculous mycobacterial (NTM) infections cause substantial morbidity and mortality, and rates of NTM infections acquired at healthcare facilities are increasing. The proposed studies will develop an advanced statistical strategy for NTM surveillance within a hospital network and utilize molecular sequencing of NTM isolates to improve understanding of healthcare facility NTM acquisition. This work will determine if the combination of advanced statistical surveillance and molecular sequencing can improve NTM surveillance and understanding of NTM acquisition, ultimately preventing NTM infections and reducing risk of harm to hospitalized patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE (General Audience, public health relevance, 2-3 sentences) This research addresses a specific unmet medical need, the absence of an effective medical therapy for acute lung injury (ALI), a common disorder in patients with bacterial pneumonia or SARS-CoV-2 infec- tion and its severe form, acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) that is fatal in 40% of patients. The work is broadly impactful because the white blood cells called neutrophils (Polymorphonuclear leuko- cytes, PMN) that damage the lungs in infectious ALI/ARDS also cause other acute and chronic inflam- matory diseases. In the last period, we showed that the human voltage-gated proton channel (hHv1) in PMN is essential to produce the inflammatory response, and we propose here to confront lung injury by a novel strategy: targeting hHv1 in PMN, both directly and by blocking a natural activator of hHv1, al- bumin (Alb), that we recently reported to be required for hHv1 operation, thereby offering two ways to confront the disease at the earliest stage before it becomes a more complex disorder.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Glioblastoma (GBM) is the most common primary brain tumor in adults and one of the most deadly cancers, with a median survival of only 12-15 months despite extensive treatment. This application aims to identify the important new role of clinically-relevant retinoic acids in regulating lipid metabolism and to unveil the underlying resistance mechanism of GBM to this therapy. Completion of this study will provide a new and very promising combination strategy to treat GBM by concurrently inhibiting lipid synthesis and oxidation using clinically available drugs, thereby building the foundation for further testing in GBM patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: NARRATIVE Interprofessional collaboration and workforce diversity are known to be important to care quality for older adults, but have not been well studied within aging research practice. This proposal investigates how to maximize diversity and interprofessional collaboration in aging research and will provide greater understanding of the aging research community’s needs and produce actionable insights to diversify and strengthen collaborations created. By providing experience in aging research, social network analysis, intervention development, and organizational behavior, the research plan is highly complementary to the career development of an independent aging researcher focused on developing interventions to promote interprofessional collaboration and improve the quality of aging research and care.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Ph+ and Ph1-like acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) cells rely on the expression of the cell cycle regulatory protein CDK6 for their proliferation and survival. The effects of CDK6 are, in part, kinase-independent. This proposal focuses on assessing the role of CDK6 through genetic and pharmacological interventions based on CDK4/6-targeted PROTACs that inhibit the enzymatic activity of CDK6 and promote its degradation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Narrative Malaria remains a devastating global health problem, although tremendous progress has been achieved in the past decade. Much of the progress can be attributed to effective use of drug treatments for Plasmodium falciparum, especially artemisinin (ART) combination therapies (ACTs); however, emerging resistance to ART (ART-R) and the ACT partner drugs threatens this progress. Our experimental approach is to elucidate drug-gene associations and decipher mechanisms of action and resistance to ART and other antimalarial drugs, using forward genetic screens of P. falciparum mutants created by random piggyBac mutagenesis.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Current treatment options for mucormycosis (commonly caused by Rhizopus delemar) are inadequate, and fail in 40% or more of infected patients. The fungus uses proteins and toxic substances to invade host cell tissues and cause disease. We propose to identify methods by which these proteins and toxic substances invade and kill host cells, so we can design better and more efficient therapeutic strategies to prevent or treat these lethal infections.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: An increasing number of people living with HIV use stimulants, such as Methamphetamine and Cocaine, but the cellular and molecular mechanisms by which stimulants interact with HIV and anti-retroviral therapy (ART) to drive neuroinflammation and promote neuronal dysfunction and neurocognitive impairment are poorly understood. We propose to resolve this knowledge gap by creating a consistent, translationally relevant, human cell-culture model of microglia and dopamine neurons that can release dopamine, enabling precise evaluation of the effects of both stimulants and stimulant-mediated dopamine release in the context of HIV and ART. Combining this system with our existing high-throughput assays, we will define the processes by which stimulants alter HIV infection and inflammation, identifying the genes, inflammatory pathways and receptors associated with these changes in both microglia and neurons and determining how these changes alter neuronal function and microglia-dopamine neuron communication.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Families with children who have identified deficits in speech and/or sensory or musculoskeletal impairments without a known cause may be referred for genetic testing to find out whether there is a genetic cause. However, there is little research into how parents and caregivers use this diagnosis to inform decisions about therapeutic services, access to school services, or how a genomic diagnosis informs the practice of the community professionals who provide these services. This project will examine how a genomic diagnosis shapes the care that children receive from community professionals, including physical and occupational therapists, speech-language pathologists, special education teachers, behavior analysts, and mental health providers.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCIENCE CENTER
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Uterine fibroids (UFs; leiomyomas) are the most important benign neoplastic threat to women’s health worldwide. Current treatment options are limited beyond surgery, and the development of more effective medical therapies will require a better understanding of the underlying molecular etiology of UFs. Accordingly, this proposal is impactful as it suggests a novel etiologic basis for UF development through pathological reprogramming of the myometrial epitranscriptome and further offers proof of concept for therapeutic intervention using epigenetic inhibitors of tumorigenic enhancer activity driven by m6A-chromatin crosstalk. The studies proposed herein thus address and mechanistically connect two overarching issues in the field: the emerging role of the dynamic epitranscriptome in UF pathogenesis and the development of novel targeted therapies for UFs.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Resistance to endocrine therapy is a leading cause of treatment failure and death in women with breast cancer. IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative (Public Health Relevance) Heart failure with preserved ejection fraction (HFpEF) is a highly morbid condition in which exercise capacity is significantly reduced. Our goal is to understand how functional iron deficiency relates to exercise capacity in HFpEF and in middle-aged adults at risk for HFpEF. We will then perform a trial to investigate how iron repletion influences mechanisms of exercise intolerance in patients with symptomatic HFpEF.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Persistent HIV replication in populations of macrophages and microglia in protected anatomical compartments like the brain is a central impediment to successfully curing HIV. This problem is heightened among vulnerable populations with substance use disorders, including misuse of therapeutics such as benzodiazepines which exacerbate neuroHIV. This proposal will address these issues by defining the transcriptional processes regulating HIV replication dynamics in myeloid cells and evaluating how epigenetic factors such as RUNX1 are involved in benzodiazepine mediated increases in transcription and replication.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Less than 2% of the human genome sequences are protein-coding genes, while more than 98% of the genome consists of non-coding regulatory DNA and RNA sequences which play an essential role in biology and human diseases. Targeted engineering the function and activity of non-coding regulatory genome could greatly expand the “druggable genome”, and holds great promise for gene-regulation based therapeutics and genomics medicine. Here, by taking advantage of our newly developed multi-omics approach, we seed to identify the regulators, which determine the activity of non-coding DNA and RNA sequences and can be utilized to modulating gene expression via engineering non-coding regulatory sequences.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Patients who survive acute critical illness but require prolonged mechanical ventilation (PMV, i.e. mechanical ventilation >14-21 days) are growing rapidly in number, have large post-acute care expenditures, and experience a grim 60% 1-year mortality. It is unclear how decisions made during the transition from acute respiratory failure to prolonged mechanical ventilation (e.g. use of LTCHs for post-acute care) impacts long- term outcomes. We will determine (1) trends and drivers of variation in post-acute facility use among patients at high risk for PMV and (2) the ways in which LTCH use may influence provider behavior at short stay hospitals and outcomes of patients at high risk for PMV, using quantitative/econometric and qualitative methods. The knowledge generated from this mixed methods approach will be critical to inform both clinical practice (i.e. by altering the way providers plan for and choose optimal sites of post-acute care) and future policy (i.e. by potentially shaping future payment reform and determining whether other sites of post-acute care, such as skilled nursing facilities, should be targets of quality reporting legislation).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF SOUTH CAROLINA AT COLUMBIA
PHR: Sarcopenia, defined as low muscle mass and function, affects up to 60% of individuals diagnosed with colorectal cancer and is associated with treatment complications, poor prognosis, and reduced overall and cancer-related survival. Currently, there have been no investigations into therapeutic strategies to ameliorate the burden of sarcopenia in cancer. The goal of this proposed study is to examine the feasibility and acceptability of creatine supplementation and resistance training in individuals who are sarcopenic after treatment for colorectal cancer and to measure outcomes related to body composition, physical function and quality of life.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: As preclinical Alzheimer's Disease (AD) becomes a more common target of intervention studies, there is an increased demand for cognitive assessments that are sensitive to very early cognitive change. This study will develop the mobile Cognitive App Performance Platform (mCAPP), with tasks based on current theories of cognitive neuroscience and focused on areas of domain-specific cognitive deficits known to be impacted early in AD. The mCAPP will be validated in a cohort of carefully characterized individuals with neuropsychological and neuroimaging biomarker data in order to leverage existing data and create a tool that has the potential to reduce study participation burden, gamify the experience to increase engagement, and provide an opportunity to collect cognitive data frequently and quickly for the purpose of cognitive screening and monitoring cognitive change during intervention trials in preclinical AD.

PHR: Project Narrative The intracellular bacterial pathogen Legionella pneumophila is an important cause of hospital- and community- acquired pneumonia. We propose to define novel mechanisms underlying how the innate immune system successfully overcomes the ability of Legionella to disarm alveolar macrophage function. Defining these mechanisms will enable the design of new anti-bacterial therapeutics that are effective against Legionella and other intracellular bacterial pathogens.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Narrative By harmonizing and freely disseminating current and historical time diary data from around the world, IPUMS Time Use enables rigorous and reproducible investigations of the implications of time use for health and well- being over time and space and among population subgroups. The data are critical for understanding the uneven consequences of public health crises (e.g., the COVID-19 pandemic, structural racism) and social determinants of children’s formative experiences, family processes, parenting, and quality of life. The expansions and enhancements proposed in this continuation will stimulate scientifically rigorous, policy-relevant research on population behavior, health, and well-being across the life course, over time, and across policy contexts.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: The reactivation of Plasmodium vivax dormant parasites is one of the major challenges to current malaria elimination efforts. We propose to implement a tightly-controlled field study in Cambodia, specifically designed to empower state-of-the-art genomic analyses, to rigorously study P. vivax relapses and the efficacy of primaquine radical cure. Our studies will provide a unique perspective on the mechanisms regulating these dormant parasites and will provide immediately-relevant clinical information to better eliminate this important human parasite.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Aging is associated with loss of lung structure, declining function, and increased susceptibility to lung disease, together termed senile emphysema. The goal of this proposal is to define mechanisms that result in loss of adult mesenchymal vascular progenitor and innate lymphoid progenitor cell function, contributing to accelerated lung aging and increased susceptibility to emphysema in the aged population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Despite accumulating evidence indicates that alpha-synuclein-based neurodegeneration develops first in the brainstem before affecting other brain areas, existing imaging methods are incapable of resolving details of tiny deep brainstem nuclei in living elderly humans. This limits our capability of diagnosing and treating early stage synucleinopathy patients (such as premotor Parkinson's disease) before they develop symptoms. The goal of this project is to fill this gap by generating an atlas of arousal and motor brainstem nuclei in living elderly healthy subjects by ultra-high field MRI. We will use the atlas as a tool to investigate brainstem-based biomarkers of premanifest synucleinopathy able to assess the integrity of brainstem microstructure and connectivity pathways before the development of full-blown neurodegeneration.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative Hearing loss is the most common sensory deficit in humans and causes severe disability in affected individuals. The goal of this project is to understand how sensory cells within the ear build a mechano-sensitive hair bundle to detect sound, as this process is commonly disrupted in genetic and acquired forms of hearing loss. We propose to study the molecules that build and maintain the hair bundle, and to understand how disruption to these processes cause hearing loss.
