PHR: BIDS-TP: Project Narrative The focus of the University of Michigan (UM) Biomedical Informatics and Data Science Training Program (BIDS-TP) is on developing a unique environment and an effective curriculum to train a cadre of data-savvy, computationally-skilled, and highly-motivated biomedical scholars. All BIDS-TP students will be trained in collecting, managing, processing, interrogating, and analyzing large amounts of complex high-dimensional biomedical information, as well as scientific rigor, validity, and reproducibility. BIDS-TP will increase the capacity, ability, and efficacy of the US workforce to address known and unexpected biomedical, health and environmental challenges using advanced bioinformatics and data science techniques.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative About 30 million Americans have diabetes, another 84 million have prediabetes, and nearly a quarter of health care expenditures are for diabetes and its complications. In addition to economic costs, metabolic diseases like diabetes cause enormous suffering due to heart disease, kidney failure, liver failure, strokes, amputations and many other health problems. This application is relevant to public health because of its overarching goal of training exceptional scientists capable of developing new strategies to decrease the burden of diabetes in the United States.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative: Several prior studies have shown the potential value of medication sampling to promote population-wide smoking cessation engagement, but whether these same benefits apply to varenicline, arguably the best single-agent cessation medication, is unclear. This randomized clinical trial will offer a test of varenicline sampling as a method to engage all smokers in the quitting process. Ultimately, the population impact of medication/varenicline sampling could be profound, offering a significant and measurable opportunity to lessen the impact of tobacco on public health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  There is a current and growing public health need for well-trained basic and clinician scientists, and physician scientists, to conduct research in otolaryngology and communication health to increase the science knowledge base and improve prevention, diagnosis, and treatment of disorders that decrease the lifespan and quality of life of men and women of all ages. This grant supports the continuation of Interdisciplinary Research Training in Otolaryngology and Communication Sciences, an integrated program based in the Department of Otolaryngology-Head and Neck Surgery at the Medical University of South Carolina. The goal is to provide mentored research opportunities in the disciplines related to otolaryngology and communication health, and the tools to become independent investigators and effective research team members whose work will increase understanding of mechanisms underlying these disorders and improve health outcomes.

PROJECT_TITLE: Interdisciplinary Research Training in Otolaryngology and Communication Sciences

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Narrative This proposal focuses on research and training that are directly relevant to hearing loss, speech and language disorders, and communication disorders in humans. This training program will prepare a cadre of scientists to address fundamental questions pertaining to hearing and communication neuroscience. These individuals will not only advance our understanding of biologic and behavioral bases of a broad spectrum of auditory-vocal communication disorders, but will also generate innovative diagnostic and therapeutic applications.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The prevalence of anxiety and depression are high among adolescents, but most ethnic minority adolescents in need do not access any MH care. The White House, the U.S. Surgeon General, the American Academy of Pediatrics, and the American Academy of Child and Adolescent Psychiatry, have all called for action to address the youth MH crisis and have highlighted accessible, effective school-based MH interventions for diverse students as a key strategy; research is needed to determine how to implement digital tools to improve mental health service access and outcomes for vulnerable youth served by school-based health centers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF MASSACHUSETTS MED SCH WORCESTER
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Worldwide, Neisseria gonorrhoeae (Ng) is one of the most common sexually transmitted bacterial diseases. These bacterial infections cause pelvic inflammatory disease that can lead to infertility, ectopic pregnancy and chronic pelvic pain and have been associated with increased transmission of HIV. We will examine how Ng manages to evade the immune system to enhance its ability to infect females by exploiting an estrogen- induced anti-viral protein called interferon epsilon.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: Project Narrative Food insecurity and social isolation are social risks that affect a wide variety of health outcomes, and commonly co-occur. To improve health and reduce health inequities, effective strategies to address food insecurity and social isolation are critically necessary, particularly among medically underserved populations with chronic conditions such as diabetes. If the proposed aims are achieved, a combination of group medical visits and produce prescriptions may prove a viable model for addressing social isolation and food insecurity in primary care settings.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative for The Development and Experimental Verification of Computational  Methods to Design Therapeutic Proteins  Binding proteins such as antibodies are among the most important tools in modern medicine, but they still have limitations. The proposed research will allow for the design of proteins with better properties that are less expensive to produce in far less time than current methods. This will allow doctors to respond to medical threats, whether they are cancer, a new antibiotic-resistant bacteria, or an emerging pandemic, in near real time, thereby saving the lives of individuals that current technologies cannot help.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT LAY NARRATIVE The incidence of dizziness increases from 22% for adults between the ages of 65 and 69 to over 40% between the ages of 80 and 84 years, and fall-related injuries are highly correlated with reports of dizziness, constituting the sixth leading cause of death in the elderly and associated with a 20% mortality rate. We will identify the genes and pathways involved in the vestibular portion of the balance system of humans and aged mice, compare the genomic composition of human and mouse vestibular tissues, then test the hypothesis that the genes and/or pathways identified are critical to balance function. Our team will combine resources with the expertise of a neurotologist, otolaryngologist/data scientist, computational biologists, and neurogeneticists to identify genes and pathways underlying imbalance, leading to targeted therapies for prevention and treatment of imbalance and falls in the elderly.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: A triumvirate of interacting regulatory elements co-exist on chromosome 3, which is commonly lost in human clear cell renal cell carcinoma, contributing to haploinsufficiency, with loss of heterozygosity driving disease progression. This study will explore the unique interplay between these factors (methylation writers, readers, and erasers) at the mitotic spindle that sets the stage for renal carcinogenesis. We further identify and define key nodes at which pharmacologic strategies provide the opportunity to explore therapeutic intervention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In eukaryotes, transcriptional regulation is essential to maintaining cell identity, responding to intra- and extra-cellular signals, and coordinating various cellular activities, whereas dysregulations in this process can cause a broad range of diseases. Parallel multi-omics single- cell sequencing now becomes a routine technique to reveal the transcriptional regulatory mechanisms at the finest resolution possible, but its computational modeling is still in its infancy due to its ultra-high dimensionality, complex feature interactions, and high vulnerabilities to numerous confounding factors. This research aims to develop a suite of interpretable deep learning models and open-source software to construct personalized regulome via flexible single- cell multiome integration, which will push our understanding of transcriptional regulation to a single cell resolution and allow direct prioritizations of key dysregulations associated with genetic disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This application focuses on improving diagnostic accuracy of developmental language disorder (DLD), a chronic developmental disorder occurring in 7% of the US population that negatively impacts children's long-term social, educational, and vocational outcomes. The proposed project will be the first to investigate DLD markers in Vietnamese bilingual and monolingual children. Outcomes include validated tools for accurate identification, which in turn will increase access to intervention to relieve the burden of the disorder for children who speak Vietnamese as a first language (spoken by 1.5 million in the US and 100 million worldwide).

PHR: Project Narrative Cryogenic Electron Microscopy (cryo-EM) has become a major technology to determine the structures of proteins, particularly large protein complexes and assemblies, but reconstructing protein structures from cryo-EM images data is still a time-consuming, labor-intensive, and inaccurate process. This project will develop deep learning methods to automatically and accurately build protein structures from cryo-EM images, which will be useful tools to advance structural biology and structure-based biomedical research and technology development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Therapeutic interventions, such as exposure therapy, reduce pathological fear in patients with anxiety disorders—but this fear reduction is often transient and vulnerable to relapse. The impermanence of extinction-based therapy is a major challenge to clinical interventions for a host of disorders, including anxiety and post-traumatic stress disorder. Therefore, the long-term goal of this project is to understand the neural substrates of extinction, particularly the specific brain circuits involved in the contextual retrieval of extinguished fear memories.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The Center for Leadership in Environmental Awareness and Research (CLEAR) proposes an integrated, transdisciplinary framework, rooted in advanced techniques in environmental engineering and biomedical research, to address human exposure routes and health risks from volatile organic compounds (VOCs) in urban areas. Research findings on (a) the relationship between VOC exposure and human health risks—for preterm birth and associated adverse health outcomes in particular—combined with (b) new methods and technologies to assess, communicate, and reduce those health risks, and (c) a new understanding of related biological systems, will contribute to improved public health interventions. CLEAR research is expected to have a direct impact on affected communities, stakeholders, and the agencies responsible for reduction of environmental VOC exposure and for Superfund site management.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Exposure to volatile organic compounds (VOCs) has, in recent years, been of increasing concern because of the heightened awareness of vapor intrusion into basements and resulting impacts on public health. Our ability to address this public health issue is limited by our ability to identify belowground VOC contamination in a spatially comprehensive and cost-efficient way. CLEAR’s (Center for Leadership in Environmental Awareness and Research) Project E1 provides proof-of-concept for using aboveground plant tissue to provide data identifying hot spots and sources of belowground VOCs that can be integrated into a geospatial GIS framework; metrics from our geospatial GIS framework and metrics of public health concern can be spatially correlated to focus remediation and/or mitigation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative – Project E2 Project Narrative The Center for Leadership in Environmental Awareness and Research (CLEAR) is dedicated to understanding and mitigating human exposures to volatile organic compounds (VOCs) and health risks in urban areas. Assessing and remediating VOC vapor intrusion (VI) is challenging due to the complexity and high cost of off- line sampling methods and conventional engineering remediation strategies. CLEAR Project E2 transforms the paradigm of VI assessment and remediation from conventional off-line methods to a new data-science driven approach and provides a first-of-its-kind platform with functionality ranging from real-time VI monitoring and data collection/analysis to data-based decision making and improved remediation outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative: This project will provide a better understanding of reproductive, developmental, immunological, neurobehavioral, and multigenerational health effects of a wide-range of individual VOCs and VOC mixtures in zebrafish, including combinations and concentrations of VOC contamination similar to those found in the homes and environments of our target population in Detroit, MI. CLEAR Project B1 will identify specific genetic and epigenetic biomarkers associated with each VOC exposure and their potential impacts on subsequent generations. Results will be utilized by the Community Engagement Core to aid the community, policy-makers, physicians, and other stakeholders to implement prevention and intervention measures to protect public health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The Center for Leadership in Environmental Awareness and Research (CLEAR) has built an integrated, transdisciplinary framework, rooted in advanced techniques in environmental engineering and biomedical research, to address human exposures to volatile organic compounds (VOCs) and health risks in urban areas. Research findings on (a) the relationship between VOC exposure and human health risks—for preterm birth and related health outcomes in particular—combined with (b) new methods and technologies to assess and reduce those health risks, and (c) a new understanding of related biological systems, will contribute to improved public health interventions. CLEAR research is expected to have a direct impact on affected communities, stakeholders, and the agencies responsible for Superfund site management and the reduction of environmental VOC exposure. Project B2 uses a mouse model to decipher the signaling pathways by which exposure to VOCs during pregnancy have an impact on early life growth and development with a particular focus on the developing fetal immune system.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Volatile organic compounds (VOCs) contaminate shallow soils and groundwater at Superfund, residential, commercial, and industrial properties, leading to exposures via vapor intrusion; available data suggests that VOCs are associated with higher risk for preterm birth (PTB). The Center for Leadership in Environmental Awareness and Research (CLEAR) is dedicated to understanding and mitigating this serious environmental health problem. CLEAR Project B3 will specifically address the impact of VOCs on PTB risk through an epidemiologic study of pregnant women in metropolitan Detroit; additionally, B3 will examine if VOCs are associated with altered maternal inflammation or placental function (DNA methylation, gene expression) and potential sources of VOC exposure, which may yield insights into interventions to prevent adverse pregnancy outcomes and/or areas to target for VOC remediation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: RESEARCH INST OF FOX CHASE CAN CTR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This proposal will test the ability of CBL0137 to induce Z-DNA formation in advanced and metastatic melanoma. This effect of CBL0137 as of a ‘virus mimetic’ is predicted to activate nuclear necroptosis via the ZBP1-RIPK3- MLKL signaling cascade in melanoma TME and synergize with immunotherapy. We will therefore clinically validate an entirely new concept for making immunologically cold tumors hot with a broader reach to immunotherapy-refractory human cancers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Autism spectrum disorder (ASD) is a clinically heterogeneous neurodevelopmental disorder that is associated with various gene mutations, including ASH1L (Absent, Small, or Homeotic discs 1-Like) gene that encodes a histone methyltransferase with its function in facilitating gene expression through epigenetic modification of chromatin. To understand the epigenetic mechanisms underlying ASH1L’s function in ASD pathogenesis, we will use an Ash1l-knockout-induced ASD mouse model to examine the function, transcriptome, and epigenome of cortical excitatory neurons, inhibitory neurons, and astrocytes in the mouse brain. The success of this project will not only largely advance our understanding of basic epigenetic mechanisms in autism pathogenesis, but also potentially lead to the development of new therapeutic approaches to treat ASD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative In collaboration with CLEAR’s other projects and cores, the CEC will facilitate bidirectional exchange of knowledge among CLEAR Center researchers, residents, local organizations, and other stakeholders in Detroit and the surrounding region. The CEC will advance the CLEAR mission through community engagement, outreach and education across Detroit, using a combination of traditional and innovative strategies to increase a broad understanding of the prevalence of VOCs in homes across the Detroit area and how to identify and reduce potential sources of VOCs in homes. The CEC will implement strategies to inform residents about VOCs hazards, while also providing referrals and resources to reduce VOC exposure.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative This proposal aims to extend the cellular, synaptic and circuit level understanding of circuit state modulation from studies of an individual hormone action on a single circuit state to the impact of a complete hormonal environment from a particular behavioral state on several different circuit states from the same defined connectome. We aim to address this issue by studying the fully-defined motor circuits in the isolated crab (Cancer borealis) stomatogastric ganglion, using a multi-disciplinary approach that combines electrophysiological manipulations of identified circuit neurons with mass spectroscopic identification of individual hormones and their biologically relevant concentrations. Insofar as the neural circuits in many, and perhaps all, animals are configured via neuromodulation into different circuit states, and no previous study appears to have addressed this issue at the level proposed herein, a positive outcome from the proposed experiments will contribute to fundamental knowledge about the nature and behavior of living systems.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: NARRATIVE: Substance use, especially in young and middle adulthood, is a major public health problem in the United States, costing more than 100,000 lives and $440 billion annually. This project aims to understand the role of local labor market structure in substance use behaviors and its socio-physical-behavioral health mechanisms, to develop agent-based models to make substance use/use disorder/overdose projections for Ohio through 2030, and to conduct policy experiments. Findings will inform policy interventions to prevent substance use problems, which is especially relevant for areas experiencing economic contractions or employment shocks following a pandemic.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Public Health Relevance. Klebsiella pneumoniae (Kpn) is a leading cause of hospital-acquired infections. Epidemiological studies show that the gastrointestinal is the main reservoir for Kpn, through which it can cause disease in the colonized host or transmit to another host. This project aims to define the factors that allow Kpn to establish itself in the gut.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Narrative Exposure to stress can induce active coping behaviors, but is also a precipitating factor for human anxiety, depression and post-traumatic stress disorder. Stress increases release of the neurotransmitter acetylcholine (ACh) and we have found that levels of ACh are elevated throughout the human brain when patients are currently depressed. We propose to study stress- induced ACh release, how this becomes dysregulated in response to prolonged stress, and whether it alters coping behaviors, so we can understand brain circuits that are dysfunctional in patients with stress disorders and find new ways to treat those who do not respond to existing treatments.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative TB remains a global health threat with 9.9 million new TB cases globally in 2020. TB vaccine endeavors have been largely unsuccessful in preventing infection, but the recent clinical trial of M72-AS01E demonstrated ~50% efficacy as a Prevention of Disease (POD) vaccine. This project will study a vaccine targeting unique antigens in Mycobacterium tuberculosis that promotes distinct T cell responses during infection and modulates immunopathology, to inform development of improved POD vaccines for TB.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: A new NIH-funded study, HeartShare, aims to gather a wide range of multi-omics data to better understand the etiology of heart failure with preserved ejection fraction (HFpEF) to guide targeted therapeutic developments. However, such rich data modalities are costly and not easy to gather from patients receiving currently available standard of care. Our ancillary study aims to utilize low cost and accessible electrocardiogram data via artificial intelligence to predict and subtype HFpEF.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Campylobacter spp. are the leading cause of bacterial-derived gastrointestinal infection in the world with significant impacts on human health in both developed and developing countries. This prevalence is primarily due to the ability of these bacteria to reside in the gastrointestinal tracts of various animals and transmit to humans where they colonize the colon and cause inflammation. This project will work to understand how a novel regulator in C. jejuni controls nutrient acquisition through sensing an uncommon intracellular signal and subsequently upregulating a system that can transport and metabolize a host-derived molecule to obtain the nutrient it contains.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative: Continuous renewal of the cells that line our digestive tract is essential for health and depends on signals from adjacent ‘mesenchyme.’ Distinct cell populations within the ‘mesenchyme’ serve crucial supportive functions, but their origins and organizational principles remain unknown. Our studies aim to elucidate how discrete cells assemble into a supportive tissue in fetal and early post- natal life and will reveal strategies to prevent or better treat inflammatory bowel disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE For patients with head and neck cancer, delays starting adjuvant radiation therapy are common, disproportionately burden racial minorities, and contribute to poor survival and racial disparities in mortality. However, effective therapies to improve the delivery of timely, equitable, guideline-adherent adjuvant radiation therapy are lacking. We have developed a navigation-based multilevel intervention to enhance care coordination, communication, and key cancer care delivery processes that could provide the first effective treatment in this population, thereby improving survival, decreasing racial disparities in outcomes, and developing new standards of clinical care.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Mycobacterium tuberculosis (Mtb), the causative agent of tuberculosis (TB), has a complex cell wall which contains many unique lipids, making them attractive targets for immune recognition in host defense. This proposal aims to use a novel humanized transgenic mouse model to study the regulation and function of a conserved mycobacterial lipid antigen-specific T cell population during Mtb infection. Findings from our studies will provide foundation for future studies of the clinical relevance of this T cell population in human TB.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project narrative/Relevance to public health statement The NIA/AA for Institute on Methods and Protocols for Advancement of Clinical Trials in ADRD (NIA/AA IMPACT-AD) Course is a 4.5-day multidisciplinary clinical trial training course providing focused instruction on the design, conduct and analysis of ADRD clinical trials, ranging from mechanistic studies to large, community-based interventions. Multidisciplinary training that combines traditional clinical trials training with specialized skills in statistics, study recruitment, study organization, neuropsychology, ethics and informatics will accelerate the establishment of a new, diverse and well-trained cadre of investigators to lead the development of therapies for ADRD, a key priority for improving public health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE mTOR pathway hyperactivity is a major cause of brain malformations and epilepsy, which results in morbidity, mortality, and disability, and currently available medications are unable to cure the underlying disease process and fail to control seizures in one out of three patients. Using a 3-D human neural cell culture model, the proposed project studies how hyperactivity of the mechanistic target of rapamycin (mTOR) pathway related to STRADA mutations causes cortical malformation and epilepsy. Understanding these mechanisms should help identify therapeutic targets to halt or reverse the development of epilepsy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: PENNSYLVANIA STATE UNIV HERSHEY MED CTR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Hepatitis B virus (HBV) is responsible for 257 million infection worldwide and currently there is no effective treatment to cure the disease. Nearly all high-resolution HBV structures published to date utilized E Coli expression system that either 1) lacks the nucleic acid binding domain, or 2) lacks post-translational modification, or 3) encapsidates non-viral nucleic acids; thus, making it difficult to correlate the observed structures with biomedical data. This proposal aims to dissect native high-resolution HBV structures from human hepatoma cells and will provide new structural insights that contribute to our understanding of disease pathogenesis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: In this application, we propose the establishment of the Alzheimer’s-focused Celdara Medical High-Potential Entrepreneurs’ Fellowship Program (A-CHEF). Successful completion of the aims and milestones outlined in this application will provide invaluable immersive training and career development to early-stage scientists, while simultaneously expanding the Alzheimer’s research workforce and advancing novel Alzheimer’s therapeutics toward the clinic and ultimately to patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Hazardous drinking is the leading sexual orientation-related health disparity impacting sexual minority women (SMW; e.g., lesbian, bisexual). While this disparity has primarily been attributed to exposure to minority stress (e.g., discrimination, stigma), minority stress, alone, cannot fully explain hazardous drinking disparities between SMW and heterosexual women. Therefore, this study will examine how other factors, including risk factors (e.g., childhood sexual abuse) and potential mechanisms (e.g., emotion dysregulation, drinking expectancies), combine with minority stress to increase SMW's risk for hazardous drinking.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Extracellular Vesicles (EVs) are present in circulation at a relatively early stage of hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC). The long-term goal of this R01 proposal is to develop and validate a streamlined HCC EV surface protein assay (SPA), capable of highly sensitive and specific quantification of 32 subpopulations of HCC EVs using plasma samples by synergistically integrating two very powerful platform technologies – i) a click chemistry- mediated EV isolation platform (i.e., EV Click Beads) and ii) downstream 4-plex real-time immuno-PCR for quantification of the isolated HCC EVs. The successful development of the proposed HCC EV SPA is rapidly translatable, enabling more sensitive and specific quantification of subpopulations of HCC-associated EVs to detect early-stage HCC.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research aims to evaluate how frailty status changes the effectiveness and safety of drug and procedural therapy as well as health care costs and resource use in older adults. This research is relevant to public health because the evidence generated from this work can help clinicians and health care systems choose effective and safe treatments based on the frailty status. Thus, it accomplishes the National Institute on Aging's missions and initiatives by promoting individualized care to improve the health status of older adults.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE People with Parkinson's disease (PD) experience restricted communicative participation, which means that they have difficulty taking part in life situations where knowledge, information, ideas, or feelings are exchanged. The proposed project—utilizing dialogue theory, speech signal processing, causal inference, and a large corpus of 480 spoken dialogues—will permit identification of hypothesis-driven treatment targets to directly and effectively improve communicative participation of people with PD. This work addresses a critical gap in clinical practice and sets the stage for a subsequent well-informed, clinical trial within this new realm of clinical intervention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research will address a critical public health problem, fatigability- a predictor of future mobility problems in aging, by determining biomechanical and energetic consequences of greater muscle fatigue in older adults. Our innovative, translational approach, which combines state-of-the-art experimental and computational approaches from tissue to behavioral levels, will provide the new information necessary to bridge an existing knowledge gap and thus enable translation of basic science to public health. Our mechanistic outcomes of fatigability will identify promising targets for intervention to mitigate or prevent fatigability and related mobility decline in our aging population, as such, this project is highly relevant to the missions of NIH and NIA.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative Type II spiral ganglion neurons innervate the outer hair cells of the cochlea and have nociceptive characteristics that enable them to detect hair cell loss or damage. This project will define developmental mechanisms guiding cochlear innervation by studying these type II neurons and the axon guidance events that turn their peripheral axons towards the cochlear base in order to contact multiple outer hair cells. Understanding these developmental mechanisms is necessary for the repair of auditory circuits following acoustic trauma and to promote cochlear re-innervation during the course of regeneration-based deafness therapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative In the first project period, we discovered negative crosstalk between the SCAP-dependent and caspase 2 (Casp2)-dependent SREBP activation pathways. Whereas SCAP-dependent SREBP activation dominates in simple steatosis, Casp2-dependent SREBP activation dominates in ER-stressed livers, which progress to steatohepatitis. We now plan to investigate how the crosstalk between the two SREBP activation pathways controls progression to non-alcoholic steatohepatitis (NASH) and its suitability for therapeutic intervention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Increasing access to medications for opioid use disorder could dramatically reduce risk of overdose and other negative health outcomes after release from jail, but these medications are often not available during and after jail stays. In this project, we study the public health impact of a statewide law in Maryland requiring local jails to provide access to medication during incarceration with linkage to care after release.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Metabolic syndrome (MS), characterized by a cluster of conditions including dyslipidemia, central abdominal obesity, insulin resistance, and high blood pressure, is prevalent in people living with HIV (PLWH), and puts them at greater risk of cardiovascular events. Intestinal dysbiosis, compromised intestinal barrier integrity and associated inflammation has been linked with MS in certain populations, but whether this is a driving factor of high levels of MS in HIV+ MSM has not been deeply explored. This proposal couples multi'omic interrogation of intestinal biopsy samples from HIV+ and negative MSM with and without MS and mechanistic studies in innovative in vitro systems and gnotobiotic mice to test the hypothesis that intestinal dysbiosis impacts gut barrier function in HIV+ MSM, and that this promotes MS via the translocation of microbial products.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Immunotherapy using a patient’s own engineered T cells has revolutionized the treatment of relapsed leukemia in children, but this therapy has not been nearly as effective for solid tumors. Therefore, children with relapsed solid tumors remain in dire need of alternative therapies. This project aims to investigate how we can increase the potency of these engineered T cells in order to target solid tumors that have been resistant to T cell therapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: Brain Derived Neurotrophic Factor (BDNF) is a growth factor that is essential for neuronal survival, differentiation, development, and plasticity. Transcriptional regulatory mechanisms provide the specificity required for the appropriate upregulation of BDNF in response to a wide variety of conditions and stimuli, which thereby allows for proper neuronal functioning. This proposal aims to identify and determine the specificity provided by enhancers, non-coding regulatory regions of the genome, in Bdnf regulation and as such will increase our understanding of the fundamental mechanisms that link BDNF’s expression and functions to sensory stimuli.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Infections due to antibiotic-resistant bacteria known as Enterobacterales are occurring increasingly in the community in otherwise healthy persons without significant prior health care contact. Our goal is to identify community-based exposures to resistant bacteria by examining carriage in healthy persons and potential household environmental sources. Our results will lead to ways to control the sources that we find and to decrease the risk of antibiotic-resistant bacterial infections in the community.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE For patients with upper extremity dysfunction caused by strokes, brain trauma, or spinal cord injury, brain- machine interface (BMI) technologies may one day restore function by utilizing cortical neural signals to control the movements of a robotic limb with multiple degrees of freedom. However, the current generation of BMI devices are guided by visual feedback alone, without somatosensory feedback. Our proposal is designed to increase our understanding of sensorimotor integration by examining how varying stimulation parameters affect perceived somatosensation (Aim 1), examine task performance using artificial somatosensation versus native touch (Aim 2), and compare real touch to artificial somatosensation for response time (Aim 3).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: NARRATIVE Developmental Origins of Health and Disease (DOHaD) is a well-accepted concept that exposures during early life (fetal and newborn periods) influence individual’s health and disease risk across the life span. The major contributing factors include environmental toxicants, nutrition, microbiome, stress, hormones, metabolites, drugs, and alcohol. The US DOHaD Society’s missions are to promote diversity and inclusion in the Society’s leadership, to facilitate collaborative studies on these important factors in order to understand their roles in health and disease, and to bring together clinicians, toxicologists, epidemiologists, nutritionists, physiologists, and basic scientists to develop novel preventive strategies, advocate for sound public policy, and ultimately improve the health of Americans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: RELEVANCE The continuing decrease in the number of surgeon-scientists may significantly limit opportunities for future scientific discovery and innovation, and mounting evidence suggests that this decline is due to a ‘pipeline’ problem. Trainees in Otolaryngology-Head and Neck Surgery and the Communication Sciences can face geographic, financial, and systemic barriers that may discourage pursuit of a career as a surgeon-scientist, thus new and innovative approaches are needed to encourage careers in research and to provide research training and effective mentorship. The Research Symposium for Clinician-Scientist Development in Otolaryngology and the Communication Sciences will address this problem by organizing a ‘Research Boot Camp’ that provides instruction, mentorship, and career development tools for attendees.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: NARRATIVE Mapping the spatial organization of the human brain at cellular resolution from single cell gene expression profiles is essential to understanding the function of neurocircuits in the brain. Spatial Genomics has developed a technology to map cell populations and molecular states of single cells in their native environment. This technology can identify cell types and the spatial interactions between neurons and glia in the brain to generate a spatial map with molecular information.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
ORG_NAME: LOUISIANA STATE UNIV A&M COL BATON ROUGE
PHR: Project Narrative  Health disparities exist for children who live in the Deep South, and these include inequities in our understanding of Developmental Language Disorder (DLD) in children who speak various nonmainstream dialects of English and in the materials and methods used to identify and treat children within DLD within these dialects. Using an innovative Disorder within Dialects framework, the proposed studies seek to further test a sentence recall task targeting tense and agreement (T/A) for its diagnostic accuracy and theoretical basis by expanding the type of child profile studied, examining the T/A structures in various syntactic frames, testing the nature of the scoring, and conducting several across-dialect and dialect-specific analyses of the data. The findings will advance our understanding of DLD within various dialects of English and move us one step closer toward developing dialect-appropriate and diagnostically accurate assessments, which should help reduce health disparities in children who live in the Deep South and elsewhere.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Muscle cachexia is a debilitating syndrome that has a dramatic impact on survival and quality of life of many cancer patients and remains a poorly explored area. We believe that achievement of this research program to validate the role of Transglutaminase 2 in cancer-driven muscle cachexia will lead to a paradigm shift, both in terms of understanding the etiology of muscle cachexia, and in terms of drug discovery to curb this life-threatening comorbidity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative: Uncovering the molecular mechanisms controlling cell motility will facilitate the development of new therapeutic strategies aimed at enhancing the efficiency of stem cell therapies, promoting wound healing, or preventing diseases, including cancer metastasis. Although migrating cells can adapt to physical signals imposed by the local microenvironment, the impact of these cues on the mechanisms of cell locomotion remains unclear. We will herein employ an interdisciplinary approach to elucidate how pressure forces influence migration mechanisms and cell behavior in physiological microenvironments.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The goal of this project is to explore the usefulness of a new molecule, RP-115, to measure inflammation and changes to astrocyte cells in the brains of people with Alzheimer's disease (AD). EAAT2, the target of RP-115, expressed abundantly by brain astrocytes, declines sharply in regions of the brain affected by AD. We believe that the use of positron emission tomography (PET) scanning to map radioactive RP-115 binding in AD patient brains will provide insight into the role of inflammation in early AD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NURSING RESEARCH
PHR: Public Health Relevance Billions of federal dollars are spent annually on health care for low-income children, yet children who experience early life adversity (e.g., poverty) continue to experience disproportionately higher rates of health and disease burden relative to their non-poor counterparts. The proposed study examines the influence of early life adversity on accelerated biological aging across the first years of life in order to advance our understanding of the genesis of early life health disparities that shape health outcomes across the life course. Findings from this study will help identify actionable targets for subsequent preventative and early intervention efforts aimed at reducing health and disease risk among vulnerable children, which is critically important given the prevalence of health disparities and limited public health resources available to address this issue; investments targeting children’s early experiences and development can be more cost effective and impactful for promoting children’s health and wellness and their eventual opportunities for success.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Large outbreaks of enterovirus D68 (EV-D68) infections are becoming more frequent and are associated with paralytic disease (acute flaccid myelitis). We will use in vivo, ex vivo, and in vitro models to identify specific EV-D68 sequences and pathogenic mechanisms that lead to the development of paralytic disease. An increased knowledge of mechanisms that are involved in EV-D68 AFM will inform the development of broad-spectrum antivirals.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed project is aimed at testing a novel hypothesis that the learning deficit in DLD is rooted in an ineffective management of the interaction between explicit and implicit learning, caused by an impaired executive function of shifting. The project proposes that children with DLD demonstrate overreliance on explicit learning, and are failing to initiate a shift to implicit learning during complex learning, because of their impaired executive function of shifting. Children will perform two artificial grammar learning tasks that require the extraction of regularities from a complex structure. Behavioral and electrophysiological measures of learning outcomes, learning strategies, and implicit knowledge will be assessed in relation to the executive function of shifting, and compared between children with DLD and age and gender matched controls. The two learning tasks will differ in the extent to which the use of explicit learning is suppressed. The suppression of explicit learning will allow the evaluation of implicit learning without the interference of explicit learning, and without reliance on shifting. The study will subsequently determine whether the suppression of explicit learning improves learning of complex structures in children with DLD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
ORG_NAME: PENNSYLVANIA STATE UNIV HERSHEY MED CTR
PHR: Project Narrative The HIV-1 pandemic remains an ongoing health crisis, with drug resistance and the elimination of the rapidly- established latent reservoir continuing to thwart efforts to eradicate the infection. This research project focuses on virus-cell interactions to investigate the interplay between the HIV-1 replication machinery and cellular factors that assemble to form biomolecular condensates. Our innovative project also considers the influence that substance use disorder may have on HIV-1 replication, with the ultimate goal of finding ways to disrupt infection.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Nutrient handling in the gastrointestinal tract is a complex process that involves digestive enzymes and nutrient transport. Nutrients that are non-digestible by us are broken down by microbes normally residing in the GI tract, which contribute energy and other benefits to the host. The regulation of these events requires endocrine cells that reside in the intestine. This project seeks to uncover how endocrine cells in the large intestine regulate microbial nutrient digestion and host metabolism, which has important implications to our understanding of how obesity occurs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Protein replacement therapy is a cornerstone in the treatment of genetic diseases with loss/reduction of function of a particular protein, by using recombinant proteins or recombinant engineered proteins. Nevertheless, these conventional replacement therapies have formidable limitations such as the requirement of burdensome frequent dosing. This project aims to advance a transformative long-acting mRNA replacement therapy for patients with severe genetic disorders such as hemophilia.

PHR: Project Narrative The precise assembly and operation of the release apparatus for neurotransmitters is critical for normal brain function and is affected in brain disease. Our results will provide detailed molecular insights into mechanisms of neuronal communication and how such communication fails in brain disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative Hearing loss is largely irreversible because in most cases it involves the loss of cochlear hair cells, which in mammals are for the most part not generated past embryogenesis. Deafness may occur due to death of IHCs or, more commonly, OHCs, and thus the regeneration of these specific hair cell types would be necessary to restore hearing. The conversion of IHCs into OHCs that we have discovered in Tbx2 mutants provides unique and novel means for elucidating how these two complementary mechanosensory cell types are generated, knowledge that will guide and assist future therapeutic attempts via regeneration.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Narrative In 2012 President Obama signed the National Alzheimer's Plan Act with a primary objective to decrease racial disparities of Alzheimer's disease and related dementias (ADRD). While it is known that some ethnoracial groups have higher rates of dementia, reasons for these disparities are unknown. We propose to continue our unprecedented lifecourse cohort study of disparities in late life ADRD and cognitive outcomes, the Kaiser Healthy Aging and Diverse Life Experiences Study (KHANDLE). KHANDLE Cycle 1 enrolled 1712 diverse elderly individuals with the goal of delineating lifecourse drivers of disparities in rates of ADRD and cerebropathology. In KHANDLE Cycle 2 we will enroll an additional 500 participants and extend our study outcomes to incidence of ADRD, cognitive decline and changes in neuroimaging based biomarkers of neurodegeneration and vascular brain injury.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative Exposure to cues associated with drug use can trigger relapse in persons suffering from cocaine use disorder. The proposed research is in line with NIH's mission of reducing the burden of neuropsychiatric disease as it characterizes the involvement of a unique neuronal population, cholinergic interneurons, that may contribute to the persistence of high levels of cue-induced cocaine craving, in both male and female rats. By focusing on a novel target in relation to persistent drug craving, this work has the potential to identify novel therapeutic interventions for preventing relapse and thus prolonging abstinence.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Cardio-metabolic diseases including diabetes, obesity, cardiovascular diseases and fatty liver disease affect a large fraction of the adult population of the US. The identification of preventable risk factors is therefore a priority. This project aims to determine whether women who experience greater exposures to environmental chemicals during pregnancy may be at greater risk for developing cardio-metabolic disease later in life.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS MED BR GALVESTON
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Crimean-Congo hemorrhagic fever virus (CCHFV) is a tick-borne emerging pathogen that causes severe and often fatal hemorrhagic fever in humans across a broad geographic range that includes more than 30 countries. CCHFV is of particular importance to public health as there are no licensed vaccines or treatments available for use in humans and because of the concern that it could be used as an agent of biological terrorism. The recombinant vaccine proposed here offers a potential medical countermeasure that can provide coverage across all six genetically distinct clades of CCHFV.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF MASSACHUSETTS MED SCH WORCESTER
PHR: Project Narrative Lung infections are a worldwide public health crisis. They are the leading cause of acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) and sepsis, and improvement in patient outcome has been virtually stagnant for decades. The goal of this proposal is to reveal the biological features of the immune receptor LOX-1 in response to respiratory infection, possibly revealing novel targets for clinical intervention in patients with or at risk for pneumonia and ARDS.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE A lack of diversity among investigators is a strong impediment to resolving national and global challenges related to substance misuse. Certain early career investigators face multidimensional historical and social factors that hinder access to adequate mentorship, quality instruction, focused faculty attention, and the financial support necessary to become independent substance misuse and addition scientist. The proposed program, the Scientific Training in Addiction Research Techniques (START), is a trans-disciplinary drug abuse research education program for early career investigators dedicated to enhancing diversity in the next generation of substance misuse and addiction scientists.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: NARRATIVE This proposal explores epigenetic regulation of neurosensory cell development in the mouse inner ear. In humans, pathogenic variants in the chromatin remodeler gene CHD7 cause CHARGE syndrome, a congenital disorder affecting vision, hearing, cognition, and development of brain, craniofacial, skeletal, renal, and cardiac structures. Our aims assess roles for CHD7 in inner ear neurosensory cell development, to help establish a basis for the design of pharmacologic or gene-based therapies to treat hearing and vestibular disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL LIBRARY OF MEDICINE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE / PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE Machine learning tools can help biomedical researchers to understand their data or to make predictions. Acquiring labeled examples from biomedical experts is a significant limitation in developing machine learning tools. These tools also often fail to generalize beyond the datasets used for tool development. Improving the efficiency of data labeling and generalization would increase the impact of these tools in biomedical research.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR COMPLEMENTARY & INTEGRATIVE HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Women interpersonal violence (IV) survivors are at risk for experiencing stigma which can compound IV-related distress and “downstream” adverse health outcomes, and intersectionalities of vulnerable identities amplify health risk. The proposed community-engaged integrated trauma-informed yoga and adapted mindful self- compassion (I-YMSC) intervention offers a complementary and integrative approach (CIA) for reducing distress as a mechanism for improving psychological, behavioral, and physical health in ethno-racially diverse women. Short-term, this research will contribute to our understanding of the feasibility and acceptability of a novel, multicomponent CIA to reduce distress among diverse IV survivors; long-term, this research has potential to increase our knowledge of approaches to promote health equity in other marginalized groups.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  People with a history of Opioid Use Disorder and criminal justice involvement are more likely to experience loneliness following release from jail/prison leading to negative outcomes such as treatment dropout and increased substance use. Providing peer recovery support, particularly through a highly accessible, digital health platform, is a potential way to decrease loneliness in this population. The current study seeks to test whether a mobile peer recovery support app, delivered to individuals with a recent history of taking medication for opioid use disorder while in jail/prison, will improve outcomes for this vulnerable population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The differentiation of cells into functionally distinct types enables animals to build multicellular bodies and allows their closest-living relatives, choanoflagellates, to take advantage of different environments. Based on our working model that choanoflagellates and animals evolved cell differentiation programs from a common, ancestral genetic toolkit, this proposal advances molecular genetic tools in choanoflagellates to investigate the mechanisms that govern cellular differentiation in these aquatic microeukaryotes. This work will provide novel functional data to highlight the conservation or divergence or regulatory mechanisms in choanoflagellates and animals, thereby illuminating the core functions of genes that were foundational for the origin of animals and that remain integral for human biology.

PROJECT_TITLE: The ancestry of animal cell differentiation and pluripotency

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Drug therapy is required to treat trypanosomatid parasite infections, yet existing drugs suffer from challenging treatment regimens, emerging drug resistance, and significant gaps in our understanding of their mechanisms of action and trypanocidal targets. The proposed research will use a state-of-the-art genetic screening tool to identify genes whose expression promotes resistance against the clinically relevant anti-trypanosomatid drugs currently in use. The phenotypes imparted by multi-resistance genes will then be evaluated to identify pathways that result in drug resistance and, conversely, cell death, the outcomes of which will be transformative for future drug development in trypanosomatid parasites.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative  Clostridium perfringens requires branched chain amino acids (BCAAs) for growth and we have shown that contact of this bacterium with a differentiated muscle cell line upregulates expression of the C. perfringens gene encoding the BCAA transporter BrnQ2, so we will use BCAA transporter or toxin null mutants to test if a BCAA transporter(s) is important for C. perfringens growth using BCAAs in blood or toxin-damaged muscle cells. Furthermore, diabetics have elevated blood BCAA levels, so we will use BCAA transporter mutants in normal and diabetic mice to test whether BCAA transporter(s) is/are important contributor(s) to the association of C. perfringens-mediated gas gangrene with diabetics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The research plan is designed to test the beneficial metabolic and anti-inflammatory actions of an endogenously present class of modified fats, termed nitro-fatty acids. This project provides a novel precision pharmacology therapy, oral CXA-10, for the treatment of obese asthma, a disease that responds poorly to standard asthma medications and increases airway hyperreactivity. The study will leverage both clinical variables (lung function, asthma control questionnaire and bronchial hyperreactivity) as well as the use of gut, lung, nasal, plasma and urine samples as a translational research tool to better understand obesity-mediated changes in relation to how CXA-10 effects changes in gene expression and how –omics profiles are modified by CXA-10.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative The true benefit of biomedical research to public health depends upon swift and efficient translation of scientific discoveries into the healthcare domain. This translation is accomplished first and foremost by the cadre of “bilingual” clinician-scientists who are at home in both the world of science and the world of clinical medicine. Our program aims precisely to nurture the development of such clinician-scientists in the field of otolaryngology – head and neck surgery.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: Opioid overdose-related deaths have surged worldwide in recent years, largely due to a lack of effective interventions for the sustained cessation of opioid use. Experiencing stressful events is an important risk factor for the development of opioid use disorder (OUD) and a common trigger for relapse, but the neural mechanisms that mediate these effects are incompletely understood. This proposal aims to provide foundational knowledge for OUD prevention and treatment development by (1) determining how stress alters heroin intake and relapse and by (2) systematically examining stress-induced neuroadaptations in a stress- and opioid-responsive population of ventral pallidal glutamate neurons.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative The proposed research is relevant to public health because it focuses on discovery of novel signaling pathways that drive castration-resistant prostate cancer. IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: NARRATIVE Individuals with physical disabilities have a right to full participation and inclusion in their communities – a right upheld by national and international laws and regulations. This basic right is not currently experienced, particularly within the domain of parasport and, more recently, the rapidly growing sector of active eSports. The proposed research will seek to explore and understand the experiences of individuals with physical disabilities in active eSports, with the goal of creating a knowledge base that can be used by future researchers to promote full participation in the active eSport community.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Correlations in neural dynamics across the brains of interacting individuals are an emergent and highly conserved property of social interactions, but the functional relevance of these correlations remains enigmatic. In this proposal we will use a comparative multi-species approach, combining state-of-the-art wireless technological advances and cellular/subcellular resolution imaging with pioneering molecular-genetic tools to decipher the biological mechanisms that enable neural synchrony and unequivocally define its function. By moving beyond a correlative understanding of this intriguing emergent neural property, we will determine its role in successful social interaction and attachment, a finding with transformative implications for the manipulation of these dynamics in a therapeutic context.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: There is an unmet medical need to develop new treatment approaches for patients with genetic disorders, and intrauterine transplantation (IUTX) of hematopoietic stem cells is one of the few therapeutic approaches that can promise the birth of a healthy infant who requires no further treatments. Thus far, for reasons that are not currently well understood, IUTX has only been successful for treating X-SCID patients; in these studies, we will identify obstacles to IUTX success, and test novel ways of overcoming them to enable successful application of IUTx to diseases such as sickle cell disease (SCD). In addition, we created and will validate overtime a large animal model of SCD, which will be a valuable and highly clinically relevant resource for the SCD community in general.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Acute retinal necrosis is a viral infection of the retina with devastating complications resulting in life-long visual impairment, a worse quality of life, reduction in productivity, and can be associated with central nervous system infection and death despite rapid treatment. This project aims to provide the necessary skills to understand how the viral-innate immune response interplay unfolds within nonregenerative retinal tissue and whether there are pathways that can be targeted to improve visual outcomes following viral infection of the retina.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Project Narrative Pediatric acute respiratory distress syndrome is a life-threatening and frequent problem experienced by thousands of children each year. In severe pediatric acute respiratory distress, little evidence substantiates current supportive practices. The overall objective of this study is to compare short and long-term patient outcomes in two groups of children: one group managed with a mechanical ventilation protocol that reserves the use of extracorporeal membrane oxygenation (ECMO) until protocol failure to another group supported on ECMO per usual care.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE T cell immunotherapy focused on effector T cells has revolutionized cancer treatment. We and others have recently discovered that naïve T cells – the primordial substrate of T cell immunity – exist in distinct transcriptional states, which in turn dictates their capacity to become effector T cells. Here, we propose to test the transformative hypothesis that these naïve T cell archetypes can be modified (induced, expanded, contracted) by the type of microbial exposure (i.e.: bacteria, viruses, helmiths) and thus be programmed to become better at mounting anti- tumor immunity.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed T32 program for Clinical Research Training for the Fetal-Neonatal Brain will train the next generation of clinician-scientists in the research methodologies required to advance understanding of the developing human brain in vivo. The 2-3 year multidisciplinary research training program will focus on rigorous research methodology, advanced multimodal neurodiagnostic techniques for the fetus and newborn, and post- acquisition data processing, interpretation and analysis. The expertise developed will be critical for the formulation of future preventive neuroprotection strategies for the fetus and newborn.

PROJECT_TITLE: Clinical Pediatric Research Training for the Fetal-Neonatal Brain

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE During S phase, essential nuclear processes such as DNA replication, transcription, and chromatin re- establishment must be coordinated to ensure genetic and epigenetic stability are maintained. These processes operate within the confines of spatially-distinct condensates and nuclear bodies, yet the mechanisms that regulate their spatial dynamics remain unknown. The goals of our research are to elucidate the mechanisms that regulate transcription condensate dynamics during DNA replication, to discover the pathways that balance histone biosynthesis to ensure epigenetic stability, and to understand how cells re-establish 3-dimensional chromatin structure following DNA replication.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Many neurological disorders, including Parkinson's and Alzheimer’s Diseases impair attention, working memory and other foundational cognitive functions, which are thought to depend upon the interactions between different thalamic nuclei and cortical regions. This study will clarify the interactions among the many distinct cortical and thalamic sub-regions during normal cognitive function, and when some regions are impaired, yielding insights into the brain processes underlying symptoms of many patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed study will generate population-based data on the effectiveness of lung cancer screening with low dose computed tomography. These results have the potential to inform patient and clinician shared decision- making conversations and future US Preventive Services Task Force evidence reviews. As the number of patients screened for lung cancer increases due to expanded eligibility criteria, this research is timely and responsive to the National Cancer Institute’s goal to support research in cancer control that will help inform guideline development and policy decisions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Problematic cannabis use is common and leads to enormous personal and societal burden; thus, there is an urgent need to understand who is vulnerable, and why, in order to facilitate prevention and treatment. The current study will combine neural and behavioral measures with acute drug administration to better understand the neural mechanisms underlying the rewarding, reinforcing properties of cannabis. This work will ultimately contribute to a deeper understanding of brain and behavioral risk factors underlying problematic cannabis use and promote the development of targeted, prevention and intervention efforts for this population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE: Amnestic mild cognitive impairment (aMCI) is an early stage in the Alzheimer’s clinical syndrome, and it will be important to determine whether biological processes in aMCI might differ due to a remote history of mild traumatic brain injury (mTBI). To this end, the proposed study will combine state-of-the-art high definition transcranial direct current stimulation and blood-derived biomarker tools with comprehensive clinical and cognitive information to inform whether the biological changes in aMCI relate to a history of mTBI. This new information will provide the necessary groundwork to begin identifying the biological processes for how ACS is related to TBI, which could eventually lead to the development of new interventions to mitigate risk for ACS in older adults with a TBI history.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The emergence of antibiotic resistant bacteria poses an immense threat to public health, but we know little about the mechanisms that explain why some strains, out of the huge diversity of a bacterial species, are more likely to become and stay resistant. The project in this proposal aims to address this gap in knowledge, focusing on the common pathogen Neisseria gonorrhoeae, the cause of the sexually transmitted disease gonorrhea. We expect this project will facilitate novel strategies to prevent, control, and treat antibiotic resistance.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative. The National Cancer Institute estimates that in 2018, approximately 1.7 million people will be diagnosed with cancer in the United States alone, and of those, approximately 600,000 will succumb to their disease. One of the key drivers of cancer is the aberrant expression of cancer-causing proteins. This program will develop a platform to evaluate the efficacy of heterobifunctional small molecules for targeted degradation of currently “undruggable” metalloproteins activated during tumorigenesis or tumor progression.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Nearly half of patients with pancreatic neuroendocrine tumors (PanNET) present with liver metastases at diagnosis, which correlates with poor prognosis, and the immunosuppressive microenvironment of PanNET limits the efficacy of immune checkpoint inhibitors (ICI) for metastatic PanNET patients, with a less than 10% objective response rate. Emerging evidence suggests that increased vascular leakage and poor vascular perfusion resulting from vascular destabilization impair immune cell infiltration into tumors, thus facilitating tumor immune evasion and consequent tumor progression. In this work, we propose to study role of angiopoietin-2/Tie2 signaling, which regulates vascular destabilization and dysfunction, in liver metastatic progression and in ICI therapy resistance of metastatic PanNET as well as the potential of Tie signaling molecules as sensitive cancer biomarkers for PanNET patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Public Health Relevance The proposed research is relevant to public health because understanding predictors of initial treatment response and weight loss maintenance for adolescents with obesity will lead to an ability to match adolescents to personally effective treatment. Precision medicine approaches directed toward initial treatment response and weight loss maintenance will have the long-term impact of reducing the health burden of obesity, a chronic and impairing disease, as well as enhancing overall health and longevity. The current project directly responds to gaps identified by a recent NIH workshop on precision medicine in the context of adolescent obesity and addresses an NIDDK priority area of weight loss maintenance.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE Effective prevention, treatment, and recovery services for substance use disorders (SUD) and HIV and their effective implementation in real-world service settings can be achieved via adaptive interventions; these interventions explicitly guide the modification of the type/intensity of services (or implementation supports) based on the context and changing needs of individuals with or at risk for SUD/HIV and the settings where they receive care. However, (i) existing adaptive intervention approaches have been unable to harness the unprecedented opportunities offered by advances in digital technologies, such as electronic health records (EHRs) and mobile devices; and (ii) existing experimental designs and data analytics have not kept up with the critical questions investigators must address to optimize the adaptation of SUD/HIV services across different levels, modalities, and timescales. The focus of the Methodologies for Adapting and Personalizing Prevention, Treatment, and Recovery Services for SUD and HIV (MAPS Center) is the development, evaluation, and dissemination of novel data collection and data analysis methodologies that are essential to optimize adaptive interventions to combat SUD/HIV.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Genetic alterations in human cancer have been systematically studied over the past decade, but the impact of a majority of these changes on the proteome – the functional end of the genome – are poorly understood. In this project we will use a state-of-the-art, unbiased analysis method, mass spectrometry-based proteomics, to define the protein content and identify key posttranslational modifications of the proteins that are involved in cell signaling. By integrating the proteomics data with the genomics and metabolomics data for the same samples/tumors we will shed new light on the biology of cancer and, importantly, we will help to identify new targets for therapeutic intervention.

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative - Overall Tulane National Primate Research Center (TNPRC) has one of the largest specific pathogen free (SPF) rhesus monkey breeding colonies in the US, a resource that has provided animals for NIH funded research projects for several decades. Over half of all research projects at TNPRC are initiated by outside investigators, making this resource essential to the success of many NIH-funded researchers across the country. Experienced leadership and significant infrastructure investment, combined with proven techniques in breeding colony management, ensure continued responsible stewardship of this nationally recognized resource.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: The ability to efficiently generate comprehensive datasets from large mammalian brains would enable researchers to investigate these complex structures more efficiently and systematically. Towards this goal, LifeCanvas Technologies will develop new tissue processing and imaging instruments for high-throughput, high-resolution, automated volumetric imaging of various large-scale mammalian brains. Together with LifeCanvas’ state-of-the-art tissue clearing, labeling and analysis pipeline, the new developments will provide the neuroscience research community with powerful tools to generate unprecedented, comprehensive datasets for a large variety of mammalian samples, including rodent, non-human primate and human brains.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: NARRATIVE Single amino acid variants in TREM2 have been identified by genome-wide association studies to be one of the strongest genetic risk factors for late-onset Alzheimer's disease (AD) and AD-associated variants in TREM2 impair TREM2's ability to bind and signal in response to ligands in the body, further affecting TREM2- mediated immune activation in AD. The central hypothesis of the proposed study is that the available drugs, including FDA-approved drugs, could bind TREM2 at either basic and/or hydrophobic binding site, allosteric effect of drugs at TREM2 either or two binding sites could regulate ligand binding at both sites to modulate TREM2-mediated immune activation in AD, and compensate for the loss of TREM2-mediated immune activities by AD-associated TREM2 variants. New knowledge gained from this study could have high impact for AD research and treatment by repositioning the available drugs to target TREM2 and further the insight into available drugs modulating TREM2-mediated immune activation, offering a molecular basis for strategy development of using available drugs including drug combinations to target TREM2 for AD treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Respiratory viral infections such as influenza and COVID-19 are frequent causes of acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS), which is often followed by a devastating long term morbid complication, post-viral pulmonary fibrosis. Despite the pulmonary endothelium playing an important role in the development of ARDS, the therapeutic potential of modulating EC dysfunction to prevent deleterious long-term consequences has not been well-explored. Reversing endothelial dysfunction and restoring pulmonary vascular integrity through augmentation of an endothelial receptor, S1PR1, could provide a novel strategy to promote lung repair and prevent viral-injury induced lung fibrosis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative As survival becomes a standard expectation for infants with congenital heart disease (CHD), the focus of the clinical community is now shifting to understanding and improving long-term neurodevelopmental outcomes in these high-risk children. This study aims to understand the influence of impaired placenta and other maternal- fetal risk factors on fetal and postnatal brain development among CHD survivors. Findings from this study will lay the foundation for developing early, neuroprotective and/or neurorehabilitative interventions aimed at mitigating neurodevelopmental delay and improving quality of life in this population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative 5-10% of auditory nerve fibers in the inner ear (type II fibers) are thought to be involved in detecting loud sounds, and to possibly contribute to pathologies like noxacusis that can accompany hearing loss. Such deficits can substantially affect the ability to lead our everyday lives. This proposal seeks to identify and investigate multiple cellular pathways that may contribute to type II fiber activity and its changes after noise exposure, to provide a basis for preventing or curing inner ear pathologies related to type II fiber activity.
