IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE A lack of basic knowledge about bilingual language organization prevents the adequate treatment of bilingual individuals after brain damage, leading to recovery rates that are well below those of their monolingual counterparts. The current project addresses this gap in our knowledge by testing healthy and aphasic bilingual individuals in behavioral and fMRI paradigms to identify the degree to which the cognitive and neural mechanisms that support bilingual language use are shared or distinct across languages and levels of linguistic representation. Obtaining this information constitutes a critical first step to potentially develop targeted intervention approaches that will maximize language recovery in post-stroke aphasia in a demographic group that will be the majority of the US population by 2040.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NURSING RESEARCH
PHR: NARRATIVE Rural populations in the U.S. are disproportionately burdened by cardiovascular disease and type 2 diabetes. Lifestyle modification interventions are needed that support long-term engagement in risk-reducing health behaviors. Our proposal will study the effects of a family focused, lifestyle intervention that is culturally tailored for use with rural Hispanic and non-Hispanic adults and will have significant potential for broad dissemination to reduce T2D and CVD health disparities in rural U.S. communities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative The DREAM Challenges is an organization supporting collaborative competitions, a crowd-sourced initiative to accelerate innovation and insight in the biomedical sciences. DREAM has hosted Challenges in oncology to facilitate the development, evaluation, and comparison of algorithms that are critical to this field, such as models for patient prognosis and diagnosis, and prediction of therapeutic response. The DREAM Challenges has established itself as an important resource for the cancer research community and will continue to innovate and expand into critical areas in cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Gout is the most prevalent inflammatory arthritis with a worsening global disease burden and a substantial and rising prevalence of cardiometabolic comorbidities, which in turn contribute to premature mortality. These trends highlight the shortcomings of our current approach to gout care and call for personalized comorbidity- integrated models of gout care with the potential to synergistically address gout and its comorbidities. This Career Development Award proposes to leverage real-world and patient-derived data to conduct rigorous comparative effectiveness studies to examine the gout benefits of pleiotropic cardiometabolic medications and identify comorbidity phenotype clusters of incident gout and their associated outcomes to inform personalized comorbidity-integrated gout care and help improve both gout morbidities and comorbidities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: STATE UNIVERSITY OF NEW YORK AT BUFFALO
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Although electronic nicotine delivery systems (ENDS), particularly e-cigarettes, are of substantial public health importance, our ability to accurately characterize and non-obtrusively track ENDS puff behavior is quite limited. To overcome this barrier, the proposed research will use a novel Flexible Robust Instrumentation of ENDS (FRIENDS) monitor to assess puff behavior in the lab and the natural environment among participants representing a wide range of ENDS devices and users. This work will markedly advance our understanding of ENDS use behavior, make available to the field a validated, inexpensive, flexible, and accurate method (the FRIENDS monitor) for use in future studies, and guide the development of improved self-report assessments.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The overarching goal of the Center for Aging and Policy Studies (CAPS) is to improve the health, well-being, and independence of middle-age and older adults by directly addressing some of today’s most pressing issues facing those adults and the families that care for them. Critical issues are the growing disparities in middle-age and older adult health across geographic areas and population subgroups, and the changing needs of the older adult population in terms of familial support and caregiving. CAPS will achieve its important goal by conducting innovative and rigorous research, providing state-of-the-art training to scientists conducting that research, and widely disseminating their research findings to other scientists, decision makers, and the public.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative: The overarching goal of this study is to identify effective metabolic based diagnostic and therapeutic strategies to improve the overall survival of patients with Non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC). We propose to investigate the positron emission tomography (PET) tracer, 18F-BnTP as a novel metabolic diagnostic and to develop metabolic based therapeutic strategies targeting oxidative mitochondrial metabolism in therapy resistant KRAS/LKB1 and EGFR mutant lung tumors. This work represents a new approach to overcoming therapy resistance in KRAS/LKB1 and EGFR mutant lung tumors – one in which the tumor’s metabolic and bioenergetic dependencies are profiled and then selectively targeted.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project is a collaboration between three academic institutions and Aethlon Medical, Inc. The overarching objective is to improve response to immunotherapy by removing immunosuppressive exosomes from the circulation of patients with head and neck squamous cell cancer (HNSCC). Aethlon Medical, Inc. has developed a GMP-compatible device to remove circulating exosomes, the Hemopurifier. We will use the Hemopurifier to show that removal of exosomes from HNSCC patients’ blood prior to immunotherapy will promote immune cell recovery and significantly increase the response rate.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Signal transduction is the process by which cells respond to environmental cues - networks of protein-protein interactions are coordinated by the reversible addition and removal of phosphate in response to the signal. Disruption of the normal patterns of phosphorylation has been implicated in the etiology of a variety of major human diseases, including cancer. The ability to modulate signaling pathways selectively holds enormous therapeutic potential. The first drugs directed against protein tyrosine kinases (PTKs) have now entered the market and represent breakthroughs in the treatment of cancer; however, challenges remain, including the fact that patients develop resistance to such drugs. Therefore, despite the obvious potential of PTK inhibitors as drug candidates, alternative approaches, to target simultaneously different signaling enzymes and events, are expected be more effective than focusing on PTKs alone. But what are those alternative approaches? The focus on PTKs for drug development ignores the other major component of phosphorylation-dependent regulation of signaling. Protein phosphorylation is a reversible process, in which the coordinated and competing activities of kinases and phosphatases are important for determining signaling outcome. The protein tyrosine phosphatases (PTPs), which work in combination with the PTKs, have been garnering attention as potential therapeutic targets, but remain a largely untapped resource for drug development. This proposal focuses on a functional analysis of specific PTPs in models of cancer. The hypothesis to be tested is that PTPs function as specific regulators of tyrosine phosphorylation-dependent signaling pathways and thus manipulation of PTP function in cell and animal models will reveal new insights into the critical signaling events that underlie the disease. The overall goal is to define functional links between particular PTPs and specific signaling pathways in cancer, with a view to establishing how disruption of such functions affects the etiology of the disease and to reveal novel therapeutic targets from among the PTPs themselves or from the signaling pathways they regulate. Furthermore, we have now developed new approaches to “drugging” the PTPs themselves, producing drug-like molecules that are opening up new opportunities for cancer therapy.

PHR: Project Narrative South Asians are a rapidly increasing minority population in the U.S., Canada, and the U.K. This group has marked increase in premature heart disease and diabetes that is not fully explained by diet and lifestyle or traditional lipids. By understanding what might explain the increased heart and diabetes risk, we may better treat and prevent these conditions in South Asians.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative West Virginia (WV) ranks among the worst states in most indicators of health outcome, including stroke prevalence and its co-morbid conditions. To address these issues, the WVU Stroke CoBRE will continue to conduct basic and translational research to decrease morbidity and mortality related to stroke through improved understanding of pathophysiological mechanism(s) of stroke. This will be achieved through the development of stroke researchers at WVU by mentored research training and the expansion of cutting-edge research core facilities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: In this project we will focus on poorly studied noncanonical short RNAs, tRFs, that are generated by mechanisms very different from microRNAs and yet several of them are now known to enter into microRNA mediated gene regulatory machinery (RISC). This project will identify specific surveillance mechanisms that keep many tRFs out of RISC, mechanisms that can be altered in pathological conditions and for therapeutic purpose. In parallel, the project will study those tRFs that elude the surveillance mechanisms and enter RISC, to determine their effects on gene regulation, cellular phenotypes and microRNA mediated gene expression, thus significantly expanding our understanding of RNA mediated post-transcriptional gene regulation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because it will provide us with fundamental knowledge of the intra-tick and intra-host infection biology of the tick-borne bunyavirus, severe fever with thrombocytopenia syndrome virus (SFTSV). Due to its high case fatality rate, ability to cause hemorrhagic disease, and lack of specific treatment strategies, SFTSV is considered a priority infectious disease by the World Health Organization. Elucidating the basic infection biology of SFTSV within the Haemaphysalis longicornis tick and within the skin of the vertebrate host will lay the foundation towards developing novel interventions that disrupt SFTSV transmission and survival.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Over 90% of individuals worldwide have been infected by varicella zoster virus (VZV), the cause of chickenpox. VZV remains dormant in the nervous system and, when it reactivates, can cause the painful condition shingles or debilitating neurologic conditions such as brain or spinal cord inflammation (encephalitis and myelitis). Here, we propose to use new stem-cell based models to investigate pathways within neurons that contribute to persistence and reactivation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative There remains a need for novel research that facilitates responsible reporting back of research results (RBRR) in a manner that raises data and environmental health literacy and supports communities striving for environmental health and structural change. Rooted in bioethics, the program focuses on how to report back social determinants of health and soil and air quality data with rural and urban communities that are disproportionately impacted by pollution. Building upon trusted and established long-term partnerships and leveraging existing datasets, the project goal is to create and pilot a national model of report back that engages diverse environmental justice communities to ensure that RBRR reaches all populations in a manner tailored to their individual needs, including culture, life stage, language, and design.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The goal of this research program is to determine the role, the Kcnn1 potassium channel plays during recovery from spinal cord injury. We are combining in vivo imaging with state of the art optogenetic and CRISPR/Cas9-medidate techniques to generate stable zebrafish lines to understand the molecular mechanisms that underlie these neuronal processes. These lines will then be used in high- throughput screening to identify potential therapeutic targets.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Family psychoeducation for adults living with psychotic disorders in Tanzania (KUPAA Trial) The proposed research is relevant to public health because the mental health needs of individuals with psychotic disorders in low-resource countries have been severely neglected, due in part to a lack of culturally tailored and evidence-based interventions. Family psychoeducation (FPE) is an evidence-based practice from high-income countries that could have a significant impact in settings such as Africa and other regions worldwide where resources are limited, families are largely responsible for care and support, and traditional beliefs and treatments are common. This R01 will test the effectiveness and mechanisms of action of a newly adapted and culturally tailored version of FPE called KUPAA for adults living with psychotic disorders in Tanzania which aligns with NIMH Strategy 4.2.B, “Building models to scale-up evidence-based practices for use in public and private primary care, specialty care, and non-traditional settings.”

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The emerging science of the exposome – the totality of non-genetic exposures across the life cycle -- is a crucial new direction for research to foster healthy families and prevent later-life chronic disease. Assessments involve hundreds of measurements of chemical exposures, neighborhood stressors, and early health indicators at the cellular level. With input from participants in studies of pregnancy and child health, this project will develop ethical and practical methods for reporting back personalized results in large studies with multiple types of data, offering reports that are meaningful and not overwhelming.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Critical self-judgment is a common phenomenon underlying a wide range of psychological disorders. The proposed project aims to investigate the neural mechanism of critical self- judgment by analyzing MRI and questionnaire data collected from 5 previous studies that all included mindfulness or compassion based interventions for various psychological symptoms, e.g., depression, anxiety, stress and chronic pain. Knowledge from this study will inform clinical practice to target critical self-judgment as an underlying common root for a wide range of psychological disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: This project aims to promote improved mental health outcomes for young adults by combining electronic health records with psychiatric and cognitive dimensional measures to predict risk for, and course of, psychopathology. It will enroll a group of 10,000 individuals, ages 18-20, who will complete the brief web-based battery every six months for two years. The artificial intelligence models developed from combining psychiatric and cognitive dimensions with health records will allow health systems to conduct earlier mental health screening and link interventions to illness phase in the young adults most likely to benefit from them.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Narrative The clinical diagnosis of Parkinson disease (PD) and multiple system atrophy (MSA) can be challenging, especially at early disease stages. This project aims to develop two compensatory blood-based biomarker assays, which will likely establish the foundation leading to inexpensive, accurate, and clinically routine tests that improves PD and MSA diagnosis accuracy and/or enhances disease progression monitoring.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Project Narrative Intimate partner violence (IPV) is common, with over 7% of U.S. women reporting physical or sexual violence, and/or stalking in the past year. Over half of women experiencing IPV are victimized multiple times over multiple years, therefore meeting the definition of a chronic condition. This proposal seeks to characterize the impact of state law on rates of IPV and IPV related health outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Severe to profound hearing loss, largely attributable to injury to the sensory hair cells, affects 1 in 1,000 newborns, and 60% of people older than 70 years, and has multiple causes, genetic, environmentally induced, and age-related. The mechanisms of hair cell damage and death are in most cases not well understood and the work will address these mechanisms in two ways: firstly, by studying mouse mutants that have human equivalents such as TMC1, which, with over 50 mutations, is one of the most common causes of genetic hearing loss; secondly, by investigating mechanisms and reversibility of transduction loss in genetic deafness and the connection to hair cell apoptosis.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The MIDAS network aims to advance science to improve global preparedness and response against infectious disease threats by supporting the infectious disease modeling community through research, training, promotion, and service. The MIDAS Coordination Center will support these important efforts by gathering resources necessary for infectious disease modeling research; harmonizing important datasets; fostering community-based activities; training infectious disease researchers; conducting coordination and outreach activities; and conducting novel research into the evaluation of infectious disease models. These efforts will build a stronger research community and advance the state of the science of infectious disease modeling.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This proposal aims to create a series of deep learning (DL)-based pipelines for generating synthetic data points from chest radiographs for medical dataset augmentation and improved fairness in pathology detection. By leveraging generative modeling and Denoising Diffusion Probabilistic Models (DDPMs), this research has the potential to improve the accuracy and fairness of pathology detection in chest radiographs for underserved populations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project narrative Immunity is important not only for fighting infection but also many human diseases, such as cancer. The Hippo pathway is well-known for its anti-cancer role, but recent discoveries indicate this pathway is crucial for immunity. This study focuses on dissecting contribution of the Hippo kinases in immunity, which will inform development of new therapeutics to treat infection and other human diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Summary/Abstract Metabolic dysfunction occurs decades prior to the development of Alzheimer’s disease (AD), and alterations in mitochondrial complex-I (MC-1) may be the culprit. The emergence of novel imaging tools allows quantitative and non-invasive assessment of both the availability and metabolic function of MC-1, enabling mechanistic understandings of mitochondrial dysfunction, revolutionizing how we monitor metabolic health in vivo, and paving the way for therapeutic development targeting MC-1 and mitochondrial metabolism. In this exploratory study, we will evaluate the feasibility of two novel scanning techniques in murine models of AD to 1) image the availability of MC-1 using [18F]BCPP-EF PET and 2) assess the MC-1 metabolic function in real time using hyperpolarized MR spectroscopy to observe the metabolic conversion of [2-13C]pyruvate to [5-13C]glutamate, a process occurring in mitochondria, serving as a readout of MC-1 metabolic function.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) is an autoimmune disease characterized by inefficient clearance of apoptotic cells, termed efferocytosis. Lipid metabolism is linked to the efferocytosis function of macrophages, but the mechanism by which macrophages regulate lipid metabolism for efferocytosis is unknown. In this project, we will define how the quantity and composition of lipid droplets in macrophage subsets affect efferocytosis and determine if they can be manipulated to shift macrophage function for the treatment of SLE.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE CDC and SAMHSA data indicate that in 2021 there were about 500,000 new U.S. cocaine users aged 12 and older and that cocaine accounted for about 1 in every 4 drug overdose-related deaths. Development of novel therapies to address the challenge of new and on-going cocaine use depends on insights into the underlying biological changes within the brain of affected individuals, but prior research has focused overwhelmingly on how cocaine affects activity of neurons. This proposal explores new evidence that cocaine changes activity of astrocytes that are predicted to influence on-going cocaine use and relapse to use after abstinence.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: TEXAS TECH UNIVERSITY HEALTH SCIENCES CENTER AT EL PASO
PHR: Project narrative  GABAergic neurons, the most common inhibitory neurons present in the human brain, were found to be dysfunction in Alzheimer’s disease. The molecular mechanism about the deregulation of GABAergic synapse function is largely unknown in Alzheimer’s disease. The present study is designed to understand the molecular mechanism behind the GABAergic synapse dysfunction in Alzheimer’s disease.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative Although many studies have described race/ethnic-based discrepancies in suspensions and expulsions for children of color relative to White children, little is known about how teachers evaluate children’s behaviors that serve as the basis for these disciplinary decisions, especially at the preschool level. This study addresses this limitation by examining whether children of color with similar demographics and comparable levels of social-emotional regulation as White children receive harsher behavioral assessments. It also examines whether teacher-child racial/ethnic match influence children’s behavioral ratings.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Genetic and epidemiologic evidence linking underlying immune dysfunction and autoimmune conditions (AIDs) with Parkinson’s disease risk and worse outcomes. We hypothesize that inflammatory mechanisms contribute to both PD and autoimmune diseases, and certain candidate therapies approved to target immune processes in AIDs are also effective in mitigating PD risk and phenoconversion. Here, we will leverage the well- characterized effects of genetic variation influencing the expression or function of individual therapeutic targets (summarized using polygenic scores) as instruments to help to understand the downstream effects of AID treatment on PD risk and conversion from prodromal to diagnosed PD. .

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research is relevant to public health because it focuses on developing and testing clinical decision support in intensive care units for timely identification of patients suitable for activity interventions. We expect study results will impact the field by developing a pragmatic way of accelerating the concurrent use of patient data with guideline recommendations at the point of care to support ICU clinicians in delivering evidence-based care, decrease the duration of bedrest, and reduce hospital-acquired functional decline. Thus, the proposed research is relevant to the part of AHRQ's mission that pertains to making healthcare safer, higher quality, and evidence-based.

PROJECT_TITLE: Improving Identification and Coordination of Mobility Interventions in the ICU Using Clinical Decision Support

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: In aging, MDD is linked to systemic inflammation, cognitive deficits and treatment-resistance, with women highly susceptible. In an animal model, we will test the impact of sex and age on hypobaric hypoxia-induced depressive, anxiety and cognitive symptoms. Since rates of antidepressant treatment-resistance increase with aging, the impact of age and sex will be addressed on the antidepressant-like efficacy of SSRIs and the bioenergetic com- pound cyclocreatine under conditions of chronic hypobaric hypoxia.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Remodeling of synaptic connections between neurons is considered a cellular basis of information storage in the brain. In this proposal, we will examine the regulation and functions of the master transcription factor CREB within synapses and in strengthening neuronal connections. The results will provide a deeper understanding of learning and memory in physiological conditions as well as insights into cognitive dysfunction in memory disorders.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The ability to assess body composition and physical activity (PA) with wearable technology offers many benefits for people with DS such as completing measurements in a comfortable testing environment. Despite the potential benefits and convenience of wearable technology, the accuracy of devices for measuring body composition and PA needs to be established prior to widespread adoption and utilization in this special population. Accordingly, this proposal will address a primary scope of NOT-OD-21-092, which includes validating at-home diagnostic tools, including actigraphy and wearable technologies, in adults with DS.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: METTL3 deficiency-mediated neuronal m6A reduction contributes to neurodegeneration in Alzheimer’s disease and multiple m6A modification sites in the gene transcripts of Aβ metabolism (production and degradation) pathways have been identified by the online resources of m6A methylation profiling and m6A predictor. In the preliminary data, we found that AAV-mediated METTL3 knockdown of primary neurons increases the Aβ level and impairs the mRNA decay of the Aβ metabolism-related gene BACE1. In this application, we proposed to investigate the molecular mechanisms underlying the Aβ accumulation caused by impaired METTL3-m6A signaling in neurons with a focus on mRNA stability, translation, splicing and nuclear export of Aβ metabolism- related gene transcripts.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Most of what we know about visual search comes from experiments where observers do hundreds of instances of the same task, but most searches in the world involve a search for one thing, followed by another search for something else, and so forth. We will determine if the rules, established in studies of long blocks of trials, apply to situations where different search tasks are intermixed. We will focus especially on factors known to influence errors in search and will use Emergency Department radiology as a specific real-world setting.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because it investigates an essential stage of the infection process of Entamoeba histolytica, a major public health problem in many developing countries. We established a method for producing infectious cysts in vitro and will now develop a procedure for reproducible, high efficiency excystation of cysts in laboratory culture, thus allowing us to study this key process. This will provide a critical foundation for future studies to develop mechanisms targeting this stage of infection as a way to reduce the spread of this disease pursuant to part of the NIH’s mission.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Despite the clear association between high-risk human papillomavirus (HR-HPV) and cervical cancer, there is a lack of understanding why some women clear HPV infection while others suffer from chronic infection that leads to cervical dysplasia and cancer. There is emerging evidence that the vaginal microbiome plays an important role in this process however the mechanisms linking vaginal bacteria with host responses, specifically antibody responses, to HPV infection and cervical neoplasia progression are underexplored. This project will study the role of antibody bound and unbound bacteria and associated bacterial functions in women with different HPV infection status and cervical dysplasia pathology.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative In this study, we will establish a robust data ecosystem for the IMPACT-MH consortium, producing data that is findable, accessible, interoperable, and reusable (FAIR). By adhering to these principles, we aim to greatly accelerate scientific discoveries in mental health research. To achieve these goals, the IMPACT-MH Data Coordination Center will establish three cores: Project Coordination and Data Management Core. Data Standards Core and Data Analytics Core. Through collaborative efforts and the utilization of advanced data management and analytics techniques, we are confident that our team will make significant contributions to the field and advance our understanding of mental health. .

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Children who have difficulty listening, especially in complex auditory environments, despite clinically normal hearing, are currently underserved because factors underlying their listening problems are not well understood. Our goal is to model the relationship between listening in noise ability and sentence comprehension which is a predictor of academic success in school-age children, with lexical knowledge as a mediator and working memory capacity as a moderator. Results will have direct implications in shifting clinical assessment and intervention paradigms for children with auditory processing problems.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR ADVANCING TRANSLATIONAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH STATEMENT Extreme heat events (EHEs) may intensify COVID-19 (C-19) propagation, representing the interaction of two devastating public health emergencies: the C-19 pandemic and climate change. This proposal will provide the first rigorous evidence of the association between EHEs and C-19 propagation using a quasi-experimental de- sign, as well as identifying individual and other factors increasing risk of C-19-related morbidity during EHEs. Findings will provide an important first step to overcome roadblocks that currently limit tailored public health risk messaging and interventions for individuals vulnerable to C-19-related and extreme heat event-related morbidity and mortality as these two public health emergencies interact. 1

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Narrative Aging impairs immune cell functions, which causes a reduction in our ability to fight off pathogens. Research has shown that aging causes accumulation of fibrous extracellular matrix material in the lymph nodes, which may change the biophysical properties of the tissue, and immune cell functions have been shown to be impacted by these biophysical properties. Here, we investigate how lymph node biophysical properties change in aging, which has not been investigated.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The Anton 3 supercomputer and data resource to be deployed at the Pittsburgh Supercomputing Center, through this award and in partnership with D. E. Shaw Research, will enable researchers to simulate larger and more complex biomolecular systems hundreds of times faster than any other resource available to the biomedical community and will make the resulting simulation data readily available to all. This powerful and unique resource will bring unprecedented understanding of fundamental processes of biology, leading to better ways to treat disease and improve quality of life.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE     During adolescence, exposure to media depicting gun violence, including mass shootings and police-involved shootings of Black people, has been linked to increased anxiety and depression symptoms, as well as racial stress and trauma among Black adolescents. This project seeks to determine if a novel probe of neurocognitive processing (i.e., steady-state visual evoked potentials) and experience sampling of media consumption of gun violence events can be used to predict future adolescent anxiety, depression, and racial inequities. Findings will enhance understanding of the negative effects of specific media content on adolescent mental health, enabling the development of targeted interventions to reduce anxiety and depression, with particular emphasis on addressing racial stress and trauma.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Glaucoma, the leading cause of irreversible blindness worldwide, has significant disparities in prevalence, presentation, and treatment in the United States (US). Pragmatic registry-based randomized controlled trials (RRCT) can increase participant diversity, more efficiently enroll patients, improve the generalizability of study findings, and reduce costs. This planning grant helps to prepare for a future RRCT in ophthalmology in the US, and to establish infrastructure vital to support additional pragmatic RRCTs in ophthalmology.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative This project will identify disparities in access to reproductive healthcare at the U.S. county level from 2009- 2021. This will be the first project to measure reproductive healthcare deserts, or areas where access to reproductive care is limited or nonexistent, and to document the relationship between access to reproductive healthcare and reproductive autonomy and maternal and infant health. This information will allow researchers, policymakers, and practitioners to better understand areas of need and to address inequalities in access to reproductive healthcare by race/ethnicity, socioeconomic status, and rurality.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE FOR OCCUPATIONAL SAFETY AND HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative  This project will accurately determine the longitudinal changes in physical characteristics through the different stages of pregnancy. With this knowledge, we can begin to biomechanically analyze how pregnant individuals perform different occupational tasks as they learn to adapt to their rapidly changing bodies. In turn, we can develop occupational standards and protocols unique to the pregnant population that are based on sound empirical research.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Capturing body segment changes during pregnancy to develop an accurate biomechanical model.
STUDY_SECTION_NAME: Safety and Occupational Health Study Section[SOH]

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Parkinson’s disease (PD) and Dementia with Lewy bodies (DLB) are related neurodegenerative diseases in which the protein alpha-synuclein disrupts transport of cargo in vesicles (trafficking) within the cell. We have previously found that increasing palmitoylation (modification of proteins by the fatty acid palmitate) by inhibiting a depalmitoylating enzyme, acyl protein thioesterase-1 (APT1), helps restore trafficking. In this proposal, we evaluate the potential of palmitoylation as a therapeutic strategy for PD and DLB by identifying and validating the specific proteins affected by APT1 inhibition and also determining if alpha-synuclein alters the global palmitoylation profile in a mouse model of PD/DLB.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative We seek to understand how infection with the enteric pathogen, Yersinia pseudotuberculosis, impacts M cells in the intestinal epithelium that overlying the Peyer’s patches in the small intestine. We will build a genetic system based on mouse intestinal organoids that express Cas9 only in M cells and use this system to interrogate how M cell proteins that are targeted by the Y. pseudotuberculosis Yops interfere with M cell functions. In addition, we will measure the numbers of M cells during an acute Y. pseudotuberculosis infection.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative This project will develop a universal sensitivity analysis framework for unmeasured confounding in drug-related public policy evaluation, which can simultaneously handle three data challenges commonly encountered in sensitivity analyses in drug-related policy research: non-binary treatments, multiple outcomes, and subgroup- specific effects. Such a universal sensitivity analysis framework will produce more reliable and robust causal inference results for drug-related public policy research in much broader settings. The new framework will be applied to study the causal influences of mobility policies (e.g., social distancing policies) on drug overdose deaths among the overall population and those among different racial groups, as well as other outcomes such as tobacco use and excessive drinking.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed studies are relevant to public health, as they aim to greatly improve the reference sequence database for eukaryotic pathogens, VEupathDB, a Bioinformatics Resource Centers (BRCs) project funded by the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases (NIAID). By significantly increasing the number of functionally annotated genes in this database, the research outcomes will offer crucial insights into the underlying biology of parasitic eukaryotes that have a significant impact on global health. This expanded knowledge will aid in identifying promising targets for further functional studies and ultimately contribute to the development of innovative therapeutic interventions for infectious diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Human health and disease is governed by the cellular and molecular processes of life and detail down to the atomic structure of individual proteins is often required to understand the mechanisms that control disease progression and to design drugs and other therapies such as vaccines to combat them. X-ray crystallography is one of the prime technologies used to generate high quality structures, generated from crystallographic data collected at large US facilities like synchrotrons and X-ray free electron lasers. The DIALS National Resource will support software for the processing of crystallographic data in automated pipelines that will accelerate the discovery of new treatments and improve health outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project narrative Fuchs corneal endothelial dystrophy (FECD) is a common disease leading to vision impairment worldwide. Corneal transplantation is the only therapy to date, however post-surgical complications and availability of donor corneas are serious challenges. This project will establish a complete FECD mouse model (currently unavailable) that will facilitate the study of the pathological process and testing of potential therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Apathy is the most prevalent neuropsychiatric symptom in Huntington’s disease (HD) and is strongly associated with cognitive dysfunction and suicide, which is the third most common cause of death in HD. The treatment of apathy should be a priority in the clinical care of HD patients, but the etiology or pathophysiology of apathy in HD is unknown. Understanding the mechanisms that regulate apathy in HD is crucial to develop effective treatments to prevent unnecessary deaths and improve the quality of life of patients with HD.

ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MIAMI SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: Project Narrative There is currently no disease specific treatment for patients with brain hemorrhage. Multiple surgical clinical trials have failed to show benefit in outcomes. The prospective study proposed here will examine the use of magnetic resonance imaging to assess the damaged tissues around the bleed and to examine if these tissues are salvageable. The results of this study will help select patients for an intervention in future clinical trials.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: TITLE: Pathogenesis of Vascular Anomalies with GNAQ mutations. PROJECT NARRATIVE: A class of disfiguring and life-threatening vascular anomalies is associated with mutations in the GNAQ gene that cause excessive, uncontrolled activity of the protein encoded by this gene. A key roadblock to finding effective, non-invasive treatments has been the lack of animal models for the study of disease development and treatment. Our project goals are to devise a murine model to study vascular disease progression and complications in response to GNAQ activating mutation, and to identify targeted treatments for patients.

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
PHR: NARRATIVE The proteome encompasses all the proteins present in a cell, tissue, or body fluid, serving as the fundamental framework for biological processes. It plays a crucial role in defining the characteristics of an organism. Despite its immense potential, the utilization of proteomics, a method for comprehensive proteome mapping based on the use of mass spectrometry, remains limited in our endeavors to comprehend diseases and largely unexplored in clinical investigations. This can be primarily attributed to the technology’s lower sample throughput and sensitivity compared to genomic technologies. We request funding for a novel mass spectrometer addressing both of these problems with an unprecedented performance several folds superior to existing instruments. The mass spectrometer will be used in several projects aimed at a better understanding of complex diseases such as cancer and neurodegenerative disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Insight into the 3D architectures of nucleic acids is essential for understanding their diverse roles in biotechnology and medicine, especially in the growing use of DNA and RNA vaccines and therapeutics. X3DNA-DSSR is a sophisticated, highly used software tool for the analysis, annotation, and visualization of 3D nucleic acid structures. The resource is employed in biomedical research and teaching in academic institutions and for the design of pharmaceuticals in industry.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: LOUISIANA STATE UNIV A&M COL BATON ROUGE
PHR: Project Narrative  The proposed research concerns the synthesis and evaluation of a glycoconjugate vaccine to be used for the prevention of infections caused by the bacteria Acinetobacter baumannii. A. baumannii is a major cause of hospital-related and combat-related infections resulting in serious illness and high rates of death. Because of an increasing incidence of drug resistance and because there is no approved vaccine for A. baumannii, novel and effective approaches to the prevention and treatment of infections that it causes are in demand.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative This project will address fundamental questions about the mechanisms that process and repair single-stranded DNA gaps to maintain genome stability. We will achieve our goals by using unique single-molecule approaches available in the Vindigni lab. This knowledge is crucial for basic research to inform how cancer cells regulate the balance between mutagenic and error-free mechanisms of gap repair, and how targeting these mechanisms modulates chemotherapy response, particularly in the context BRCA1-deficient tumors.

PHR: Narrative Patients with systemic lupus erythematosus and other autoimmune diseases can develop systemic disease flares upon even ambient sunlight, but the mechanisms are poorly understood. IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Warming eyelids of Meibomian gland dysfunction (MGD) patients to increase oil flow is a common treatment but most commercial therapies heat eyelids from the outside, even though the glands are located close to the inner surface of the eyelids. We are proposing a novel approach for warming the eyelids from inside by designing gold nanoparticle loaded contact lenses (GoldInLens) which can be warmed by exposure to a low intensity light source due to surface plasmon resonance (SPR). The warming lens will be placed on a low thermal conductivity lens which will act as an insulator to minimize heat transfer to the cornea. 3

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Narrative: Over 95% of adults are infected with gammaherpesviruses that are known to drive development of B cell lymphomas. Unfortunately, very little is known about the viral and host factors that influence the development of gammaherpesvirus-driven lymphomas. This proposal will determine how a classical antiviral factor of the host is usurped by gammaherpesviruses to establish life-long infection.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Decades of pharmacological work has shown that neuromodulators like dopamine and serotonin can affect the activity and output of the spinal cord to change movement, but it has been difficult to understand their natural functions and targets. We will measure where and when these neuromodulators are released in the spinal cord during locomotion, and use genetic tools to see exactly what types of neurons respond. We will also block the effects of these neuromodulators and study how movement is changed.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This proposal seeks funding for the purchase of a Nanostring CosMX SMI. This instrument is the preeminent instrument on the market for single-cell spatial -omics. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF NEW MEXICO HEALTH SCIS CTR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE - OVERALL The New Mexico Alzheimer’s Disease Research Center (NM ADRC) is developed from our exploratory ADRC funded in 2020 that has been able to recruit a large, underrepresented population of Hispanics/Latinos (H/L) and American Indians (AI) for inclusion in national databanks. This is the ADRC between the Canadian and Mexican borders in the Rocky Mountain region in a state that lacks resources in its rural areas. Some of our strategies include use of a mobile MRI scanner and community health workers to obtain MRI and plasma-based biomarkers to test for early dementia in this rural population to determine those in need of further diagnostic testing and possible inclusion in future clinical trials. The outreach program in the NM ADRC will facilitate recruitment of minorities into studies, identify potential trainees, promote AD/ADRC research in New Mexico, and expand dementia care to otherwise inaccessible individuals of the state.
